agyrium: <entryFree id="n1648" type="main" key="A^gy_ri^um"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ăgȳrĭum</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>n.</gen>, <sense id="n1648.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a very old town in Sicily</hi>, <hi rend="ital">not far from Enna</hi>, <hi rend="ital">the birthplace of Diodorus Siculus</hi>, now <hi rend="ital">S. Filippo d'Argiro</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:3:28" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Verr. 2, 3, 28</bibl>.—Hence, <orth extent="full" lang="la">Ăgyrĭnen-ses</orth>, <itype>ium</itype>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:3:28" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Verr. 2, 3, 28</bibl>; or <orth extent="full" lang="la">Ăgyrī-ni</orth>, <itype>orum</itype>, <hi rend="ital">inhabitants of Agyrium</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:3:91" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 3, 8, 14, § 91</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
ah: <entryFree id="n1649" type="main" key="a_h"><orth extent="full" lang="la">āh</orth> or <orth extent="full" lang="la">ā</orth> (v. Neue, Formenl. II. 812), <pos>interj.</pos> <cb n="AIO" /> [acc. to <bibl default="NO"><author>Prisc.</author> 570</bibl> P. contract. from aha], <sense id="n1649.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">ah! alas! ha! ah me!</hi> an exclamation. </sense><sense id="n1649.1" n="I" level="1"> Of pain or grief, Gr. <foreign lang="greek">ai)/, ai)/</foreign>: <cit><quote lang="la">ah, nescis quam doleam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,002:5:1:61" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Heaut. 5, 1, 61</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,001:1:15" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> E. 1, 15</bibl>. —</sense><sense id="n1649.2" n="II" level="1"> Of entreaty to avert an evil: <cit><quote lang="la">ah! noli,</quote> <trans><tr>do not</tr>, <tr>I pray!</tr></trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,001:1:3:22" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Am. 1, 3, 22</bibl></cit>. —</sense><sense id="n1649.3" n="III" level="1"> Of indignation or reproach: <cit><quote lang="la">ah stulte,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,006:4:7:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Ad. 4, 7, 6</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ah, rogitas?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,001:5:1:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> And. 5, 1, 9</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">3, 1, 11</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n1649.4" n="IV" level="1"> Of admonition: <cit><quote lang="la">ah, ne me obsecra,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,001:3:3:11" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> And. 3, 3, 11</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ah desine,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 5, 6, 8</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n1649.5" n="V" level="1"> Of consolation: <cit><quote lang="la">quid? ah volet, certo scio,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,003:5:2:50" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Eun. 5, 2, 50</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n1649.6" n="VI" level="1"> Of raillery or joy, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,008:1:2:39" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Curc. 1, 2, 39</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
aha: <entryFree id="n1650" type="main" key="a^ha^"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăhă</orth>, <pos>interj.</pos> <etym>acc. to <bibl default="NO"><author>Prisc.</author> 570</bibl> P., primitive of the preced., but more rare</etym>, <sense id="n1650.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">aha! ah! haha!</hi> an exclamation. </sense><sense id="n1650.1" n="I" level="1"> Of reproof or denial: <cit><quote lang="la">aha, tace,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,020:4:4:36" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Truc. 4, 4, 36</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,017:2:4:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Rud. 2, 4, 6</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">aha, minime,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,004:1:1:54" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Bacch. 1, 1, 54</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n1650.2" n="II" level="1"> Of laughter, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,004:4:7:11" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Bacch. 4, 7, 11</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
ahala: <entryFree id="n1651" type="main" key="A^ha_la"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ăhāla</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <sense id="n1651.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a Roman family name</hi>, e. g. C. Servilius Ahala, who slew the turbulent Maelius, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,013:1:1:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Cat. 1, 1, 3</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,051:16:56" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Sen. 16, 56</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
aharna: <entryFree id="n1652" type="main" key="Aharna"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Aharna</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, <sense id="n1652.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a town in Etruria</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:10:25" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 10, 25</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
ahenator: <entryFree id="n1653" type="main" key="a^he_na_tor"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăhēnātor</orth>, v. aëneator.</entryFree>
aheneus: <entryFree id="n1654" type="main" key="a^he_ne^us"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăhēnĕus</orth>, <itype>ahenipes</itype>, etc., v. aën-.</entryFree>
ai: <entryFree id="n1655" type="main" key="ai1" n="1"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ai</orth>, in old Lat., corresponding to ae: AIDILIS, CAISAR, AITERNOS, for Aedilis, Caesar, aeternus; also, still later, sometimes in the poets in the termination of the genitive of the first decl.; but, as in Enn. and Lucr., <sense id="n1655.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">per diaeresin</hi> always dissyl. with long penult: <cit><quote lang="la">furit intus aquāï,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:7:464" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 7, 464</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">aurāï simplicis ignem,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 6, 747</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">terrāï frugiferāï,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1294,001:11:91:5" default="NO"><author>Mart.</author> 11, 91, 5</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:1:7:18" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 1, 7, 18</bibl>; Spauld. <bibl default="NO"><author>Prisc.</author> 728</bibl>; Prob. 1438; Vel. Long. 2222; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1294,001:Vict. 2460" default="NO"><author>Mart.</author> Vict. 2460</bibl> P.—In prim. syllables, as in <case>voc.</case> Gaĭ, <hi rend="ital">ăi</hi> could not be changed to <hi rend="ital">ae</hi> if <hi rend="ital">i</hi> was an ending; but <hi rend="ital">i</hi> was changed to <hi rend="ital">i</hi> cons., when the word received accession, e. g. <hi rend="ital">Gaius.</hi>—When a conson. followed <hi rend="ital">ai</hi>, as in CNAIVOS for <foreign lang="greek">*g*n*a*iv*o*s</foreign> (v. the Epitaphs of the Scipios, in the Append.), <hi rend="ital">ae</hi> was written at a later per., as Gnaeus; hence from <foreign lang="greek">*gra/i+os</foreign> both Graecus and Graius; from <foreign lang="greek">*ai)/akos</foreign>, Aeacus, and Aiax, for <foreign lang="greek">*ai)/as</foreign>, were formed; just as Achaeus or Achivus with Achaĭus or Achaĭcus was used.</sense><sense id="n1655.1" n="2" level="3"> * <orth extent="full" lang="la">ai</orth> = <foreign lang="greek">ai)/</foreign>, <pos>interj.</pos>, denoting grief, <hi rend="ital">ah! alas!</hi> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:10:215" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 10, 215</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
<entryFree id="n1656" type="main" key="ai2" n="3"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ai</orth>, <sense id="n1656.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">imper.</hi>, from aio.</sense></entryFree>
aiens: <entryFree id="n1657" type="main" key="aiens"><orth extent="full" lang="la">aiens</orth>, v. aio <sense id="n1657.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></sense></entryFree>
aientia: <entryFree id="n1658" type="hapax" key="aienti^a"><orth extent="full" lang="la">aientĭa</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>aio</etym>, <sense id="n1658.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">an affirmation</hi> (opp. negatio), <bibl default="NO"><author>Mart. Cap.</author> 4, p. 75</bibl> Vulc.</sense></entryFree>
aio: <entryFree id="n1659" type="main" key="a_io"><orth extent="full" lang="la">āio</orth>, <sense id="n1659.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">verb. defect.</hi> The forms in use are: <hi rend="ital">pres. indic.</hi> āio, ăis, ait—aiunt; <hi rend="ital">subj.</hi> aias, aiat—aiant; <hi rend="ital">imperf. indic.</hi> throughout, aiebam, aiebas, etc.; <hi rend="ital">imper.</hi> ai, rare; <hi rend="ital">part. pres.</hi> aiens, rare; once in <bibl default="NO"><author>App.</author> M. 6, p. 178</bibl> Elm.; and once as <pos>P. a.</pos> in <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,042:11:49" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Top. 11, 49</bibl>, v. below. Cic. wrote the <hi rend="ital">pres.</hi> aiio, acc. to <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:1:4:11" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 1, 4, 11</bibl>.—From ais with the <hi rend="ital">interrog. part.</hi> ne, ain is used in colloquial language. For <hi rend="ital">imperf.</hi> also aibas, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,019:2:4:28" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Trin. 2, 4, 28</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,006:4:2:22" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Ad. 4, 2, 22</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">aibat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,019:4:2:33" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Trin. 4, 2, 33</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">5, 2, 16</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">aibant,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 1, 2, 175</bibl></cit>; 4, 2, 102; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,001:3:3:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> And. 3, 3, 3</bibl>; ai is dissyl., but in the <hi rend="ital">imper.</hi> also monosyl., <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,020:5:49" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Truc. 5, 49</bibl>; cf. Bentl. ad <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,006:4:6:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Ad. 4, 6, 5</bibl>. Acc. to <bibl default="NO"><author>Prisc.</author> 818</bibl> P., the <hi rend="ital">pres.</hi> ait seems to take the place of a perf., but acc. to <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0996,001:1482" default="NO"><author>Val. Prob.</author> 1482</bibl> P., there was a real <hi rend="ital">perf.</hi> ai, aisti, ait; <cit><quote lang="la">as aisti,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2468,001:Ep. 54" default="NO"><author>Aug.</author> Ep. 54</bibl></cit> and 174: <cit><quote lang="la">aierunt,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Tert.</author> Fuga in Persec. 6</bibl></cit>; the <hi rend="ital">pres. inf.</hi> aiere is found in <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2468,001:Trin. 9:10" default="NO"><author>Aug.</author> Trin. 9, 10</bibl> [cf. <foreign lang="greek">h)mi/</foreign> = I say; Sanscr. <hi rend="ital">perf.</hi> 3d <number>sing.</number> āha = he spake; ad<hi rend="ital">ag</hi>ium, ad<hi rend="ital">ag</hi>io; negare for ne<hi rend="ital">ig</hi>are; Umbr. <hi rend="ital">ai</hi>tu = dicito; Engl. aye = yea, yes, and Germ. ja], <hi rend="ital">to say yes</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to assent</hi> (opp. <hi rend="ital">nego</hi>, to say no; with the ending <hi rend="ital">-tumo</hi>, aiutumo; contract. autumo; opp. negumo; v. autumo). </sense><sense id="n1659.1" n="I" level="1"> In gen.: vel ai vel nega, Naev. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Prisc.</author> 473</bibl> P.: <cit><quote lang="la">veltu mihi aias vel neges,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,017:2:4:14" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Rud. 2, 4, 14</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">negat quis? nego. Ait? aio,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,003:2:2:21" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Eun. 2, 2, 21</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Diogenes ait, Antipater negat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:3:23" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Off. 3, 23</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quasi ego id curem, quid ille aiat aut neget,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,048:2:22" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Fin. 2, 22</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,030:12:34" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Rab. Post. 12, 34</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n1659.2" n="II" level="1"> Esp. </sense><sense id="n1659.3" n="A" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">To say</hi>, <hi rend="ital">affirm</hi>, or <hi rend="ital">assert something</hi> (while <hi rend="ital">dicere</hi> signifies to speak in order to inform, and <hi rend="ital">affirmare</hi>, to speak in affirmation, Doed. Syn. 4, 6 sq.—Therefore different from <hi rend="ital">inquam</hi>, I say, I reply, since <cb n="AIO" /> aio is commonly used in indirect, and inquam in direct discourse; cf. Doed. as cited above; Herz. ad <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:C. 48:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> C. 48, 3</bibl>; and Ramsh. Gr. 800). </sense><sense id="n1659.4" n="a" level="4"> In indirect discourse: insanam autem illam (sc. esse) aiunt, quia, etc., Pac. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,073:2:23:36" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Her. 2, 23, 36</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,005:1:1:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Capt. 1, 1, 3</bibl>: <hi rend="ital">Ch.</hi> Hodie uxorem ducis? <hi rend="ital">Pa.</hi> Aiunt, <hi rend="ital">they say so</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 2, 1, 21</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">ait hac laetitiā Deiotarum elatum vino se obruisse,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,034:chapter=9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Deiot. 9</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">debere eum aiebat, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:1:18" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Verr. 2, 1, 18</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Tarquinium a Cicerone immissum aiebant,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:C. 48:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> C. 48, 8</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Vos sapere et solos aio bene vivere,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Hor.</author> Ep. 1, 15, 45</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,004:1:2:121" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> S. 1, 2, 121</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Ep. 1, 1, 88</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">1, 7, 22</bibl>.— </sense><sense id="n1659.5" n="b" level="4"> In direct discourse: Ennio delector, ait quispiam, quod non discedit a communi more verborum; <cit><quote lang="la">Pacuvio, inquit alius,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,040:11:36" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Or. 11, 36</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Vos o, quibus integer aevi Sanguis, ait, solidaeque, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:2:639" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 2, 639</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">6, 630</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">7, 121</bibl>; <cit><quote lang="la">12, 156: O fortunati mercatores! gravis annis Miles ait,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,004:1:1:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> S. 1, 1, 4</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Ep. 1, 15, 40</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">1, 16, 47</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,004:2:7:72" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> S. 2, 7, 72</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">1, 3, 22</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n1659.6" n="c" level="4"> With <hi rend="ital">acc.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Causa optumast, Nisi quid pater ait aliud,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,001:5:4:47" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> And. 5, 4, 47</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Admirans ait haec,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0472,001:5:3:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cat.</author> 5, 3, 4</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0472,001:63:84" default="NO" valid="yes">63, 84</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">Haec ait,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:1:297" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 1, 297</bibl></cit>; v. B.—</sense><sense id="n1659.7" n="B" level="2"> Simply <hi rend="ital">to speak</hi>, and esp. in the form of transition, sic ait, <hi rend="ital">thus he speaks</hi> or <hi rend="ital">says</hi> (cf. the Hom. <foreign lang="greek">w(\s fa/to</foreign>): <cit><quote lang="la">Sic ait, et dicto citius tumida aequora placat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:1:142" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 1, 142</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">5, 365</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">9, 749</bibl>.— <cit><quote lang="la">Also of what follows: Sic ait in molli fixa toro cubitum: “Tandem,” etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1224,001:1:3:34" default="NO"><author>Prop.</author> 1, 3, 34</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n1659.8" n="C" level="2"> Ut ait quispiam (regularly in this order in Cic.), in quoting an unusual expression, <hi rend="ital">as one says</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">ut ait Statius noster in Synephebis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,051:chapter=7" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Sen. 7</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ut ait Homerus,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 10</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ut ait Theophrastus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:1:19:45" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Tusc. 1, 19, 45</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ut ait Thucydides,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,002:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Them. 2</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ut ait Cicero,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:7:1:51" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 7, 1, 51</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:8:6:73" default="NO">8, 6, 73</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:9:4:40" default="NO">9, 4, 40</bibl>; <cit><quote lang="la">9, 56, 60: ut Cicero ait,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:10:7:14" default="NO"><author>id.</author> 10, 7, 14</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:12:3:11" default="NO">12, 3, 11</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">ut Demosthenes ait,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:11:1:22" default="NO"><author>id.</author> 11, 1, 22</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ut rumor ait,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1224,001:5:4:47" default="NO"><author>Prop.</author> 5, 4, 47</bibl></cit>: uti mos vester ait, Hor S. 2, 7, 79.—So without <hi rend="ital">def. subject</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">ut ait in Synephebis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:1:14:31" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 1, 14, 31</bibl></cit>.— </sense><sense id="n1659.9" n="D" level="2"> Aiunt, ut aiunt, quemadmodum or quod aiunt, in quoting a proverbial or technical phrase, <hi rend="ital">as they say</hi>, <hi rend="ital">as is said</hi>, <hi rend="ital">as the saying is</hi> (Gr. <foreign lang="greek">to\ lego/menon, w(s fasi/</foreign>; Fr. on dit; <cit><quote lang="la">Germ. man sagt), either placed after it or interposed: eum rem fidemque perdere aiunt,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,008:4:2:18" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Curc. 4, 2, 18</bibl></cit>: ut quimus, aiunt; <cit><quote lang="la">quando, ut volumus, non licet,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,001:4:5:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> And. 4, 5, 10</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">docebo sus, ut aiunt, oratorem eum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:2:57" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> de Or. 2, 57</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Iste claudus, quemadmodum aiunt, pilam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,027:chapter=28" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Pis. 28</bibl></cit> B. and K. —Also in telling an anecdote: <cit><quote lang="la">conspexit, ut aiunt, Adrasum quendam vacuā tonsoris in umbrā,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Hor.</author> Ep. 1, 7, 49</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">1, 17, 18</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n1659.10" n="E" level="2"> In judic. lang.: ait lex, ait praetor, etc., <hi rend="ital">the law</hi>, <hi rend="ital">the prœtor says</hi>, i. e. <hi rend="ital">prescribes</hi>, <hi rend="ital">commands</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">ut ait lex Julia,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:24:3:64" default="NO"><author>Dig.</author> 24, 3, 64</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Praetor ait, in eadem causā eum exhibere, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:2:9:1" default="NO"><author>ib.</author> 2, 9, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Aiunt aediles, qui mancipia vendunt, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:21:1:1" default="NO"><author>ib.</author> 21, 1, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Ait oratio, fas esse eum, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:24:1:32 al" default="NO"><author>ib.</author> 24, 1, 32 al.</bibl></cit>—</sense><sense id="n1659.11" n="F" level="1"> Ain? = aisne? also often strengthened: ain tu? ain tute? ain tandem? ain vero? in conversational lang., a form of interrogation which includes the idea of surprise or wonder, sometimes also of reproof or sorrow, <hi rend="ital">do you really mean so? indeed? really? is it possible?</hi> often only an emphatic <hi rend="ital">what?</hi> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,009:3:4:73" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Ep. 3, 4, 73</bibl>: <hi rend="ital">Merc.</hi> Servus esne an liber? <hi rend="ital">Sos.</hi> Utcumque animo conlibitumst meo. <hi rend="ital">Merc.</hi> Ain vero? <hi rend="ital">Sos.</hi> Aio enim vero, <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 3, 4, 188</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,001:1:1:128" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Am. 1, 1, 128</bibl>: <hi rend="ital">Phil.</hi> Pater, inquam, aderit jam hic meus. <hi rend="ital">Call.</hi> Ain tu, pater? <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,013:2:1:36" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Most. 2, 1, 36</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,009:5:2:33" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Ep. 5, 2, 33</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,003:2:2:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Aul. 2, 2, 9</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,008:2:3:44" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Curc. 2, 3, 44</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,005:3:4:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Hec. 3, 4, 1</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,003:3:5:19" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Eun. 3, 5, 19</bibl> al: <cit><quote lang="la">Ain tu? Scipio hic Metellus proavum suum nescit censorem non fuisse?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:6:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 6, 1</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">4, 5 al.</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">ain tute,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,020:1:2:90" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Truc. 1, 2, 90</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ain tandem ita esse, ut dicis?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,003:2:4:19" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Aul. 2, 4, 19</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,002:5:2:47" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> As. 5, 2, 47</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,019:4:2:145" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Trin. 4, 2, 145</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,001:5:3:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> And. 5, 3, 4</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">ain tandem? insanire tibi videris, quod, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:9:21" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 9, 21</bibl></cit> Manut.; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:6:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Att. 6, 2</bibl>.—Also with a <hi rend="ital">plur. verb</hi> (cf. age with <hi rend="ital">plur. verb</hi>, s. v. ago, IV. a.): <cit><quote lang="la">ain tandem? inquit, num castra vallata non habetis?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:10:25" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 10, 25</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n1659.12" n="G" level="1"> Quid ais? (as in conversation).— </sense><sense id="n1659.13" n="a" level="4"> With the idea of surprise, astonishment, <foreign lang="greek">*ti/ le/geis</foreign> (cf. Quid dixisti? <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,001:3:4:14" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> And. 3, 4, 14</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,003:5:6:16" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Eun. 5, 6, 16</bibl>, <foreign lang="greek">*ti/ ei)=pas</foreign>); <hi rend="ital">what do you say? what? Merc.</hi> Quis herus est igitur tibi? <hi rend="ital">Sos.</hi> Amphitruo, quicum nuptast Alcumena. <hi rend="ital">Merc.</hi> Quid ais? Quid nomen tibist? <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,001:1:1:208" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Am. 1, 1, 208</bibl>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,001:4:1:42" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> And. 4, 1, 42</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,002:5:1:27" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Heaut. 5, 1, 27</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n1659.14" n="b" level="4"> When one asks <pb n="79" /> <cb n="ALA" /> another for his meaning, opinion, or judgment, <hi rend="ital">what do you mean? what do you say</hi> or <hi rend="ital">think? Th.</hi> Ita me di ament, honestust. <hi rend="ital">Pa.</hi> Quid tu ais, Gnatho? Num quid habes, quod contemnas? Quid tu autem, Thraso? <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,003:3:2:21" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Eun. 3, 2, 21</bibl>: Hunc ais? <hi rend="ital">Do you mean this man?</hi> (= dicis, q. v., II.) <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0969,001:4:27" default="NO"><author>Pers.</author> 4, 27</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n1659.15" n="c" level="4"> When one wishes to try or prove another, <hi rend="ital">what is your opinion? what do you say?</hi> Sed quid ais? quid Amphitruoni [dono] a Telebois datumst? <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,001:1:1:262" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Am. 1, 1, 262</bibl>.—Hence, * <orth extent="full" lang="la">āiens</orth>, <itype>entis</itype>, <pos>P. a.</pos>, <hi rend="ital">affirming</hi>, <hi rend="ital">affirmative</hi> (usu. affirmativus): <cit><quote lang="la">negantia contraria aientibus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,042:11:49" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Top. 11, 49</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
ain: <entryFree id="n1660" type="main" key="ain"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ain</orth> = aisne, v. aio, II. F.</entryFree>
aithales: <entryFree id="n1661" type="greek" key="a^i_tha^les"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăīthăles</orth>, <gen>n.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)eiqale/s</foreign> (evergreen), <sense id="n1661.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a plant</hi>, <hi rend="ital">also called</hi> Aizoon, <hi rend="ital">houseleek</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>App.</author> Herb. 123</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
aiusloquens: <entryFree id="n1662" type="main" key="A_ius Lo^quens"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Āius Lŏquens</orth> or <orth extent="full" lang="la">Āius Lŏcūtius</orth>, <sense id="n1662.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a deity among the Romans</hi>, <hi rend="ital">who made the announcement to them</hi>, <hi rend="ital">The Gauls are coming!</hi> Varr. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:16:17:2" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 16, 17, 2</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">Aius iste Loquens, quando, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,053:2:32:69" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Div. 2, 32, 69</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 2, 1, 45</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">templum in Novā Viā Aio Locutio fieri,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:5:50" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 5, 50</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:5:32" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 5, 32</bibl>; cf. Becker, Antiq. vol. 4, p. 35.</sense></entryFree>
aizoon: <entryFree id="n1663" type="greek" key="a^i_zo_o^n"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăīzōŏn</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>n.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)ei/zwon</foreign> (ever-living), <sense id="n1663.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">an evergreen plant.</hi> </sense><sense id="n1663.1" n="I" level="1"> Majus, <hi rend="ital">live-forever</hi>, <hi rend="ital">houseleek</hi>: Sempervivum tectorum, Linn.; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:25:160" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 25, 13, 102, § 160</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n1663.2" n="II" level="1"> Minus or minusculum, <hi rend="ital">stone-crop</hi>: Sedum album, Linn.; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:25:160" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 25, 13, 102, § 160</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
ajax: <entryFree id="n1664" type="main" key="A_jax"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ājax</orth>, <itype>ācis</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*ai)/as</foreign>, <sense id="n1664.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the name of two Greeks renowned for their bravery.</hi> </sense><sense id="n1664.1" n="I" level="1"> Ajax Telamonius, <hi rend="ital">son of Telamon</hi>, who contended with Ulysses for the possession of the arms of Achilles, and, when the former obtained them, became insane and killed himself. From his blood the hyacinth sprang up, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:13:395" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 13, 395</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n1664.2" n="II" level="1"> Ajax Oileus, <hi rend="ital">son of Oileus</hi>, king of the Locri, who violated Cassandra, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:1:41" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 1, 41</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:2:66" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> de Or. 2, 66</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n1664.3" n="III" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">The title of an unfinished tragedy of the emperor Augustus</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=aug.:85" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Aug. 85</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
ajuga: <entryFree id="n1665" type="main" key="aju_ga"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ajūga</orth>: <sense id="n1665.0" n="I" level="1"><cit><quote lang="la">abiga,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1011,001:167" default="NO"><author>Scrib.</author> 167</bibl></cit>; cf. Rhod. Lex.</sense></entryFree>
ala: <entryFree id="n1666" type="main" key="a_la"><orth extent="full" lang="la">āla</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>for axla, contr. from axilla, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,040:45:153" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Or. 45, 153</bibl>; cf. <foreign lang="greek">a)/gxos</foreign> = <foreign lang="greek">w)=mos</foreign> (Hesych.) = shoulder = O. H. Germ. Ahsala; Germ. Achsel</etym>. <sense id="n1666.0" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>, <hi rend="ital">a wing</hi>, as of a bird: galli plausu premunt alas, Enn. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,053:2:26" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Div. 2, 26</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:3:226 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 3, 226 al.</bibl>: <hi rend="ital">Me.</hi> Vox mihi ad aurīs advolavit. <hi rend="ital">So.</hi> Ne ego homo infelix fui, qui non alas intervelli, <hi rend="ital">that I did not pluck off its wings</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,001:1:1:170" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Am. 1, 1, 170</bibl>.—<usg type="style">Poet.</usg>, of the gods: <cit><quote lang="la">Mors atris circumvolat alis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,004:2:1:58" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> S. 2, 1, 58</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">volucris Fati Tardavit alas,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:2:17:25" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> C. 2, 17, 25</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">bibulae Cupidinis alae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,004:1:233" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> A. A. 1, 233</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">furvis circumdatus alis Somnus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0660,001:2:1:89" default="NO"><author>Tib.</author> 2, 1, 89</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">me jocundis Sopor impulit alis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1224,001:1:3:45" default="NO"><author>Prop.</author> 1, 3, 45</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Madidis Notus evolat alis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:1:264" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 1, 264</bibl></cit>.—Of sails: <cit><quote lang="la">velorum pandimus alas,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:3:520" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 3, 520</bibl></cit>.—Of oars: <cit><quote lang="la">classis centenis remiget alis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1224,001:4:6:47" default="NO"><author>Prop.</author> 4, 6, 47</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">remigium alarum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:1:301" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 1, 301</bibl></cit> (cf. Hom. Od. 11, 125); <cit><quote lang="la">so inversely remi is used of wings: super fluctus alarum insistere remis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:5:558" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 5, 558</bibl></cit> (cf. <foreign lang="greek">pteroi=s e)re/ssei</foreign>, Eur. Iphig. Taur. 289; Aeschyl. Agam. 52; and cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:6:743" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 6, 743</bibl>). —Of wind and lightning: <cit><quote lang="la">Nisus Emicat et ventis et fulminis ocior alis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:5:319 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 5, 319 al.</bibl></cit>—</sense><sense id="n1666.1" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Transf.</usg> </sense><sense id="n1666.2" n="A" level="2"> In man, <hi rend="ital">the upper and under part of the arm</hi>, <hi rend="ital">where it unites with the shoulder; the armpit</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:9:41" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 9, 41</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:30:34" default="NO" valid="yes">30, 34</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">aliquid sub alā portare,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Hor.</author> Ep. 1, 13, 12</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">hirquinae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,015:4:2:51" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Poen. 4, 2, 51</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">hirsutae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,003:12:5" default="NO"><author>Hor.</author> Epod. 12, 5</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">halitus oris et alarum vitia,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:21:142" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 21, 20, 83, § 142</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">virus alarum et sudores,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:35:185" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 35, 15, 52, § 185</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">sudor alarum,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Petr.</author> 128</bibl></cit> (many Romans were accustomed to pluck out the hair from the armpits, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Ep. 114" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Ep. 114</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1276,001:11:157" default="NO"><author>Juv.</author> 11, 157</bibl>; v. alipilus).—</sense><sense id="n1666.3" n="B" level="2"> In animals, <hi rend="ital">the hollow where the foreleg is joined to the shoulder; the shoulder - blade.</hi>—Of elephants, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:11:324" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 11, 40, 95, § 324</bibl>.—Of frogs, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:9:159" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 9, 51, 74, § 159</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n1666.4" n="C" level="2"> In trees and plants, <hi rend="ital">the hollow where the branch unites with the stem</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:16:29" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 16, 7, 10, § 29</bibl>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:22:45" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 22, 18, 21, § 45</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:25:38 al" default="NO" valid="yes">25, 5, 18, § 38 al.</bibl>—</sense><sense id="n1666.5" n="D" level="2"> In buildings, <hi rend="ital">the wings</hi>, <hi rend="ital">the side apartments on the right and left of the court</hi>, <hi rend="ital">the side halls</hi> or <hi rend="ital">porches</hi>, <hi rend="ital">the colonnades;</hi> called also in Gr. <foreign lang="greek">ptera/</foreign>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1056,001:6:4:137" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vitr.</author> 6, 4, 137</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1056,001:4:7:92" default="NO" valid="yes">4, 7, 92</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n1666.6" n="E" level="2"> In milit. lang., <hi rend="ital">the wing of an army</hi> (thus conceived of as a bird of prey), commonly composed of the Roman cavalry and the troops of the allies, esp. their horsemen; hence, <hi rend="ital">alarii</hi> <cb n="ALAC" /> in contrast with <hi rend="ital">legionarii</hi>, and separated from them in enumeration, also having a leader, called praefectus alae, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,004:2:59 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> H. 2, 59 al.</bibl>; cf. Lips. de Milit. Rom. 1, 10 Manut.; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:2:17" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 2, 17 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl>; Herz. ad <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:1:51" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 1, 51</bibl>; Smith, Dict. Antiq.; Cincius ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:16:4:6" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 16, 4, 6</bibl>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:10:9:1" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 10, 9, 1</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">Alae, equites: ob hoc alae dicti, quia pedites tegunt alarum vice,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Serv.</author> ad Verg. A. 4, 121</bibl></cit>: peditatu, equitibus atque alis cum hostium legionibus pugnavit, Cato ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:15:9:5" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 15, 9, 5</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:2:13:45" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Off. 2, 13, 45</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">dextera ala (in alas divisum socialem exercitum habebat) in primā acie locata est,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:31:21" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 31, 21</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1044,001:2:117 al" default="NO"><author>Vell.</author> 2, 117 al.</bibl>—An <hi rend="ital">ala</hi>, as a military division, usu. consisted of about 500 men, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:10:29" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 10, 29</bibl>.!*? Such <hi rend="ital">alae</hi> gave names to several towns, since they were either levied from them, quartered in them, or, after the expiration of their time of service, received the lands of such towns.—So, Ala Flaviana, Ala Nova, et saep. (cf. castrum, II. 1. <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi>).</sense></entryFree>
alabanda: <entryFree id="n1667" type="main" key="A^la^banda"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ălăbanda</orth>, <itype>ōrum</itype>, <gen>n.</gen> and <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, <sense id="n1667.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a city in the interior of Caria</hi>, <hi rend="ital">distinguished for its wealth and luxury</hi>, <hi rend="ital">founded by Alabandus</hi>, <hi rend="ital">who was honored by the inhabitants as a deity;</hi> now <hi rend="ital">Arab-Hissar; plur.</hi> form, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:3:15" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> N. D. 3, 15</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">3, 19</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:33:18" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 33, 18</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:38:13" default="NO" valid="yes">38, 13</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1276,001:3:70" default="NO"><author>Juv.</author> 3, 70</bibl>; <number>sing.</number> form, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1318,001:5:29" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> Ep. 5, 29</bibl>.—Hence, <orth extent="full" lang="la">Ălăbandenses</orth>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:3:19" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> N. D. 3, 19</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:38:13" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 38, 13</bibl>; or <orth extent="full" lang="la">Ălăbandēni</orth>, <hi rend="ital">the inhabitants of Alabanda</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:45:25" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 45, 25</bibl>.—<orth extent="full" lang="la">Ălăbandeus</orth> (four syll.), <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos>, <hi rend="ital">of Alabanda</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Hierocles,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,039:chapter=95" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Brut. 95</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1056,001:7:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vitr.</author> 7, 5</bibl>.—<orth extent="full" lang="la">Ălă-bandĭcus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos>, <hi rend="ital">pertaining to Alabanda</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:19:174" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 19, 9, 56, § 174</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:21:16 al" default="NO" valid="yes">21, 4, 10, § 16 al.</bibl>—Also, <orth extent="full" lang="la">Ălăbandĭnus</orth>, <itype>a</itype>, um: gemma, <hi rend="ital">a precious stone</hi>, named after Alabanda, <bibl default="NO"><author>Isid.</author> Orig. 16, 13</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
alabarches: <entryFree id="n1668" type="main" key="a^la^barches"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ălăbarches</orth> and <orth extent="full" lang="la">ălăbarchĭa</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, v. arabarches, arabarchia.</entryFree>
alabaster: <entryFree id="n1669" type="greek" key="a^la^baster"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ălăbaster</orth>, <itype>tri</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> (<number>plur.</number> also <orth extent="full" lang="la">ălăba-stra</orth>, <gen>n.</gen>), = <foreign lang="greek">a)la/bastros</foreign>, <number>plur.</number> <foreign lang="greek">-ra</foreign>. <sense id="n1669.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">A box</hi> or <hi rend="ital">casket for perfumes</hi>, <hi rend="ital">tapering to a point at the top</hi>, <hi rend="ital">a box for unguents</hi>: alabaster plenus unguenti, * Cic. Ac. Post. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> 545, 15</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">mulier habens alabastrum unguenti,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,001:26:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Matt. 26, 7</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,002:14:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> Marc. 14, 3</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,003:7:37" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> Luc. 7, 37</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">redolent alabastra,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1294,001:11:8:9" default="NO"><author>Mart.</author> 11, 8, 9</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:13:19" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 13, 2, 3, § 19</bibl>.—Hence, </sense><sense id="n1669.1" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">The form of a rose-bud</hi>, <hi rend="ital">pointed at the top</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">in virides alabastros fastigato,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:21:14" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 21, 4, 10, § 14</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
alabastrites: <entryFree id="n1670" type="greek" key="a^la^bastri_tes"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ălăbastrītes</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)labastri/ths</foreign>. <sense id="n1670.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">A stone</hi>, <hi rend="ital">composed of carbonate of lime</hi> (not of gypsum, like the modern alabaster), <hi rend="ital">alabaster-stone;</hi> also called onyx and onychites, from which unguent and perfume boxes were made, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:36:60" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 36, 8, 12, § 60</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n1670.1" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">A precious stone found in the region of the Egyptian town Alabastron</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:37:143" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 37, 10, 54, § 143</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
alabastron: <entryFree id="n1671" type="main" key="A^la^bastron"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ălăbastron</orth> <itype>oppidum</itype> (<foreign lang="greek">*)alabastrw=n po/lis</foreign>, Ptol.), <sense id="n1671.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a city of Egypt in the Thebais</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:5:61" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 5, 9, 11, § 61</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
alabeta: <entryFree id="n1672" type="greek" key="a^la^be_ta"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ălăbēta</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)labh/s</foreign>, <sense id="n1672.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a fish found in the Nile</hi>: Silurus anguillaris, Linn.; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:5:51" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 5, 9, 10, § 51</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
alabis: <entryFree id="n1673" type="main" key="A^la^bis"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ălăbis</orth>, <itype>is</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <sense id="n1673.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a river in Sicily</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1345,001:14:228" default="NO"><author>Sil.</author> 14, 228</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
alacer: <entryFree id="n1674" type="main" key="a^la^cer"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ălăcer</orth>, <itype>cris, e</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> (also in <sense id="n1674.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">masc.</hi> alacris, Enn., v. below; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,003:2:3:13" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Eun. 2, 3, 13</bibl>, and <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:5:380" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 5, 380</bibl>; cf. <bibl default="NO"><author>Charis.</author> p. 63</bibl> P.—In more ancient times, alacer <gen>comm.</gen>; cf. <bibl default="NO"><author>Serv.</author> ad Verg. A. 6, 685</bibl>, and 2. acer) [perh. akin to alere = to nourish, and olēre = to grow; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:6:17" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Verr. 1, 6, 17</bibl>; Auct. ad <bibl default="NO"><author>Her.</author> 2, 19, 29</bibl>], <hi rend="ital">lively</hi>, <hi rend="ital">brisk</hi>, <hi rend="ital">quick</hi>, <hi rend="ital">eager</hi>, <hi rend="ital">active; glad</hi>, <hi rend="ital">happy</hi>, <hi rend="ital">cheerful</hi> (opp. languidus; cf. Doed. Syn. 3, 247, and 4, 450.—In the class. per., esp. in Cicero, with the access. idea of joyous activity). </sense><sense id="n1674.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg> </sense><sense id="n1674.2" n="A" level="2"> Of men: ignotus juvenum coetus, alternā vice Inibat alacris, Bacchio insultans modo, Enn. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Charis.</author> p. 214</bibl> P.: <cit><quote lang="la">quid tu es tristis? quidve es alacris?</quote> <trans><tr>why are you so disturbed? or why so excited?</tr></trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,003:2:3:13" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Eun. 2, 3, 13</bibl></cit> ( = incitatus, commotus, Ruhnk.): <cit><quote lang="la">videbant Catilinam alacrem atque laetum,</quote> <trans><tr>active and joyous</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,014:24:49" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Mur. 24, 49</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">valentes imbecillum, alacres perterritum superare,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,024:chapter=28" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Cael. 28</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Aman laetus et alacer,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,019:5:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Esth. 5, 9</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">alacres animo sumus,</quote> <trans><tr>are eager in mind</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:5:12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 5, 12 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></cit> Manut.; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:6:685 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 6, 685 al.</bibl>—With <hi rend="ital">ad</hi>: alacriores ad reliquum perficiendum, Auct. ad <bibl default="NO"><author>Her.</author> 2, 31</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">ad maleficia,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 2, 30</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ad bella suscipienda alacer et promptus animus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:3:19" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 3, 19</bibl></cit>; <cb n="ALAT" /> so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:C. 21:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> C. 21, 5</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">ad rem gerendam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,004:2:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Paus. 2, 6</bibl></cit>.—With <hi rend="ital">super</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">alacri corde super omnibus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,013:8:66" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> 3 Reg. 8, 66</bibl></cit>.—In Sall. once for <hi rend="ital">nimble</hi>, <hi rend="ital">active</hi>: cum alacribus saltu, cum velocibus cursu certabat, Fragm. 62, p. 248 Gerl.—</sense><sense id="n1674.3" n="B" level="2"> Of animals: <cit><quote lang="la">equus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,053:33:73" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Div. 33, 73</bibl></cit>: bestiae, Auct. ad <bibl default="NO"><author>Her.</author> 2, 19</bibl>. —</sense><sense id="n1674.4" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Transf.</usg>, <usg type="style">poet.</usg>, of concrete and abstract things: <cit><quote lang="la">alacris voluptas,</quote> <trans><tr>a lively pleasure</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,001:5:58" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> E. 5, 58</bibl></cit>; so, alacres enses, <hi rend="ital">quick</hi>, <hi rend="ital">ready</hi> to cut, <bibl default="NO"><author>Claud.</author> Eutr. 2, 280</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">involant (in pugnam) impetu alacri,</quote> <trans><tr>with a spirited</tr>, <tr>vigorous onset</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,001:1:1:90" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Am. 1, 1, 90</bibl></cit>. —<hi rend="ital">Sup.</hi> not used; cf. <bibl default="NO"><author>Charis.</author> 88</bibl> P.; Rudd. I. p. 177, n. 48.—<hi rend="ital">Adv.</hi>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">ălăcrĭter</orth>, <hi rend="ital">briskly</hi>, <hi rend="ital">eagerly</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Amm.</author> 14, 2</bibl>.—<hi rend="ital">Comp.</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:1:6:10" default="NO"><author>Just.</author> 1, 6, 10</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
alacritas: <entryFree id="n1675" type="main" key="a^la^cri^tas"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ălăcrĭtas</orth>, <itype>ātis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>alacer</etym>, <sense id="n1675.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the condition</hi> or <hi rend="ital">quality of</hi> alacer, <hi rend="ital">liveliness</hi>, <hi rend="ital">ardor</hi>, <hi rend="ital">briskness</hi>, <hi rend="ital">alacrity</hi>, <hi rend="ital">eagerness</hi>, <hi rend="ital">promptness</hi>, <hi rend="ital">joy</hi>, <hi rend="ital">gladness</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">alacritas rei publicae defendendae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,035:4:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Phil. 4, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">mirā sum alacritate ad litigandum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:2:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 2, 7</bibl></cit>; so <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 16, 3</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">alacritas studiumque pugnandi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:1:46" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 1, 46</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">animi incitatio atque alacritas,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,002:3:92" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> B. C. 3, 92</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">alacritas animae suae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,034:45:29" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Eccli. 45, 29</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">finem orationis ingens alacritas consecuta est,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,001:35" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> Agr. 35</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">(naves) citae remis augebantur alacritate militum in speciem ac terrorem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:2:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> A. 2, 6</bibl></cit>.—Of animals: <cit><quote lang="la">canum in venando,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:2:63" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> N. D. 2, 63</bibl></cit>. —Of a joyous state of mind as made known by external demeanor, <hi rend="ital">transport</hi>, <hi rend="ital">rapture</hi>, <hi rend="ital">ecstasy</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">inanis alacritas, id est laetitia gestiens,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:4:16:36" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 4, 16, 36</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">vir temperatus, constans, sine metu, sine aegritudine, sine alacritate ullā, sine libidine,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 5, 16, 48</bibl></cit>. —With <hi rend="ital">obj. gen.</hi>, <hi rend="ital">joy on account of something</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">clamor Romanorum alacritate perfecti operis sublatus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:2:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 2, 10 <hi rend="ital">med.</hi></bibl></cit>—* In <number>plur.</number>: <cit><quote lang="la">vigores quidam mentium et alacritates,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:19:12:4" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 19, 12, 4</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
alacriter: <entryFree id="n1676" type="main" key="a^la^cri^ter"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ălăcrĭter</orth>, <pos>adv.</pos>, v. alacer <sense id="n1676.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></sense></entryFree>
alamanni: <entryFree id="n1677" type="main" key="A^la^manni"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ălămanni</orth>, v. Alemanni.</entryFree>
alanus: <entryFree id="n1678" type="main" key="A^la_nus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ălānus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos>, <sense id="n1678.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">of</hi> or <hi rend="ital">pertaining to the Alani</hi>, = <foreign lang="greek">*)alanoi/</foreign>, <hi rend="ital">a very warlike Scythian nation upon the Tanais and Palus Mœotis</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">gens Alana,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Claud.</author> B. Get. 583</bibl></cit>.—<hi rend="ital">Subst.</hi>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">Ălānus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <hi rend="ital">one of the Alani</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0917,001:10:454" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Luc.</author> 10, 454</bibl>.—<hi rend="ital">Com. plur.</hi>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">Ălāni</orth>, <itype>ōrum</itype>, <hi rend="ital">the Alani</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:4:80" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 4, 12, 25, § 80</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Thyest. 629" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Thyest. 629</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0917,001:8:223" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Luc.</author> 8, 223</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1035,001:642" default="NO"><author>Val. Fl.</author> 642</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
alapa: <entryFree id="n1679" type="main" key="a^la^pa"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ălăpa</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>akin to -cello, to smite, as if calapa; cf. <foreign lang="greek">ko/lafos</foreign></etym>, <sense id="n1679.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a stroke</hi> or <hi rend="ital">blow upon the cheek with the open hand</hi>, <hi rend="ital">a box on the ear</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">ducere gravem alapam alicui,</quote> <trans><tr>to give</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0975,001:5:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Phaedr.</author> 5, 3</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ministri eum alipis caedebant,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,002:14:65" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Marc. 14, 65</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,004:18:22" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> Joan. 18, 22</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">19, 3</bibl>; esp. among actors, for the purpose of exciting a laugh among their auditors, * <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1276,001:8:192" default="NO"><author>Juv.</author> 8, 192</bibl>; * <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1294,001:5:61:11" default="NO"><author>Mart.</author> 5, 61, 11</bibl>.—When a slave was emancipated, his master gave him an alapa; hence, <usg type="style">poet.</usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">multo majoris alapae mecum veneunt,</quote> <trans>i. e. <tr>with me freedom is much more dearly purchased</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0975,001:2:5:25" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Phaedr.</author> 2, 5, 25</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
alapus: <entryFree id="n1680" type="gloss" key="a^la^pus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ălăpus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <etym>alapa</etym>, <sense id="n1680.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a parasite</hi>, <hi rend="ital">who submitted to the box on the ear for gold</hi>, Gloss. Isid.; cf. Barth. Advers. 19, 22.</sense></entryFree>
alaricus: <entryFree id="n1681" type="main" key="A^la^ri_cus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ălărīcus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <sense id="n1681.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">Alaric</hi>, <hi rend="ital">a king of the Goths</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Claud.</author> B. Get. 431</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
alarius: <entryFree id="n1682" type="main" key="a_la_ri^us"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ālārĭus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype> (less freq. <orth extent="full" lang="la">ālāris</orth>, e), <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>ala</etym>.—In milit. lang., <sense id="n1682.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">that is upon the wing</hi> (of an army), <hi rend="ital">of the wing</hi> (opp. <hi rend="ital">legionarii</hi>, v. ala, II. E.): <cit><quote lang="la">cohortes alariae et legionariae,</quote> <trans>i. e. <tr>of the allies</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,002:1:73" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. C. 1, 73</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">cum cohortibus alariis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:10:40" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 10, 40</bibl></cit> Weissenb.: <cit><quote lang="la">alarii equites,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:40:40" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 40, 40</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:3:39" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 3, 39</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">4, 73</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">12, 27 al.</bibl>—<pos>Subst.</pos>, the form <orth extent="full" lang="la">ālārĭus</orth>, * <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:2:17" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 2, 17</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">ut ad speciem alariis uteretur,</quote> <trans><tr>auxiliaries</tr>, <tr>allies</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:1:51" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 1, 51</bibl></cit>.—The form <orth extent="full" lang="la">ālāris</orth>, e: <cit><quote lang="la">inter legionarios aut alares,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,004:2:94" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> H. 2, 94</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">alares Pannonii,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:15:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> A. 15, 10</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">alares exterruit,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 15, 11</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
alasi: <entryFree id="n1683" type="main" key="Alasi"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Alasi</orth>, <itype>orum</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <sense id="n1683.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a tribe of Libya</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:5:37" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 5, 5, 5, § 37</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
alastor: <entryFree id="n1684" type="greek" key="A^lastor"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ălastor</orth>, <itype>ŏris</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)la/stwr</foreign> (a tormentor). <sense id="n1684.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">One of the companions of Sarpedon</hi>, <hi rend="ital">king of Lycia</hi>, <hi rend="ital">killed by Ulysses before Troy</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:13:257" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 13, 257</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n1684.1" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Name of one of the four horses in the chariot of Pluto</hi>, Cland. R. Pros. 1, 284.</sense></entryFree>
alaternus: <entryFree id="n1685" type="main" key="a^la^ternus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ălăternus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>perh. akin to Germ. Erle; Engl. alder</etym>, <sense id="n1685.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a shrub</hi>: Rhamnus Alaternus, Linn.; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:7:6" default="NO"><author>Col.</author> 7, 6</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:16:108" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 16, 26, 45, § 108</bibl>. <pb n="80" /> <cb n="ALBA" /></sense></entryFree>
alatus: <entryFree id="n1686" type="main" key="a_la_tus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ālātus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>ala</etym>, <sense id="n1686.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">furnished with wings</hi>, <hi rend="ital">winged</hi> (only <usg type="style">poet.</usg>).—Of Mercury: plantae, * <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:4:259" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 4, 259</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">pes,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,007:5:666" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> F. 5, 666</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Phoebus alatis aethera carpit equis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,010:3:416" default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 3, 416</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
alauda: <entryFree id="n1687" type="main" key="a^lauda"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ălauda</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>Celtic; lit. great songstress, from al, high, great, and aud, song; cf. the Fr. alouette; Breton. al' choueder; v. Diefenbach in Zeitschriften für vergl. Sprachf. IV. p. 391</etym>. <sense id="n1687.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">The lark</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:11:121" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 11, 37, 44, § 121</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n1687.1" n="II" level="1"> <orth extent="full" lang="la">Ălauda</orth>, <hi rend="ital">the name of a legion raised by Cœsar</hi>, <hi rend="ital">in Gaul</hi>, <hi rend="ital">at his own expense</hi> (prob. so called from the decoration of their helmet): <cit><quote lang="la">unam (legionem) ex Transalpinis conscriptam, vocabulo quoque Gallico (Alauda enim appellabatur) civitate donavit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=jul.:24" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Caes. 24</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">cum legione Alaudarum ad urbem pergit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:16:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 16, 8</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Huc accedunt Alaudae ceterique veterani,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,035:13:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Phil. 13, 2</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
alausa: <entryFree id="n1688" type="hapax" key="a^lausa"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ălausa</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>Fr. alose</etym>, <sense id="n1688.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a small fish in the Moselle</hi>, <hi rend="ital">the shad</hi>: Culpea alosa, Linn.; <bibl default="NO"><author>Aus.</author> Mos. 127</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
alazon: <entryFree id="n1689" type="greek" key="a^la_zo_n1" n="1"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ălāzōn</orth>, <itype>ŏnis</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)lazw/n</foreign> (boasting), <sense id="n1689.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a braggart</hi>, <hi rend="ital">boaster</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,012:2:1:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Mil. 2, 1, 8</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>

<entryFree id="n1690" type="main" key="A^la_zon2" n="2"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ălāzon</orth>, <itype>ŏnos</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <sense id="n1690.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a river in Albania</hi>, now <hi rend="ital">Alasan</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:6:29" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 6, 10, 11, § 29</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1035,001:6:102" default="NO"><author>Val. Fl.</author> 6, 102</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
alba: <entryFree id="n1691" type="hapax" key="alba1" n="1"><orth extent="full" lang="la">alba</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>albus</etym>, <sense id="n1691.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a white precious stone</hi>, <hi rend="ital">the pearl</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Lampr.</author> Hel. 21</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>

<entryFree id="n1692" type="main" key="Alba2" n="2"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Alba</orth> or <orth extent="full" lang="la">Alba Longa</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>v. albus</etym>. <sense id="n1692.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">The mother city of Rome</hi>, <hi rend="ital">built by Ascanius</hi>, <hi rend="ital">the son of Æneas</hi>, <hi rend="ital">upon the broad</hi>, <hi rend="ital">rocky margin which lies between the Alban Lake and Mons Albanus;</hi> destroyed by Tullus Hostilius, the third king of Rome, and never rebuilt, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0043,001:1:34:88" default="NO"><author>Enn.</author> Ann. 1, 34, 88</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:1:277" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 1, 277</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">8, 48</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:1:27" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 1, 27</bibl>-30; cf. Nieb. Rom. Hist. 1, 220 sq.; Müll. Roms Camp. 2, 97 sq.—</sense><sense id="n1692.1" n="II" level="1"> The name of several other towns. </sense><sense id="n1692.2" n="A" level="2"> <orth extent="full" lang="la">Alba Fucentĭa</orth>, or <hi rend="ital">absol.</hi> <orth extent="full" lang="la">Alba</orth>, <hi rend="ital">a town north-west of Lacus Fucinus</hi>, <hi rend="ital">on the borders of the Marsi</hi>, now <hi rend="ital">Colle di Albe</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,002:1:15" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. C. 1, 15</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:9:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 9, 6</bibl>; Pomp. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:chapter=8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 8</bibl> post. ep. 12; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:3:106" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 3, 12, 17, § 106</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n1692.3" n="B" level="2"> <orth extent="full" lang="la">Alba Pompēĭa</orth>, <hi rend="ital">in Liguria</hi>, <hi rend="ital">on the river Tanarus</hi>, now <hi rend="ital">Alba</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:3:49" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 3, 5, 7, § 49</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n1692.4" n="C" level="2"> <orth extent="full" lang="la">Alba Helvĭa</orth> or <orth extent="full" lang="la">Alba Helvōrum</orth>, <hi rend="ital">in Gallia Narbonensis</hi>, now <hi rend="ital">Viviers</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:3:36" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 3, 4, 5, § 36</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>

<entryFree id="n1693" type="main" key="Alba3" n="3"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Alba</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <sense id="n1693.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the name of a king in</hi> Alba Longa, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:14:612" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 14, 612</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,007:4:43" default="NO"><author>id.</author> F. 4, 43</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>

<entryFree id="n1695" type="main" key="Alba4" n="5"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Alba</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <sense id="n1695.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a river in Hispania Tarraconensis</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:3:22" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 3, 2, 3, § 22</bibl>; v. Albis.</sense></entryFree>
albaaemilus: <entryFree id="n1694" type="main" key="Alba Aemilus" n="4"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Alba Aemilus</orth>, <gen>m.</gen>, <sense id="n1694.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a confidant of C. Verres</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:3:62:145" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Verr. 3, 62, 145</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
albamentum: <entryFree id="n1696" type="main" key="alba_mentum"><orth extent="full" lang="la">albāmentum</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>n.</gen> <etym>albus</etym>, <sense id="n1696.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the white</hi> of the egg = albor: <cit><quote lang="la">ovi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2003,001:5:3" default="NO"><author>Apic.</author> 5, 3</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2003,001:6:9" default="NO"><author>id.</author> 6, 9</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
albana: <entryFree id="n1697" type="main" key="Alba_na"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Albāna</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> (sc. via), <sense id="n1697.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a road leading to Capua</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,011:2:34:94" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Agr. 2, 34, 94</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1038,001:9:1" default="NO"><author>Val. Max.</author> 9, 1</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
albania: <entryFree id="n1698" type="main" key="Alba_ni^a"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Albānĭa</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, <sense id="n1698.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a province on the coast of the Caspian Sea</hi>, now <hi rend="ital">Daghestan and Lesghistan</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:6:36" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 6, 13, 15, § 36</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:9:4" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 9, 4</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Sol.</author> 25</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
albanus: <entryFree id="n1699" type="main" key="Alba_nus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Albānus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>Alba</etym>. <sense id="n1699.0" n="I. A." level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Pertaining to the town of Alba</hi>, <hi rend="ital">Alban</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">exercitus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:1:28" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 1, 28</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">pax,</quote> <trans><tr>the peace between the Romans and Albans</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:1:27" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 1, 27</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n1699.1" n="B" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">Pertaining to Albania</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">mare Albanum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:6:38" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 6, 13, 15, § 38</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ora,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1035,001:5:460" default="NO"><author>Val. Fl.</author> 5, 460</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n1699.2" n="II" level="1"> Hence, <orth extent="full" lang="la">Albāni</orth>, <itype>ōrum</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> </sense><sense id="n1699.3" n="A" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">The Albans</hi>, <hi rend="ital">the inhabitants of Alba Longa</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:1:29" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 1, 29</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n1699.4" n="B" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">The Albanians</hi>, <hi rend="ital">the inhabitants of Albania</hi>, <hi rend="ital">on the Caspian Sea</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:6:38" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 6, 13, 15, § 38</bibl>.— Esp., <orth extent="full" lang="la">Lăcus Albānus</orth>, <hi rend="ital">a deep lake in Latium</hi>, south of Rome, and on the west side of old Alba, now <hi rend="ital">Lago di Albano</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:5:15" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 5, 15</bibl>.—<orth extent="full" lang="la">Mons Albānus</orth>, <hi rend="ital">a rocky mountain in Latium</hi>, now <hi rend="ital">Monte Cavo</hi>, <hi rend="ital">lying eastward from the Alban Lake</hi>, 2500 feet above the surface of the Tyrrhene Sea, on whose western declivity, extending to the lake, was the old Alba Longa. Upon its summit, which afforded a noble view, stood the splendid temple of Juppiter Latiaris, up to which wound a paved way, still in part existing, for the festive processions in the holidays of the Latins (feriae Latinae), as well as for the ovations of the Roman generals, cf. Müll. Roms Camp. 2, 139-146.— <orth extent="full" lang="la">Lăpis Albānus</orth>, <hi rend="ital">the kind of stone hewn from Mount Alba</hi>, called in Ital. <hi rend="ital">peperino</hi> or <hi rend="ital">piperno</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1056,001:2:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vitr.</author> 2, 7</bibl>; <cit><quote lang="la">hence. Albanae columnae,</quote> <trans><tr>made of such stone</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,029:2:45" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Scaur. 2, 45</bibl></cit>.—<orth extent="full" lang="la">Albānum</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>n.</gen>, <hi rend="ital">an estate at Alba</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:7:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 7, 5</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:5:13:40" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 5, 13, 40</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=aug.:72" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Aug. 72</bibl>. <cb n="ALBI" /></sense></entryFree>
albaris: <entryFree id="n1700" type="main" key="alba_ris"><orth extent="full" lang="la">albāris</orth>, <itype>e</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos>, <sense id="n1700.0" n="I" level="1"><xr><lbl>v.</lbl> <ref type="sym" targOrder="U">the foll.</ref></xr></sense></entryFree>
albarius: <entryFree id="n1701" type="main" key="alba_ri^us"><orth extent="full" lang="la">albārĭus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>albo</etym>, only in archit., <sense id="n1701.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">pertaining to the whitening of walls.</hi> —Hence, <orth extent="full" lang="la">albārĭum ŏpus</orth>, or <hi rend="ital">absol.</hi> <orth extent="full" lang="la">al-bārĭum</orth>, <hi rend="ital">white stucco</hi>, a mortar composed of lime, gypsum, and a little fine river sand, with which walls were covered and made white, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1056,001:5:2:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vitr.</author> 5, 2, 10</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1056,001:7:2:3" default="NO" valid="yes">7, 2, 3</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:35:194" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 35, 16, 56, § 194</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:36:183" default="NO" valid="yes">36, 24, 59, § 183</bibl>; also, with the form <orth extent="full" lang="la">albāris</orth>, e: <cit><quote lang="la">OPVS ALBARE,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Inscr. Orell.</author> 4239</bibl></cit>.—<orth extent="full" lang="la">albārĭus tector</orth>, <hi rend="ital">a worker in stucco</hi>, <hi rend="ital">a plasterer</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Tert.</author> Idol. 8</bibl>; or <hi rend="ital">absol.</hi> <orth extent="full" lang="la">albārĭus</orth>, Cod. Th. 13, 4, 2, and <bibl default="NO"><author>Inscr. Orell.</author> 4142</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
albatus: <entryFree id="n1702" type="main" key="alba_tus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">albātus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>from albus, as atratus from ater</etym>, <sense id="n1702.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">clothed in white</hi>: cum ipse epuli dominus albatus esset, * <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,023:chapter=13" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Vatin. 13</bibl>; * <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,004:2:2:61" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> S. 2, 2, 61</bibl>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=dom.:12" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Dom. 12</bibl>.—In the Circensian games, one party, which was clothed in white, was called albati, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:8:160" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 8, 42, 65, § 160</bibl> Hard. (cf. russatus, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1276,001:7:114" default="NO"><author>Juv.</author> 7, 114</bibl>).</sense></entryFree>
albedo: <entryFree id="n1703" type="main" key="albe_do"><orth extent="full" lang="la">albēdo</orth>, <itype>ĭnis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>id.</etym>, <sense id="n1703.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">white color</hi>, <hi rend="ital">whiteness;</hi> only in eccl. Lat.; Sev. <bibl default="NO"><author>Sulp.</author> H. Sacr. 1, 16</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Cassiod.</author> Ep. 12, 4</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
albeo: <entryFree id="n1704" type="main" key="albe^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">albĕo</orth>, <itype>ēre</itype>, <pos>v. n.</pos> <etym>id.</etym>, <sense id="n1704.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to be white</hi> (rare and orig. <usg type="style">poet.</usg>, esp. often in Ovid; but also in post-Aug. prose): campi ossibus, * <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:12:36" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 12, 36</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">caput canis capillis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,002:13:161" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> H. 13, 161</bibl></cit>.—Esp. in the <hi rend="ital">part. pres.</hi>: albens, <hi rend="ital">white</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">albentes rosae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,004:3:182" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> A. A. 3, 182</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">spumae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:15:519" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> M. 15, 519</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">vitta,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,010:5:110" default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 5, 110</bibl></cit> al.; in prose: equi, * <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1318,002:22" default="NO"><author>Plin.</author> Pan. 22</bibl>; <cit><quote lang="la">in Tac. several times: ossa, A. 1, 61: spumae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:ib. 6:37" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> ib. 6, 37</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">in pallorem membra,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:ib. 15:64" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> ib. 15, 64</bibl></cit>.—The <usg type="style">poet.</usg> expression, albente caelo, <hi rend="ital">at daybreak</hi>, <hi rend="ital">at the dawn</hi>, was used (acc. to Caecilius in <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:8:3:35" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 8, 3, 35</bibl>) in prose first by the hist. Sisenna (about 30 years before Cæs.), and after him by Cæs. and the author of the Bell. Afric.; * <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,002:1:68" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. C. 1, 68</bibl>; Auct. Bell. Afric. 11; <bibl default="NO"><author>ib.</author> 80</bibl>; cf. albesco.</sense></entryFree>
