albesco: <entryFree id="n1705" type="main" key="albesco"><orth extent="full" lang="la">albesco</orth>, <itype>ĕre</itype>, <sense id="n1705.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">v. inch.</hi> [albeo], <hi rend="ital">to become white</hi> (mostly <usg type="style">poet.</usg> or in post-Aug. prose; once in Cic.), * <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:2:773" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 2, 773</bibl>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:7:528" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 7, 528</bibl>: albescens capillus, * <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:3:14:25" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 3, 14, 25</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">maturis messis aristis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,007:5:357" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> F. 5, 357</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">aquilarum pennae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:10:13" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 10, 3, 4, § 13</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">flammarum tractus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,002:1:367" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> G. 1, 367</bibl></cit>: mare, quia a sole collucet, albescit et vibrat, * <bibl default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Ac. 2, 33, 105</bibl>.—Hence, of the appearance of daylight, of daybreak (cf. albeo), <hi rend="ital">to dawn</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">lux,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:4:586" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 4, 586</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">albescente caelo,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Paul.</author> Dig. 28, 2, 25</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
albesia: <entryFree id="n1706" type="gloss" key="albe_sia"><orth extent="full" lang="la">albēsia</orth> (for albensia), <itype>ium</itype>, <gen>n.</gen>, <sense id="n1706.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a large shield used by the Albenses</hi>, <hi rend="ital">a people of the Marsian race</hi>, Paul. ex <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=4" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 4</bibl> Müll.</sense></entryFree>
albianus: <entryFree id="n1707" type="main" key="Albi^a_nus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Albĭānus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>Albius</etym>, <sense id="n1707.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">pertaining to Albius;</hi> only in Cic.: judicium, Caecin. 10: pecunia, Clu. 30.</sense></entryFree>
albicasco: <entryFree id="n1708" type="hapax" key="albi^casco"><orth extent="full" lang="la">albĭcasco</orth>, <itype>ĕre</itype>, <sense id="n1708.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">v. inch.</hi> [albico], <hi rend="ital">to become white</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to grow clear</hi>: albicascit Phoebus, Matius ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:15:25" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 15, 25</bibl> Hertz.</sense></entryFree>
albiceris: <entryFree id="n1709" type="main" key="albi^ce_ris"><orth extent="full" lang="la">albĭcēris</orth>, <itype>e</itype>, or <orth extent="full" lang="la">albĭcērus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, also <orth extent="full" lang="la">albĭcērātus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>albuscera</etym>, prop. <sense id="n1709.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">wax-white</hi>, i. e. <hi rend="ital">light yellow</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">olea albiceris,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Cato</author>, R. R. 6</bibl></cit>, and <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:R. R. 1:24" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> R. R. 1, 24</bibl>: olea albicera, Cat. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:15:20" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 15, 5, 6, § 20</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">albicerata ficus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:15:18" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 15, 18 <hi rend="ital">init.</hi></bibl></cit>; cf. Col 10, 417.</sense></entryFree>
albico: <entryFree id="n1710" type="main" key="albi^co"><orth extent="full" lang="la">albĭco</orth>, <itype>āre</itype>, <pos>v. a.</pos> and <gen>n.</gen> <etym>albus</etym>. * <sense id="n1710.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Act.</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to make white</hi>: rivus offensus a scopulo albicatur, <hi rend="ital">becomes white</hi>, <hi rend="ital">foamy</hi>, Poët. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> 75, 21</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n1710.1" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Neutr.</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to be white</hi> (rare; <usg type="style">poet.</usg> or in post - Aug. prose): prata canis pruinis, * <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:1:4:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 1, 4, 4</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">albicans litus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0472,001:63:87" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cat.</author> 63, 87</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ex nigro albicare incipit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:27:40" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 27, 5, 23, § 40</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">colos,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:25:89" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 25, 8, 50, § 89</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">alb cans cauda,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:10:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 10, 3, 3, § 6</bibl></cit>.—Hence, * <orth extent="full" lang="la">albĭcantius</orth>, <hi rend="ital">adv. comp.</hi>, <hi rend="ital">somewhat in the way of white</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">(hyacinthus lapis) albicantius in aquaticum eliquescit,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Sol.</author> 30</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
albicolor: <entryFree id="n1711" type="hapax" key="albi^co^lor"><orth extent="full" lang="la">albĭcŏlor</orth>, <itype>ōris</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>albus-color</etym>, <sense id="n1711.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">of a white color</hi>: campus, Coripp. 1, 429.</sense></entryFree>
albicomus: <entryFree id="n1712" type="hapax" key="albi^co^mus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">albĭcŏmus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>albus-coma</etym>, <sense id="n1712.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">white-haired;</hi> hence of flowers, <hi rend="ital">having white fibres</hi>, Ven. 4, 2.</sense></entryFree>
albidulus: <entryFree id="n1713" type="hapax" key="albi^du^lus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">albĭdŭlus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <sense id="n1713.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">adj. dim.</hi> [albidus], <hi rend="ital">whitish</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">color,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Pall.</author> 3, 25, 12</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
albidus: <entryFree id="n1714" type="main" key="albi^dus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">albĭdus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>albus</etym>, <sense id="n1714.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">white</hi> (very rare): spuma, * <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:3:74" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 3, 74</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">granum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:R. R. 2:9:13" default="NO"><author>Col.</author> R. R. 2, 9, 13</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ulcus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0836,001:5:26" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cels.</author> 5, 26</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">pus albidius,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0836,001:5:28" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 5, 28</bibl></cit>, n. 4: <cit><quote lang="la">pus albidissimum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0836,001:5:26" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 5, 26</bibl></cit>, n. 20: <cit><quote lang="la">color caeruleo albidior,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1318,001:8:20:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> Ep. 8, 20, 4</bibl></cit>.—<hi rend="ital">Adv.</hi> not used.</sense></entryFree>
albineus: <entryFree id="n1715" type="hapax" key="albi^ne^us"><orth extent="full" lang="la">albĭnĕus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>id.</etym>, <sense id="n1715.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">white</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">color (equorum),</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Pall.</author> 4</bibl></cit>. 13. <cb n="ALBU" /></sense></entryFree>
albinius: <entryFree id="n1716" type="main" key="Albi^ni^us"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Albĭnĭus</orth>, <itype>ii</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <sense id="n1716.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the name of a Roman</hi> gens: <cit><quote lang="la">C. Albinius,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,022:3:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Sest. 3, 6</bibl></cit>.—Hence, <orth extent="full" lang="la">Albĭnĭānus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos>, <hi rend="ital">of</hi> or <hi rend="ital">belonging to an Albinius.—Subst.</hi>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">Albĭnĭāni</orth>, <itype>ōrum</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <hi rend="ital">adherents of Albinius</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Spart.</author> Sev. 10</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Tert.</author> ad Scap. 2</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
albinovanus: <entryFree id="n1717" type="main" key="Albi^no^va_nus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Albĭnŏvānus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <sense id="n1717.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a Roman proper name.</hi> </sense><sense id="n1717.1" n="I" level="1"> C. Pedo Albinovanus, <hi rend="ital">a contemporary and friend of Ovid</hi> (v. Pont. 4, 10), <hi rend="ital">an epic poet</hi>, of whose greater epic, which had for its subject the deeds of Germanicus, we have only a fragment remaining, under the title: De navigatione Germanici per Oceanum Septentrionalem, in <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Suas. 1, p. 11" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Suas. 1, p. 11</bibl>.—See <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:10:1:90" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 10, 1, 90</bibl>; Crinit. Poët. Lat. c. 64; Bähr's <usg type="style">Lit.</usg> Gesch. 83; 217 and 218; Weich. Poët. Lat. 382.—</sense><sense id="n1717.2" n="II" level="1"> Celsus Albinovanus, <hi rend="ital">a contemporary of Horace</hi>, to whom the latter addresses one of his epistles (Ep. 1, 8, v. Schmid. Einl.).</sense></entryFree>
albinus: <entryFree id="n1718" type="hapax" key="albi_nus1" n="1"><orth extent="full" lang="la">albīnus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = albarius, <sense id="n1718.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">one who covers walls with stucco</hi> or <hi rend="ital">plaster</hi>, <hi rend="ital">a plasterer</hi>: albini, quos Graeci <foreign lang="greek">konia/tas</foreign> appellant, Cod. Const. 10, 64, 1.</sense></entryFree>

<entryFree id="n1719" type="main" key="Albi_nus2" n="2"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Albīnus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <sense id="n1719.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a Roman family name.</hi> </sense><sense id="n1719.1" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">The name of a Roman usurer</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,006:327" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> A. P. 327</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n1719.2" n="II" level="1"> A. Postumius Albinus, censor, A. U. C. 580, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:41:106" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Verr. 1, 41, 106</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:41:27" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 41, 27</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n1719.3" n="III" level="1"> Esp.: A. Postumius Albinus, <hi rend="ital">who was consul with Lucullus a short time before the third Punic war</hi>, 603 A. U. C., <hi rend="ital">and the author of a Roman Hist. in Greek</hi>, cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,039:21:81" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Brut. 21, 81</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Ac. 2, 45, 137</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:11:8" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 11, 8</bibl>; Macr. S. praef.</sense></entryFree>
albion: <entryFree id="n1720" type="main" key="Albi^on1" n="1"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Albĭon</orth>, <itype>ōnis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>v. albus</etym>, <sense id="n1720.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">an ancient name for Britain</hi>, in Ptol. <foreign lang="greek">*)aloui/wn</foreign>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:4:102" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 4, 16, 30, § 102</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>

<entryFree id="n1721" type="main" key="Albi^on2" n="2"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Albĭon</orth>, <itype>ōnis</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <sense id="n1721.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a son of Neptune</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0929,001:2:6:4" default="NO"><author>Mel.</author> 2, 6, 4</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
albiona: <entryFree id="n1722" type="main" key="Albi^ona"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Albĭona</orth> ager trans Tiberim dicitur a luco Albionarum: quo loco bos alba sacrificabatur, Paul. ex <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=4" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 4</bibl> Müll.</entryFree>
albis: <entryFree id="n1723" type="main" key="Albis"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Albis</orth>, <itype>is</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <etym>v. albus</etym>, <sense id="n1723.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a river of Germany</hi>, now <hi rend="ital">the Elbe</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,002:41" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> G. 41</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:4:44" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> A. 4, 44</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">Albin liquere Cherusci,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Claud.</author> IV. Cons. Hon. 452</bibl></cit>.—Also <orth extent="full" lang="la">Alba</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Vop.</author> Prob. 13</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
albitudo: <entryFree id="n1724" type="main" key="albi^tu_do"><orth extent="full" lang="la">albĭtūdo</orth>, <itype>ĭnis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>albus</etym>, <sense id="n1724.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">white color</hi>, <hi rend="ital">whiteness</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">capitis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,019:4:2:32" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Trin. 4, 2, 32</bibl></cit>, v. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> 73, 5</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">furfuris,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>App.</author> Herb. 20</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
albius: <entryFree id="n1725" type="main" key="Albi^us"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Albĭus</orth>, <itype>ii</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <etym>id.; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:L. L. 8:section=80" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> L. L. 8, § 80</bibl> Müll.</etym>, <sense id="n1725.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the name of a Roman</hi> gens. —<orth extent="full" lang="la">Albĭus Tibullus</orth>, <itype>the Roman elegiac poet</itype>, v. Tibullus.</sense></entryFree>
albo: <entryFree id="n1726" type="hapax" key="albo"><orth extent="full" lang="la">albo</orth>, āre. <pos>v. a.</pos> <etym>id.</etym>, <sense id="n1726.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to make white</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">hoc albat gurgite nigras (lanas),</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Prisc.</author> Perieg. 431</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
albogalerus: <entryFree id="n1727" type="gloss" key="albo^ga^le_rus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">albŏgălērus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <etym>albus-galerus</etym>, <sense id="n1727.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the white hat of the flamen Dialis</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=10" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 10</bibl>; cf. Varr. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:10:15" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 10, 15 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></sense></entryFree>
albogilvus: <entryFree id="n1728" type="hapax" key="albo^gilvus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">albŏgilvus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> [albus-gilvusl, <sense id="n1728.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">whitish yellow</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Serv.</author> ad Verg. G. 3, 82</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
albona: <entryFree id="n1729" type="main" key="Albo_na"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Albōna</orth> <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, <sense id="n1729.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a town in</hi> Liburnia.</sense></entryFree>
albor: <entryFree id="n1730" type="main" key="albor"><orth extent="full" lang="la">albor</orth>, <itype>ōris</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <etym>albus</etym>. <sense id="n1730.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Whiteness</hi>, <hi rend="ital">white color</hi> (eccl. Lat.): <cit><quote lang="la">si (caro) versa fuerit in alborem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,003:13:16" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Lev. 13, 16</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">13, 25</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">13, 29</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n1730.1" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">The white of an egg</hi>, = albamentum (post-class.): <cit><quote lang="la">ovorum,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Pall.</author> 11, 14, 9</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2003,001:1:6" default="NO"><author>Apic.</author> 1, 6</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">ovi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1011,001:Comp. 24" default="NO"><author>Scrib.</author> Comp. 24</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
albucus: <entryFree id="n1731" type="main" key="albu_cus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">albūcus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <sense id="n1731.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">The bulb of the asphodel</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:21:109" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 21, 17, 68, § 109</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n1731.1" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">The plant itself</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>App.</author> Herb. 32</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
albuelis: <entryFree id="n1732" type="main" key="albu^e_lis"><orth extent="full" lang="la">albŭēlis</orth>, <itype>is</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, <sense id="n1732.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a kind of vine</hi>, Cels. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:3:2:24" default="NO"><author>Col.</author> 3, 2, 24</bibl>, and <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:14:31" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 14, 2, 4, § 31</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
albugo: <entryFree id="n1733" type="main" key="albu_go"><orth extent="full" lang="la">albūgo</orth>, <itype>ĭnis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>albus</etym> (perh. only in Pliny). <sense id="n1733.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">A white spot</hi>, <hi rend="ital">a disease of the eye; film</hi>, <hi rend="ital">albugo</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:32:70" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 32, 7, 24, § 70</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">oculorum albugines,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:24:19" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 24, 5, 11, § 19</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">pupillarum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:29:117" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 29, 6, 38, § 117</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">habere in oculo,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,003:21:20" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Lev. 21, 20</bibl></cit>.—*</sense><sense id="n1733.1" n="II" level="1"> In the <number>plur.</number>, <hi rend="ital">scurf upon the head</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:26:160" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 26, 15, 90, § 160</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
albula: <entryFree id="n1734" type="main" key="Albu^la"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Albŭla</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>albulus</etym>, sc. aqua. <sense id="n1734.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">An earlier name for the river Tiber</hi>, <hi rend="ital">in Middle Italy</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">amisit verum vetus Albula nomen,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:8:332" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 8, 332</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,007:4:68" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> F. 4, 68</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n1734.1" n="II" level="1"> <orth extent="full" lang="la">Albŭla</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, or <orth extent="full" lang="la">Albŭlae</orth>, <itype>ārum</itype>, sc. aquae, <hi rend="ital">several sulphur-springs near Tibur</hi>, mentioned in Strabo and Pausanias, which were beneficial to invalids both for bathing and drinking. Only three now remain, which form three small lakes, called <hi rend="ital">Bagni di Tivoli</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Canaque sulfureis albula fumat aquis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1294,001:1:13" default="NO"><author>Mart.</author> 1, 13</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:31:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 31, 2, 6, § 10</bibl>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=aug.:82" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Aug. 82</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=nero:31" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Ner. 31</bibl>; cf. Müll. Roms Camp. 1, 161 sq.</sense></entryFree>
albulus: <entryFree id="n1735" type="main" key="albu^lus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">albŭlus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <sense id="n1735.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">adj. dim.</hi> [albus], <hi rend="ital">whitish</hi>:<pb n="81" /> <cb n="ALBU" />  columbus, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0472,001:29:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cat.</author> 29, 8</bibl>; <cit><quote lang="la">esp. of the white color of water: freta,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1294,001:12:99:4" default="NO"><author>Mart.</author> 12, 99, 4</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
album: <entryFree id="n1736" type="main" key="album"><orth extent="full" lang="la">album</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>n.</gen>, v. albus, III.</entryFree>
albumen: <entryFree id="n1737" type="hapax" key="albu_men"><orth extent="full" lang="la">albūmen</orth>, <itype>ĭnis</itype>, <gen>n.</gen> <etym>albus</etym>, <sense id="n1737.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the white of an egg</hi>, <hi rend="ital">albumen</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">ovi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:28:66" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 28, 6, 18, § 66</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
albumentum: <entryFree id="n1738" type="main" key="albu_mentum"><orth extent="full" lang="la">albūmentum</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>n.</gen> <etym>id.</etym>, <sense id="n1738.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the white of an egg</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">ovi,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Veg.</author> Vet. 2, 57</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
albunea: <entryFree id="n1739" type="main" key="Albu^ne^a"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Albŭnĕa</orth>, also <orth extent="full" lang="la">Albūna</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>v. albus</etym>, <sense id="n1739.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a fountain at Tibur gushing up between steep rocks</hi> (or <usg type="style">poet.</usg>, <hi rend="ital">the nymph who dwelt there</hi>), near to which was the villa of Horace: domus Albuneae resonantis, * <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:1:7:12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 1, 7, 12</bibl>; * <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:7:83" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 7, 83</bibl>; cf. Müll. Roms Camp. 1, 238 and 239.—</sense><sense id="n1739.1" n="2" level="3"> <hi rend="ital">A sibyl worshipped in a grove at Tibur</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Lact.</author> 1, 6, 12</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">Albuna,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0660,001:2:5:69" default="NO"><author>Tib.</author> 2, 5, 69</bibl></cit>, where now Müll. reads <hi rend="ital">Aniena.</hi></sense></entryFree>
alburnum: <entryFree id="n1740" type="hapax" key="alburnum"><orth extent="full" lang="la">alburnum</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>n.</gen> <etym>albus</etym>, <sense id="n1740.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the soft</hi>, <hi rend="ital">thin</hi>, <hi rend="ital">white layer between the bark and wood of trees</hi>, <hi rend="ital">sap-wood</hi>, <hi rend="ital">alburnum</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:16:182" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 16, 38, 72, § 182</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
alburnus: <entryFree id="n1741" type="hapax" key="alburnus1" n="1"><orth extent="full" lang="la">alburnus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <etym>id.</etym>, <sense id="n1741.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a white fish</hi>, prob. <hi rend="ital">the bleak</hi> or <hi rend="ital">blay</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Aus.</author> Mos. 126</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>

<entryFree id="n1742" type="main" key="Alburnus2" n="2"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Alburnus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <sense id="n1742.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a mountain in Lucania</hi>, <hi rend="ital">not far from the river Silarus</hi>, now <hi rend="ital">Monte di Postiglione</hi>, * <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,002:3:146" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> G. 3, 146</bibl>.— Also <hi rend="ital">worshipped as a deity</hi>, Tert. contr. Marc. 1, 18.</sense></entryFree>
albus: <entryFree id="n1743" type="main" key="albus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">albus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>cf. Umbr. alfu and Sab. alpus = white; <foreign lang="greek">a)lfo/s</foreign> = white rash; O. H. Germ. Elbiz = a swan; to this have been referred also Alba Longa, Albunea, Alpes from their snowy summits (Paul. ex <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=4" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 4</bibl> Müll.), Albion from its chalky cliffs, <foreign lang="greek">*)alfeio/s</foreign>, and Albis = Elbe</etym>, <sense id="n1743.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">white</hi> (properly <hi rend="ital">dead white</hi>, not shining; e. g. hair, complexion, garments, etc., opp. <hi rend="ital">ater</hi>, black that is without lustre; while <hi rend="ital">candidus</hi> denotes a glistening, dazzling white, opp. <hi rend="ital">niger</hi>, shining black.—Hence, trop., albus and ater, a symbol of good or ill fortune; on the other hand, candidus and niger of moral worth or unworthiness; cf. Doed. Syn. III. 193 sq.—So <bibl default="NO"><author>Serv.</author> ad Verg. G. 3, 82</bibl>: aliud est candidum, i. e. quādam nitenti luce perfusum esse; aliud album, quod pallori constat esse vicinum; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,001:7:38" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> E. 7, 38</bibl>: Candidior cycnis, hederā formosior albā, with <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 3, 39</bibl>: diffusos hederā vestit pallente corymbos; but this distinction is freq. disregarded by the poets). </sense><sense id="n1743.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg> </sense><sense id="n1743.2" n="A" level="2"> In gen.: <cit><quote lang="la">barba,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,004:5:1:15" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Bacch. 5, 1, 15</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">corpus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,005:3:4:115" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Capt. 3, 4, 115</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">color albus praecipue decorus deo est, maxime in textili,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,044:2:18:45" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Leg. 2, 18, 45</bibl></cit>: albus calculus, <hi rend="ital">the small white stone used in voting</hi>, as a sign of acceding to the opinion of any one, or of the acquittal of one who is under accusation (opp. ater calculus; <cit><quote lang="la">v. calculus).— Hence, trop.: alicui rei album calculum adicere,</quote> <trans><tr>to allow</tr>, <tr>approve of</tr>, <tr>authorize</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1318,001:1:2:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> Ep. 1, 2, 5</bibl></cit>.—In Enn. an epithet of the sun and moon: sol, Enn. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,053:1:48:107" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Div. 1, 48, 107</bibl> (Ann. v. 92 Vahl.): jubar Hyperionis, Enn. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Prisc.</author> p. 658</bibl> P. (Ann. v. 547 ib.).—The following are examples of the opposition of albus and niger (instead of ater) as exceptions to the gen. rule; so always in Lucr. (who also uses albus and candidus or candens promiscuously), 2, 810; 822 sqq.; 731 sq.; 790; 767-771. Once in Cic.: quae alba sint, quae nigra dicere, Div. 2, 3; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0975,001:3:15:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Phaedr.</author> 3, 15, 10</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:2:541" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 2, 541</bibl>; cf. with <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,010:2:534" default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 2, 534</bibl> and 535; also <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,010:12:403" default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 12, 403</bibl>; 15, 46; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,002:15:37 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> H. 15, 37 al.</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">albi et nigri velleris,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,001:30:35" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Gen. 30, 35</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">non potes unum capillum album facere aut nigrum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,001:5:36" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> Matt. 5, 36</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n1743.3" n="B" level="2"> Esp. </sense><sense id="n1743.4" n="1" level="3"> <hi rend="ital">Pale</hi>, from sickness, terror, care, and the like: <cit><quote lang="la">aquosus albo Corpore languor, of dropsical persons,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:2:2:15" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 2, 2, 15</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">pallor,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,003:7:15" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Epod. 7, 15</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">vivat et urbanis albus in officiis,</quote> <trans><tr>pale from the cares of his public office</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1294,001:1:56" default="NO"><author>Mart.</author> 1, 56 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></cit> et saep. —</sense><sense id="n1743.5" n="2" level="3"> Of clothing, <hi rend="ital">white</hi>: alba decent Cererem; <cit><quote lang="la">vestes Cerealibus albas Sumite,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,007:4:619" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> F. 4, 619</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">vidit duos Angelos in albis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,004:20:12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Joan. 20, 12</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,027:3:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> Apoc. 3, 4</bibl>.—Hence, <usg type="style">poet.</usg> transf. to the person, <hi rend="ital">clothed in white</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,004:1:2:36" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> S. 1, 2, 36</bibl>: pedibus qui venerat albis, <hi rend="ital">who had come with white feet</hi>, i. e. marked with chalk, as for sale, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1276,001:1:111" default="NO"><author>Juv.</author> 1, 111</bibl> (cf. gypsatus and also <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:35:17:58" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 35, 17, 58</bibl>, §§ 199-201; Mayor ad 1. 1.).—</sense><sense id="n1743.6" n="3" level="3"> Prov. phrases. </sense><sense id="n1743.7" n="a" level="4"> Dentibus albis deridere, <hi rend="ital">to deride one by laughing so as to show the teeth</hi>, for <hi rend="ital">to deride much</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,009:3:3:48" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Ep. 3, 3, 48</bibl> (cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,005:3:1:26" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Capt. 3, 1, 26</bibl>).—</sense><sense id="n1743.8" n="b" level="4"> Albus an ater sit, nescio or non curo, <hi rend="ital">I know not</hi>, <hi rend="ital">care not whether he is white or black</hi>, i. e. <hi rend="ital">he is entirely indifferent<cb n="ALCA" />  to me</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">vide, quam te amārit is, qui albus aterve fueris ignorans, fratris filium praeteriit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,035:2:16" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Phil. 2, 16</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">unde illa scivit, ater an albus nascerer,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0975,001:3:15:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Phaedr.</author> 3, 15, 10</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0472,001:93:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cat.</author> 93, 2</bibl>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:11:1:38" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 11, 1, 38</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n1743.9" n="c" level="4"> Albo rete aliquid oppugnare, <hi rend="ital">to attack</hi> or <hi rend="ital">seize upon something with a white net</hi>, i. e. <hi rend="ital">in a delicate</hi>, <hi rend="ital">skilful manner</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">qui hic albo rete aliena oppugnant bona,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,014:1:2:22" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Pers. 1, 2, 22</bibl></cit> (so the passage seems to be more simply explained than acc. to the opinion of Gron.: qui albo (by the register of the prætor) <hi rend="ital">tamquam</hi> rete, which omission of the tamquam is a Horatian, but not a Plautinian idiom). —</sense><sense id="n1743.10" n="d" level="4"> Albā lineā aliquid signare, <hi rend="ital">to make a white line upon a white ground</hi>, i. e. <hi rend="ital">to make no distinction</hi>: et amabat omnes, nam ut discrimen non facit ... signat linea alba, Lucil. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> 282, 28</bibl> (where the common editions have neque before signare, which gives the expression a directly opposite sense): albā, ut dicitur, lineā sine curā discriminis convertebant, Gell. praef. 11.— * </sense><sense id="n1743.11" n="e" level="4"> Alba avis, <hi rend="ital">a white sparrow</hi>, for <hi rend="ital">something rare</hi>, <hi rend="ital">uncommon</hi>, <hi rend="ital">strange</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">quasi avem albam videntur bene sentientem civem videre,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:7:28" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 7, 28</bibl></cit> (quasi novum quiddam; proverbium ex eo natum, quia rarae aves albae, Manut. ad h. 1.).—* </sense><sense id="n1743.12" n="f" level="4"> Filius albae gallinae, <hi rend="ital">fortune's favorite child</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1276,001:13:141" default="NO"><author>Juv.</author> 13, 141</bibl>, prob. an allusion to the miracle that happened to Livia in regard to a white hen, v. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:15:30:40" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 15, 30, 40</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=gal.:1" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Galb. 1</bibl> (Ruperti ad h. 1, refers this expression to the unfruitfulness of a white hen, and conpares <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:R. R. 8:2:7" default="NO"><author>Col.</author> R. R. 8, 2, 7</bibl>).—* </sense><sense id="n1743.13" n="g" level="4"> Equis albis praecurrere aliquem, <hi rend="ital">to excel</hi>, <hi rend="ital">surpass one</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,004:1:7:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> S. 1, 7, 8</bibl> (the figure being drawn from the white horses attached to a triumphal chariot; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=nero:25" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Ner. 25</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=dom.:2" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Dom. 2</bibl>).—</sense><sense id="n1743.14" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Trop.</usg> </sense><sense id="n1743.15" n="A" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">Favorable</hi>, <hi rend="ital">fortunate</hi>, <hi rend="ital">propitious</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">simul alba nautis Stella refulsit,</quote> <trans>i. e. <tr>the twin-star Castor</tr>, <tr>favorable to sailors</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:1:12:27" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 1, 12, 27</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">dies,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1345,001:15:53" default="NO"><author>Sil.</author> 15, 53</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">sint omnia protinus alba,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0969,001:1:110" default="NO"><author>Pers.</author> 1, 110</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n1743.16" n="B" level="2"> <usg type="style">Poet.</usg> and <hi rend="ital">act.</hi>, of the wind, <hi rend="ital">making clear</hi> or <hi rend="ital">bright</hi>, <hi rend="ital">dispersing the clouds;</hi> hence, <hi rend="ital">dry</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Notus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:1:7:15" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 1, 7, 15</bibl></cit> (as a transl. of the Gr. <foreign lang="greek">leuko/notos</foreign>): <cit><quote lang="la">iapyx,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 3, 27, 19</bibl></cit> (cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">clarus aquilo,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,002:1:460" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> G. 1, 460</bibl></cit>).—Whence, </sense><sense id="n1743.17" n="III" level="1"> <orth extent="full" lang="la">album</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>n.</gen>, <hi rend="ital">whiteness.</hi> </sense><sense id="n1743.18" n="A" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">White color</hi>, <hi rend="ital">white</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">maculis insignis et albo,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,002:3:56" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> G. 3, 56</bibl></cit>; <cit><quote lang="la">sparsis pellibus albo,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,001:2:41" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> E. 2, 41</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">columnas polire albo,</quote> <trans><tr>to make white</tr>, <tr>whiten</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:40:51" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 40, 51</bibl></cit>.—Hence, </sense><sense id="n1743.19" n="2" level="3"> Esp., </sense><sense id="n1743.20" n="a" level="4"> <hi rend="ital">The white of the eye</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">oculorum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0836,001:2:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cels.</author> 2, 6</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0836,001:7:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 7, 7</bibl>, n. 6 and 12.—</sense><sense id="n1743.21" n="b" level="4"> <hi rend="ital">The white of an egg</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">ovi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0836,001:6:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cels.</author> 6, 6</bibl></cit>, n. 7.—</sense><sense id="n1743.22" n="c" level="4"> In <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:6:17:7" default="NO"><author>Col.</author> 6, 17, 7</bibl>, <hi rend="ital">a white spot on the eye</hi>, i. e. a disease of it, = albugo.—</sense><sense id="n1743.23" n="B" level="2"> In the lang. of polit. life, <hi rend="ital">a white tablet</hi>, <hi rend="ital">on which any thing is inscribed</hi> (like <foreign lang="greek">leu/kwma</foreign> in Gr.). </sense><sense id="n1743.24" n="1" level="3"> <hi rend="ital">The tablets on which the</hi> Pontifex Maximus <hi rend="ital">registered the principal events of the year</hi>, <hi rend="ital">the</hi> Annales maximi (v. annales): in album referre, <hi rend="ital">to enter</hi> or <hi rend="ital">record in</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:2:12:52" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> de Or. 2, 12, 52</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:1:32:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 1, 32, 2</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n1743.25" n="2" level="3"> <hi rend="ital">The tablets of the prœtor</hi>, <hi rend="ital">on which his edicts were written</hi>, and which were posted up in some public place, Paul. Sent. l. 1, t. 14.—Hence, sedere ad album, <hi rend="ital">to be employed with the edicts of the prœtor</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Ep. 48" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Ep. 48</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">se ad album transferre,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:12:3:11" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 12, 3, 11</bibl></cit> Spald.—</sense><sense id="n1743.26" n="3" level="3"> Esp., <hi rend="ital">a list of names</hi>, <hi rend="ital">a register</hi>, e. g. Album senatorium, <hi rend="ital">the tablet on which the names of the senators were enrolled</hi>, <hi rend="ital">the roll</hi>, <hi rend="ital">register</hi>, which, by the order of Augustus, was to be posted up annually in the senate-house, <bibl default="NO"><author>Diom.</author> 55, 3</bibl>, and Fragm. 137: <cit><quote lang="la">aliquem albo senatorio eradere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:4:42" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 4, 42 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></cit>—Also, <hi rend="ital">the list of the judges chosen by the quœstors</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">aliquem albo judicum eradere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=cl.:16" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Claud. 16</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=dom.:8" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Dom. 8</bibl>.—And transf. to other catalogues of names: <cit><quote lang="la">citharoedorum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=nero:21" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Ner. 21</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
alcaeus: <entryFree id="n1744" type="main" key="Alcaeus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Alcaeus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*)alkai=os</foreign>, <sense id="n1744.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a renowned lyric poet of Mitylene</hi>, <hi rend="ital">contemporary with Sappho</hi>, 610 B.C., <hi rend="ital">inventor of the metre which bears his name</hi>, <hi rend="ital">and which was imitated by the Latin poets</hi>, <hi rend="ital">esp. by Horace;</hi> v. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:2:13:27" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 2, 13, 27</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">4, 9, 7</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Ep. 1, 19, 29</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">2, 2, 99</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,002:15:29 sq" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> H. 15, 29 sq.</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:10:1:63" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 10, 1, 63</bibl>.— Hence, <orth extent="full" lang="la">Alcăĭcus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos>, = <foreign lang="greek">*)alkai+ko/s</foreign>, <hi rend="ital">of</hi> or <hi rend="ital">pertaining to Alcœus</hi>: versus, <hi rend="ital">the Alcaic verse;</hi> cf. <bibl default="NO"><author>Diom.</author> 510</bibl> P.; Grotef. Gr. II. 107; Zumpt, Gr. § 866.</sense></entryFree>
alcamenes: <entryFree id="n1745" type="main" key="Alca^me^nes"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Alcămĕnes</orth>, <itype>is</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*)alkame/nhs</foreign>, <sense id="n1745.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a Greek sculptor of the school of Phidias</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:1:30" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> N. D. 1, 30</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1038,001:8:11" default="NO"><author>Val. Max.</author> 8, 11</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:34:72" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 34, 8, 19, § 72</bibl>. <cb n="ALCI" /></sense></entryFree>
alcander: <entryFree id="n1746" type="main" key="Alcander"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Alcander</orth>, <itype>ri</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <sense id="n1746.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">A Trojan</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:13:258" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 13, 258</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n1746.1" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">A companion of Æneas</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:10:338" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 10, 338</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
alcathoe: <entryFree id="n1747" type="main" key="Alca^tho^e_"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Alcăthŏē</orth>, <itype>ēs</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*)alkaqo/h</foreign>, <sense id="n1747.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the castle of Megara</hi>, named after Alcathous; poet for <hi rend="ital">Megara</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:7:443" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 7, 443</bibl> (cf. Paus. Attic. p. 98).</sense></entryFree>
alcathous: <entryFree id="n1748" type="main" key="Alca^tho^us"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Alcăthŏus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*)alka/qoos</foreign>, <sense id="n1748.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">son of Pelops</hi>, <hi rend="ital">founder of Megara</hi>, which was hence called Alcathoi urbs, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:8:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 8, 8</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
alce: <entryFree id="n1749" type="main" key="Alce_"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Alcē</orth>, <itype>ēs</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, <sense id="n1749.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a town in</hi> Hispania Tarraconensis, now <hi rend="ital">Alcazar de S. Juan</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:40:48" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 40, 48</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:49" default="NO" valid="yes">49</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
alcea: <entryFree id="n1750" type="greek" key="alce^a"><orth extent="full" lang="la">alcĕa</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)lke/a</foreign>, <sense id="n1750.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a species of mallows</hi>: Malva alcea, Linn.; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:27:21" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 27, 4, 6, § 21</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
alcedo: <entryFree id="n1751" type="main" key="alce_do"><orth extent="full" lang="la">alcēdo</orth> (<orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">halc-</orth>), <itype>ĭnis</itype>, later † <orth extent="full" lang="la">alcyon</orth> (<orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">halc-</orth>), <itype>ĭnis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)lkuw/n</foreign> [O. H. Germ. alacra; the forms halcedo, halcyon arose from a fancied connection with <foreign lang="greek">a(/ls</foreign> = the sea], <sense id="n1751.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the kingfisher</hi>, <hi rend="ital">halcyon</hi>: Alcedo hispida, Linn.: Alcedo dicebatur ab antiquis pro alcyone, Paul. ex <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=7" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 7</bibl> Müll.: haec avis nunc Graece dicitur <foreign lang="greek">a(lkuw/n</foreign>, a nostris halcedo; sed hieme quod pullos dicitur tranquillo mari facere, eos dies halcyonios appellant (Gr. <foreign lang="greek">a(lkuoni/des h(me/rai</foreign>, Aristoph. Av. 1594 Bergk), <hi rend="ital">halcyon-days</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:L. L. 7:section=88" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> L. L. 7, § 88</bibl> Müll.; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,015:1:2:142" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Poen. 1, 2, 142</bibl>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:10:32:47" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 10, 32, 47</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
alcedonia: <entryFree id="n1752" type="main" key="alce_do_ni^a"><orth extent="full" lang="la">alcēdōnĭa</orth> (<orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">halc-</orth>), <itype>ōrum</itype>, <gen>n.</gen> <etym>alcedo</etym>, <sense id="n1752.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the fourteen winter days during which the kingfisher broods and the sea is calm</hi>, v. alcedo.—Hence, trop., <hi rend="ital">a deep calm</hi>, <hi rend="ital">profound tranquillity</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">ludi sunt, tranquillum est, alcedonia sunt circum forum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,006:prol. 26" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Cas. prol. 26</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">mare ipsum aiunt, ubi alcedonia sint, fieri feriatum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1245,001:Fer. Alc. 3" default="NO"><author>Front.</author> Fer. Alc. 3</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
alces: <entryFree id="n1753" type="main" key="alces"><orth extent="full" lang="la">alces</orth>, <itype>is</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym><foreign lang="greek">a)/lkh</foreign>; O. H. Germ. Elaho; Norse, elgr; Engl. elk</etym>, <sense id="n1753.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the elk</hi>, living in the northern regions: Cervus alces, Linn.; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:6:27" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 6, 27</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:8:39" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 8, 15, 16, § 39</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
alcestis: <entryFree id="n1754" type="main" key="Alcestis"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Alcestis</orth>, <itype>is</itype>, or <orth extent="full" lang="la">Alcestē</orth>, <itype>ēs</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*)/alkhstis</foreign> or <foreign lang="greek">*)alkh/sth</foreign>, <sense id="n1754.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">daughter of Pelias</hi>, <hi rend="ital">and wife of Admetus</hi>, <hi rend="ital">king of Pherœ</hi>, for the preservation of whose life she resigned her own, but was afterwards brought back from the lower world by Hercules, and restored to her husband, v. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0533,001:Fab. 51" default="NO"><author>Hyg.</author> Fab. 51</bibl> and 251; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1294,001:4:75" default="NO"><author>Mart.</author> 4, 75</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1276,001:6:652" default="NO"><author>Juv.</author> 6, 652</bibl>.—Also, <hi rend="ital">a play of Nœvius</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:19:7" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 19, 7</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
alceus: <entryFree id="n1755" type="main" key="Alceus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Alceus</orth> (<orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">dissyl.</orth>), <itype>ĕi and ĕos</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*)alkeu/s</foreign>, <sense id="n1755.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">father of Amphitryo and grandfather of Hercules</hi>, who was named Alcides from him, <bibl default="NO"><author>Serv.</author> ad Verg. A. 6, 392</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
alcibiades: <entryFree id="n1756" type="main" key="Alci^bi^a^des"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Alcĭbĭădes</orth>, <itype>is</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> (<sense id="n1756.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">gen.</hi> Alcibiadi, <bibl default="NO"><author>Arn.</author> adv. Gent. 6, p. 198</bibl>; <case>voc.</case> Gr. Alcibiadē, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:39:36" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 39, 36</bibl>), = <foreign lang="greek">*)alkibia/dhs</foreign>. </sense><sense id="n1756.1" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">An Athenian general in the time of the Peloponnesian war</hi>, distinguished for his beauty, wealth, and natural endowments, as well as for his changing fortunes and want of fixed principle, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:2:22" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> de Or. 2, 22</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:3:22" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Tusc. 3, 22</bibl> (his life, v. in Plut., Nep., and Just.).—Hence, * <orth extent="full" lang="la">Alcĭbĭădēus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos>, <hi rend="ital">pertaining to him</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Arn.</author> 6, p. 198</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n1756.2" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">The name of a later Greek in the time of the war with the Romans</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:39:36" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 39, 36</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
alcidemos: <entryFree id="n1757" type="main" key="Alci^de^mos"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Alcĭdĕmos</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, v. 1. Alcis.</entryFree>
alcides: <entryFree id="n1758" type="main" key="Alci_des"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Alcīdes</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*)alkei/dhs</foreign>, <sense id="n1758.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a male descendant of Alceus;</hi> usu. <hi rend="ital">his grandson Hercules</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,001:7:61" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> E. 7, 61</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:8:203" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> A. 8, 203</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">10, 321</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">quid memorem Alciden?</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 6, 123</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:1:12:25" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 1, 12, 25</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0660,001:4:1:12" default="NO"><author>Tib.</author> 4, 1, 12</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1224,001:1:20:49" default="NO"><author>Prop.</author> 1, 20, 49</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">non fugis, Alcide,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,002:9:75" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> H. 9, 75</bibl></cit>; <case>voc.</case> also Alcidā, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Herc. Fur. 1343" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Herc. Fur. 1343</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
alcimachus: <entryFree id="n1759" type="main" key="Alci^ma^chus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Alcĭmăchus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*)alki/maxos</foreign>, <sense id="n1759.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a famous Greek painter</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:35:139" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 35, 11, 40, § 139</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
alcimede: <entryFree id="n1760" type="main" key="Alci^me^de_"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Alcĭmĕdē</orth>, <itype>ēs</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*)alkime/dh</foreign>, <sense id="n1760.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a daughter of Autolycus</hi>, <hi rend="ital">wife of Æson</hi>, <hi rend="ital">and mother of Jason</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,002:6:105" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> H. 6, 105</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0533,001:Fab. 14" default="NO"><author>Hyg.</author> Fab. 14</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1035,001:1:317" default="NO"><author>Val. Fl.</author> 1, 317</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1020,001:5:236" default="NO"><author>Stat.</author> Th. 5, 236</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
alcimedon: <entryFree id="n1761" type="main" key="Alci^me^don"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Alcĭmĕdon</orth>, <itype>ontis</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <sense id="n1761.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the name of an artist in wood-carving</hi>, of whom nothing more is known; <cit><quote lang="la">perh. contemporary with Vergil,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,001:3:37" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> E. 3, 37</bibl></cit> and 44: ubi v. Wagn.</sense></entryFree>
alcinous: <entryFree id="n1762" type="main" key="Alci^no^us"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Alcĭnŏus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*)alki/noos</foreign>, <sense id="n1762.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a king of the Phœacians</hi>, <hi rend="ital">by whom Ulysses</hi>, <hi rend="ital">in his wanderings</hi>, <hi rend="ital">was entertained as guest</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,009:2:9:42" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> P. 2, 9, 42</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1224,001:1:14:24" default="NO"><author>Prop.</author> 1, 14, 24</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0533,001:Fab. 23:125" default="NO"><author>Hyg.</author> Fab. 23, 125</bibl>. On account of the luxury that prevailed at his court, Horace called luxurious young men juventus Alcinoi, <hi rend="ital">voluptuaries</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Hor.</author> Ep. 1, 2, 29</bibl> (cf. the words of Alcinous in Hom. Od. 8, 248). His love for horticulture (cf. Hom. Od. 7, 112 sq.) was also proverbial: pomaque et Alcinoi silvae, <pb n="82" /> <cb n="ALEA" /> <hi rend="ital">fruit-trees</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,002:2:87" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> G. 2, 87</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">Alcinoi pomaria,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1020,002:1:3:81" default="NO"><author>Stat.</author> S. 1, 3, 81</bibl></cit>.—Hence, Alcinoo dare poma, of any thing superfluous (as in silvam ligna ferre, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,004:1:10:34" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> S. 1, 10, 34</bibl>, and in Gr. <foreign lang="greek">glau=k) ei)s *)aqh/nas</foreign>), <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,009:4:2:10" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> P. 4, 2, 10</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1294,001:7:41" default="NO"><author>Mart.</author> 7, 41</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
alcis: <entryFree id="n1763" type="greek" key="Alcis1" n="1"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Alcis</orth>, <itype>ĭdis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*)alki/s</foreign> [from <foreign lang="greek">a)lkh/</foreign>, strength], <sense id="n1763.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">an appellation of Minerva among the Macedonians</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Minervae, quam vocant Alcidem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:42:51" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 42, 51</bibl></cit>, where Weissenb. reads <hi rend="ital">Alcidemon.</hi></sense></entryFree>

<entryFree id="n1764" type="hapax" key="Alcis2" n="2"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Alcis</orth>, <gen>m.</gen> <etym>acc. to some fr. the Gr. <foreign lang="greek">a)lkh/</foreign>; acc. to others, the Old Germ. Elk = force</etym>, <sense id="n1764.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a deity of the Naharvali</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,002:43" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> G. 43</bibl>; cf. Ruperti ad h. 1.</sense></entryFree>
alcisthene: <entryFree id="n1765" type="main" key="Alcisthe^ne_"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Alcisthĕnē</orth>, <itype>ēs</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*)alkisqe/nh</foreign>, <sense id="n1765.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a Greek female painter</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:35:147" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 35, 11, 40, § 147</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
alcithoe: <entryFree id="n1766" type="main" key="Alci^tho^e_"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Alcĭthŏē</orth>, <itype>ēs</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*)alkiqo/h</foreign>, <sense id="n1766.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">one of the daughters of Minyas in Thebes</hi>, <hi rend="ital">changed into a bat for ridiculing the orgies of Bacchus</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:4:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 4, 1</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">274</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">389</bibl> sq.; cf. O. Müll. Gesch. Hellen. Stämme, 1, 167 sq.</sense></entryFree>
alcmaeo: <entryFree id="n1767" type="main" key="Alcmaeo1" n="1"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Alcmaeo</orth>, <orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">Alcmaeon</orth>, <itype>ŏnis</itype>, and <orth extent="full" lang="la">Alcmaeus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> (Alcmaeo, <bibl default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Ac. 2, 28</bibl>: <sense id="n1767.0" n="I" level="1"><cit><quote lang="la">Alcmaeus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,005:3:4:30" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Capt. 3, 4, 30</bibl></cit>), = <foreign lang="greek">*)alkmai/wn</foreign>, <hi rend="ital">a son of Amphiaraus and Eriphyle;</hi> in obedience to the command of his father he killed his mother, and on this account was pursued by the Furies, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0533,001:Fab. 71" default="NO"><author>Hyg.</author> Fab. 71</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0533,001:73" default="NO">73</bibl> and 245; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:3:5:11" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 3, 5, 11</bibl>.—Hence, * <orth extent="full" lang="la">Alcmaeŏnĭus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos>, <hi rend="ital">pertaining to Alcmœon</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">furiae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1224,001:4:4:41" default="NO"><author>Prop.</author> 4, 4, 41</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>

<entryFree id="n1768" type="main" key="Alcmaeo2" n="2"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Alcmaeo</orth>, <itype>ŏnis</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <sense id="n1768.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a Pythagorean philosopher of Croton</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:1:27" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> N. D. 1, 27</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
alcmanium: <entryFree id="n1769" type="main" key="Alcma_ni^um"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Alcmānĭum metrum</orth>, <sense id="n1769.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the kind of verse named after the Greek poet Alcman</hi>, <hi rend="ital">Alcmanian; the</hi> Hexapodia anapaestica catalectica, <bibl default="NO"><author>Serv.</author> 1818</bibl> P.; cf. Grotef. Gr. II. 110 and 142; Munk, Metres, p. 102.</sense></entryFree>
alcmena: <entryFree id="n1770" type="main" key="Alcme_na"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Alcmēna</orth> or <orth extent="full" lang="la">Alcŭmēna</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, also <orth extent="full" lang="la">Alcmēnē</orth>, <itype>ēs</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> (always Alcumena in Plaut. Am.: <sense id="n1770.0" n="I" level="1"><cit><quote lang="la">Alcmene,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:9:276" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 9, 276</bibl></cit>; <hi rend="ital">gen.</hi>, Gr. Dor. Alcumenās, Plaut. Am. Argum.; <cit><quote lang="la">Alcmenes,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Herc. Oet. 1825" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Herc. Oet. 1825</bibl></cit>), = <foreign lang="greek">*)alkmh/nh</foreign>, <hi rend="ital">daughter of Electryon</hi>, <hi rend="ital">wife of Amphitryo</hi>, <hi rend="ital">and mother of Hercules by Jupiter</hi>, <hi rend="ital">and of his twin-brother Iphiclus by Amphitryo</hi>, Plaut. Am.; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0533,001:Fab. 29 al" default="NO"><author>Hyg.</author> Fab. 29 al.</bibl></sense></entryFree>
alcyon: <entryFree id="n1771" type="main" key="alcyon"><orth extent="full" lang="la">alcyon</orth>, v. alcedo.</entryFree>
alcyone: <entryFree id="n1772" type="main" key="Alcy^o^ne_"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Alcyŏnē</orth> (<orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">Halc-</orth>), <itype>ēs</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*)alkuo/nh</foreign>, <sense id="n1772.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a daughter of Æolus</hi>, <hi rend="ital">who</hi>, <hi rend="ital">from love to her husband Ceyx</hi>, <hi rend="ital">who had suffered shipwreck</hi>, <hi rend="ital">threw herself into the sea and was changed into a kingfisher</hi> (<foreign lang="greek">a)lkuw/n</foreign>; <cit><quote lang="la">v. alcedo),</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:11:384" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 11, 384</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">710</bibl> sq.</sense></entryFree>
alcyoneus: <entryFree id="n1773" type="main" key="alcy^o^ne_us"><orth extent="full" lang="la">alcyŏnēus</orth> and <orth extent="full" lang="la">-nĭus</orth> (<orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">halc-</orth>), <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>Alcyone</etym>, <sense id="n1773.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">pertaining to Alcyone</hi> or <hi rend="ital">alcyon</hi> (v. alcedo). </sense><sense id="n1773.1" n="a" level="4"> Alcyonei dies = alcedonia (q. v.), <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:11:2" default="NO"><author>Col.</author> 11, 2</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n1773.2" n="b" level="4"> Alcyoneum medicamen, or <hi rend="ital">absol.</hi>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">alcyŏnēum</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>n.</gen>, or even <orth extent="full" lang="la">alcyŏnĭum</orth>. <hi rend="ital">sea-foam</hi>, used as a remedy for spots on the face: <cit><quote lang="la">alcyoneo utuntur ad oculorum cicatrices,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:32:86" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 32, 8, 27, § 86</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0836,001:5:6:18" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cels.</author> 5, 6, 18</bibl>, n. 26.</sense></entryFree>
alcyonides: <entryFree id="n1774" type="greek" key="alcy^o^ni^des"><orth extent="full" lang="la">alcyŏnĭdes</orth> (<orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">halc-</orth>) dies = <foreign lang="greek">a(lkuoni/des h(me/rai</foreign>, the same as alcedonia (cf. also alcedo), <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:10:90" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 10, 32, 47, § 90</bibl>.</entryFree>
alea: <entryFree id="n1775" type="main" key="a_le^a"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ālĕa</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>of uncer. origin; Curtius asserts an obscure connection with the words for bone; Sanscr. asthi; Zend, açti; Gr. <foreign lang="greek">o)ste/on</foreign>; Lat. os (ossis)</etym>. <sense id="n1775.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">A game with dice</hi>, and in gen., <hi rend="ital">a game of hazard</hi> or <hi rend="ital">chance.</hi> There were among the Romans two kinds of dice, tesserae and tali, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,051:16:58" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Sen. 16, 58</bibl>. The tesserae had six sides, which were marked with I. II. III. IV. V. VI.; the tali were rounded on two sides, and marked only on the other four. Upon one side there was one point, unio, an ace, like the ace on cards, called canis; on the opp. side, six points called senio, six, sice; on the two other sides, three and four points, ternio and quaternio. In playing, four tali were used, but only three tesserae. They were put into a box made in the form of a tower, with a strait neck, and wider below than above, called fritillus, turris, turricula, etc. This box was shaken, and the dice were thrown upon the gaming-board. The highest or most fortunate throw, called Venus, jactus Venereus or basilicus, was, of the tesserae, three sixes, and of the tali when they all came out with different numbers. The worst or lowest throw, called jactus pessimus or damnosus, canis or canicula, was, of the tesserae, three aces, and of the tali when they were all the same. The other throws were valued acc. to the numbers.<cb n="ALEC" />  When one of the tali fell upon the end (in caput) it was said rectus cadere, or assistere, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,048:3:16:54" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Fin. 3, 16, 54</bibl>, and the throw was repeated. While throwing the dice, it was customary for a person to express his wishes, to repeat the name of his mistress, and the like. Games of chance were prohibited by the Lex Titia et Publicia et Cornelia (cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:3:24:58" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 3, 24, 58</bibl>), except in the month of December, during the Saturnalia, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1294,001:4:14:7" default="NO"><author>Mart.</author> 4, 14, 7</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1294,001:5:85" default="NO">5, 85</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1294,001:14:1" default="NO">14, 1</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=aug.:71" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Aug. 71</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:11:5" default="NO"><author>Dig.</author> 11, 5</bibl>. The character of gamesters, aleatores or aleones, was held as infamous in the time of Cicero, cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,013:2:5:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Cat. 2, 5, 10</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,035:2:23" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Phil. 2, 23</bibl>, although there was much playing with aleae, and old men were esp. fond of this game, because it required little physical exertion, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,051:16:58" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Sen. 16, 58</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=aug.:71" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Aug. 71</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1276,001:14:4" default="NO"><author>Juv.</author> 14, 4</bibl>; cf. <cit><quote lang="la">Jahn,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,008:2:471" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> Tr. 2, 471</bibl></cit>; Rupert. ad <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,002:24:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> G. 24, 5</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">provocat me in aleam, ut ego ludam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,008:2:3:75" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Curc. 2, 3, 75</bibl></cit>.—Ludere aleā or aleam, also sometimes in aleā: <cit><quote lang="la">in foro aleā ludere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,035:2:23:56" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Phil. 2, 23, 56</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:11:5:1" default="NO"><author>Dig.</author> 11, 5, 1</bibl>: ludit assidue aleam, Poët. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=aug.:70" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Aug. 70</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">aleam studiosissime lusit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=cl.:33" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Claud. 33</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=nero:30" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Ner. 30</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1276,001:8:10" default="NO"><author>Juv.</author> 8, 10</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">repetitio ejus, quod in aleā lusum est,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:11:5:4" default="NO"><author>Dig.</author> 11, 5, 4</bibl></cit>.—Hence, in aleā aliquid perdere, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,035:2:13" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Phil. 2, 13</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">exercere aleam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,002:24" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> G. 24</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">indulgere aleae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=aug.:70" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Aug. 70</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">oblectare se aleā,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=dom.:21" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Dom. 21</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">prosperiore aleā uti,</quote> <trans><tr>to play fortunately</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=cal.:41" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Calig. 41</bibl></cit>.—<usg type="style">Trop.</usg>: Jacta alea esto, <hi rend="ital">Let the die be cast! Let the game be ventured!</hi> the memorable exclamation of Cæsar when, at the Rubicon, after long hesitation, he finally decided to march to Rome, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=jul.:32" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Caes. 32</bibl>, ubi v. Casaub. and Ruhnk.—</sense><sense id="n1775.1" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Transf.</usg>, <hi rend="ital">any thing uncertain</hi> or <hi rend="ital">contingent</hi>, <hi rend="ital">an accident</hi>, <hi rend="ital">chance</hi>, <hi rend="ital">hazard</hi>, <hi rend="ital">venture</hi>, <hi rend="ital">risk</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">alea domini vitae ac rei familiaris,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:R. R. 1:4" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> R. R. 1, 4</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">sequentes non aleam, sed rationem aliquam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:ib. 1:18" default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 1, 18</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">aleam inesse hostiis deligendis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,053:2:15" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Div. 2, 15</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">dare summam rerum in aleam,</quote> <trans><tr>to risk</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:42:59" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 42, 59</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">in dubiam imperii servitiique aleam ire,</quote> <trans><tr>fortune</tr>, <tr>chance</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:1:23" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 1, 23</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">alea belli,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:37:36" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 37, 36</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">talibus admissis alea grandis inest,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,004:1:376" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> A. A. 1, 376</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">periculosae plenum opus aleae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:2:1:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 2, 1, 6</bibl></cit>: M. Tullius extra omnem ingenii aleam positus, <hi rend="ital">raised above all doubt of his talents</hi>, Plin. praef. § 7: emere aleam, in the Pandects, <hi rend="ital">to purchase any thing uncertain</hi>, <hi rend="ital">contingent</hi>, e. g. a draught of fishes, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:18:1:8" default="NO"><author>Dig.</author> 18, 1, 8</bibl>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:18:4:7" default="NO"><author>ib.</author> 18, 4, 7</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
alearis: <entryFree id="n1776" type="main" key="a_le^a_ris"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ālĕāris</orth>, <itype>e</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>alea</etym>, <sense id="n1776.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">of</hi> or <hi rend="ital">pertaining to a game of chance</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">tabula,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2305,001:Chron. 2:1" default="NO"><author>Cael. Aur.</author> Chron. 2, 1</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
alearius: <entryFree id="n1777" type="hapax" key="a_le^a_ri^us"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ālĕārĭus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>id.</etym>, <sense id="n1777.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">of</hi> or <hi rend="ital">pertaining to a game of chance</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">amicitiae,</quote> <trans><tr>formed at the gaming-table</tr>,</trans> <bibl default="NO"><author>Amm.</author> 28, 4, 21</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
aleator: <entryFree id="n1778" type="main" key="a_le^a_tor"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ālĕātor</orth>, <itype>ōris</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <etym>id.</etym>, <sense id="n1778.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a player with dice</hi>, also <hi rend="ital">a gamester</hi> in gen., <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,017:2:3:29" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Rud. 2, 3, 29</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,013:2:10:23" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Cat. 2, 10, 23</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,035:2:27" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Phil. 2, 27</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">aleatoris castra,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:5:13" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Verr. 2, 5, 13</bibl></cit>; so <bibl default="NO"><author>Sid.</author> Ep. 5, 17</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:11:5" default="NO"><author>Dig.</author> 11, 5</bibl>; Cod. 3, 43.</sense></entryFree>
aleatorius: <entryFree id="n1779" type="main" key="a_le^a_to_ri^us"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ālĕātōrĭus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>aleator</etym>, <sense id="n1779.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">pertaining to a gamester</hi>: aleatoria damna, <hi rend="ital">in gaming</hi>, * <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,035:2:27" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Phil. 2, 27</bibl>: aleatorium forum calfecimus, <hi rend="ital">gaming-board</hi>, August. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=aug.:71" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Aug. 71</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">ritu,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:18:13" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 18, 13</bibl></cit>.—Hence, <orth extent="full" lang="la">ālĕātōrĭum</orth>, <itype>ii</itype>, <gen>n.</gen>, <hi rend="ital">the place where games of chance are played</hi>, <hi rend="ital">a gaming-house</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Sid.</author> Ep. 2, 2</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
alebas: <entryFree id="n1780" type="main" key="A^le_bas"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ălēbas</orth>, v. Aleuas.</entryFree>
alebria: <entryFree id="n1781" type="gloss" key="a^lebri^a"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ălebrĭa</orth>, <itype>ium</itype>, <gen>n.</gen> <etym>alo</etym>, <sense id="n1781.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">nourishing food</hi>, = bene alentia, Paul. ex <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=25" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 25</bibl> Müll.</sense></entryFree>
alec: <entryFree id="n1782" type="main" key="a_lec"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ālec</orth> (better, <orth extent="full" lang="la">allec; hallec</orth> also in MSS.), <itype>ēcis</itype>, <gen>n.</gen>, or <orth extent="full" lang="la">ālex</orth> (<orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">hāl-</orth>), <itype>ēcis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> and <gen>m.</gen> (v. Rudd. I. p. 17, n. 93; Schne<bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:Gr. 2:110" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Gr. 2, 110</bibl> and 128), acc. to <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:31:95" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 31, 8, 44, § 95</bibl>, <sense id="n1782.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the sediment of a costly fish-sauce</hi>, garum; and in gen. <hi rend="ital">the sauce prepared from small fish</hi>, <hi rend="ital">fish-pickle</hi>, <hi rend="ital">fish-brine</hi>: alec danunt, * Plaut. Fragm. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> 2, 395</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">120, 3</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">faecem et allec,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,004:2:4:73" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> S. 2, 4, 73</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">2, 8, 9</bibl> K. and H.: <cit><quote lang="la">putri cepas hallece natantes,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1294,001:3:77" default="NO"><author>Mart.</author> 3, 77</bibl></cit> Schneid.—The <number>plur.</number> not in use, v. <bibl default="NO"><author>Prisc.</author> p. 686</bibl> P.</sense></entryFree>
alecto: <entryFree id="n1783" type="main" key="A_lecto"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ālecto</orth>, <itype>ūs</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*)alhktw/, ou=s</foreign> (found only in <case>nom.</case> and <case>acc.</case>), <sense id="n1783.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the name of one of the three furies</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:7:341" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 7, 341</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">Alecto torvam faciem Exuit,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 7, 415</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">luctificam Alecto ciet,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 7, 324</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
alectorius: <entryFree id="n1784" type="hapax" key="a^lecto^ri^us"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ălectŏrĭus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos>, <sense id="n1784.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">pertaining to a cock</hi> (<foreign lang="greek">a)le/ktwr</foreign>): <cit><quote lang="la">gemma,</quote> <trans><tr>a gem found in the maw of a cock</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:37:144" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 37, 10, 54, § 144</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
alectorolophos: <entryFree id="n1785" type="greek" key="a^lecto^ro^lo^pho^s"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ălectŏrŏlŏphŏs</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)lektoro/lofos</foreign>,<cb n="ALES" />  <sense id="n1785.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">an herb good for a cough</hi>, <hi rend="ital">cock's comb</hi>: Rhinanthus crista galli, Linn.; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:27:40" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 27, 5, 23, § 40</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
alecula: <entryFree id="n1786" type="main" key="a_le_cu^la"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ālēcŭla</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <lbl>dim.</lbl> <etym>alec</etym>, <sense id="n1786.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">fish-sauce</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:8:17" default="NO"><author>Col.</author> 8, 17</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:6:8" default="NO">6, 8</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
aleius: <entryFree id="n1787" type="main" key="A^le_i^us"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ălēĭus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos>, = <foreign lang="greek">*)alh/i+os</foreign>, <sense id="n1787.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">of</hi> or <hi rend="ital">pertaining to Ale in Lycia</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Aleïi campi,</quote> <trans><tr>where Bellerophon</tr>, <tr>having been thrown from Pegasus</tr>, <tr>and blinded by the lightning of Jupiter</tr>, <tr>wandered and perished</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0533,001:Fab. 57" default="NO"><author>Hyg.</author> Fab. 57</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,010:259" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> Ib. 259</bibl>: qui miser in campis maerens errabat Aleïs (<hi rend="ital">per synaeresin</hi> for Aleïis), <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:3:26:63" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 3, 26, 63</bibl> (as transl. of <foreign lang="greek">*)/htoi o( ka\p pedi/on to\ *)alh/ion oi)=os a)la=to</foreign>, Hom. ll. 6, 201; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:5:91" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 5, 27, 22, § 91</bibl>).</sense></entryFree>
