alemanni: <entryFree id="n1788" type="main" key="A^le^manni"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ălĕmanni</orth> (<orth extent="full" lang="la">Ălămanni</orth> and <orth extent="full" lang="la">Ălă-mani</orth>), <itype>ōrum</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <etym>= Alle-Männer</etym>, <sense id="n1788.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the Alemanni</hi>, <hi rend="ital">German tribes who</hi> (as their name indicates) <hi rend="ital">formed a confederation on the Upper Rhine and Danube</hi>, from whom the Gauls transferred the name to the whole German nation; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1224,001:Caes. 21" default="NO"><author>Aur. Vict.</author> Caes. 21</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Claud.</author> II. Cons. Stil. 17</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Sid.</author> 5, 375</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n1788.1" n="II" level="1"> Derivv., </sense><sense id="n1788.2" n="1" level="3"> <orth extent="full" lang="la">Ălĕmannĭa</orth> (<orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">Ălăm-</orth>), <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>cf. Fr. Allemagne; Ital. Alemagna</etym>, <hi rend="ital">the country of the Alemanni</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Claud.</author> I. Cons. Stil. 234</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n1788.3" n="2" level="3"> <orth extent="full" lang="la">Ălĕmannĭcus</orth> (<orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">Ălăm-</orth>), <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos>, <hi rend="ital">Alemannic</hi>, <hi rend="ital">pertaining to the Alemanni</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">tentoria,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Amm.</author> 27, 2</bibl></cit>.—Hence, <hi rend="ital">a surname of Caracalla</hi>, <hi rend="ital">on account of his victory over the Alemanni</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Spart.</author> Carac. 10</bibl>. —</sense><sense id="n1788.4" n="3" level="3"> <orth extent="full" lang="la">Ălĕmannus</orth> (<orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">Ălăm-</orth>), <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <hi rend="ital">a surname of the emperor Gratian</hi>, <hi rend="ital">on account of his victory over the Alemanni</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1224,001:Epit. 47" default="NO"><author>Aur. Vict.</author> Epit. 47</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
alemon: <entryFree id="n1789" type="main" key="A^le_mon"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ălēmon</orth>, <itype>ŏnis</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <etym><foreign lang="greek">a)lh/mwn</foreign>, a wanderer</etym>, <sense id="n1789.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a Greek; father of Myscelus</hi>, <hi rend="ital">who built Crotona in Lower Italy</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:15:18" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 15, 18</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
alemona: <entryFree id="n1790" type="hapax" key="A^le^mo_na"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ălĕmōna</orth> (<orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">Ălĭm-</orth>), <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>alo</etym>, <sense id="n1790.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a tutelar goddess of the fœtus</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Tert.</author> Anim. 37</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
alemonides: <entryFree id="n1791" type="main" key="A^le_mo^ni^de_s"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ălēmŏnĭdēs</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <sense id="n1791.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">patr.</hi>, <hi rend="ital">the son of Alemon</hi>, i. e. <hi rend="ital">Myscelus</hi>, <hi rend="ital">who founded Crotona in Lower Italy</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:15:26" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 15, 26</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
aleo: <entryFree id="n1792" type="main" key="a_le^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ālĕo</orth>, <itype>ōnis</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> (rare, for the class. aleator), <sense id="n1792.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a gamester</hi>, Naev. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:24" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> 24</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">impudicus et vorax et aleo,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0472,001:29:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cat.</author> 29, 2</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0472,001:6:11" default="NO" valid="yes">6, 11</bibl>; Tert. Fug. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0969,001:13" default="NO"><author>Pers.</author> 13</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
aleria: <entryFree id="n1793" type="main" key="A^le^ri^a"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ălĕrĭa</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*)aleri/a</foreign>, <sense id="n1793.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the oldest town of the island Corsica</hi>, captured by L. Scipio: HEC. CEPIT. CORSICA(m). ALERIA(m) QVE. VRBE(m), the second epitaph of the Scipios in Grotef. 4, 298; cf. Wordsw. p. 160; Mannert. Ital. 2, 516 sq.</sense></entryFree>
ales: <entryFree id="n1794" type="main" key="a_le^s"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ālĕs</orth>, <itype>ālĭtĭs</itype> (<case>abl.</case> aliti, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Med. 1014" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Med. 1014</bibl>; <sense id="n1794.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">gen. plur.</hi> alitum, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1294,001:13:6" default="NO"><author>Mart.</author> 13, 6</bibl>, and lengthened alituum, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:2:928" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 2, 928</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:5:801" default="NO" valid="yes">5, 801</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:1039" default="NO" valid="yes">1039</bibl>; 1078; 6, 1216; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:8:27" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 8, 27</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1020,002:1:2:184" default="NO"><author>Stat.</author> S. 1, 2, 184</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Manil.</author> 5, 370</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Amm.</author> 19, 2</bibl>) [ala-ire, as comes, eques, etc., acc. to some; but cf. Corss. Ausspr. II. p. 209], <pos>adj.</pos> and <hi rend="ital">subst.</hi> (<usg type="style">poet.</usg> and post-Aug. prose). </sense><sense id="n1794.1" n="I" level="1"> <pos>Adj.</pos>, <hi rend="ital">winged</hi>: angues, Pac. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,036:1:19" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Inv. 1, 19</bibl>; cf. Mos. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,043:3:9" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Rep. 3, 9</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">ales avis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:2:44" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> N. D. 2, 44</bibl></cit> (as transl. of the Gr. <foreign lang="greek">ai)o/los o)/rnis</foreign>, Arat. Phaen. 275): <cit><quote lang="la">equus,</quote> <trans>i. e. <tr>Pegasus</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,001:3:12:24" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> Am. 3, 12, 24</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">deus,</quote> <trans><tr>Mercury</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:2:714" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> M. 2, 714</bibl></cit>; so also <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1020,001:4:605" default="NO"><author>Stat.</author> Th. 4, 605</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">currus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Med. 1024" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Med. 1024</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">fama,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Claud.</author> I. Cons. Stil. 2, 408</bibl></cit>.—And with a trope common in all languages, <hi rend="ital">quick</hi>, <hi rend="ital">fleet</hi>, <hi rend="ital">rapid</hi>, <hi rend="ital">swift</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">rutili tris ignis et alitis Austri,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:8:430" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 8, 430</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">passus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:10:587" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 10, 587</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">harundo,</quote> <trans><tr>the swift arrow</tr>,</trans> <bibl default="NO"><author>Prud.</author> Psych. 323</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n1794.2" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Subst. com. gen.</hi>, <hi rend="ital">a fowl</hi>, <hi rend="ital">a bird</hi> (only of large birds, while <hi rend="ital">volucris</hi> includes also insects that fly). </sense><sense id="n1794.3" n="A" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">Com. gen.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">pennis delata,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:6:822" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 6, 822</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">exterrita pennis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:5:506" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 5, 506</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">argentea,</quote> <trans>i. e. <tr>the raven before its metamorphosis</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:2:536" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 2, 536</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">superba,</quote> <trans><tr>the peacock</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1294,001:14:67" default="NO"><author>Mart.</author> 14, 67</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1294,001:9:56" default="NO">9, 56</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">longaeva,</quote> <trans><tr>the phœnix</tr>,</trans> <bibl default="NO"><author>Claud.</author> 35, 83</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">famelica,</quote> <trans><tr>the pigeon-hawk</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:10:28" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 10, 10, 12, § 28</bibl></cit>.—On the contr., <hi rend="ital">masc.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Phoebeïus,</quote> <trans><tr>the raven</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:2:544" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 2, 544</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">albus,</quote> <trans><tr>the swan</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:2:20:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 2, 20, 10</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">cristatus,</quote> <trans><tr>the cock</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,007:1:455 al" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> F. 1, 455 al.</bibl></cit> —</sense><sense id="n1794.4" n="B" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">Fem.</hi>, as referring to a female bird: <cit><quote lang="la">Daulias ales = philomela,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,002:15:154" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> H. 15, 154</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">exterrita = columba,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:5:505" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 5, 505</bibl></cit>. But ales, i.e. aquila, as the bird of Jove, is sometimes <hi rend="ital">masc.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">fulvus Jovis ales,</quote> <trans><tr>the eagle</tr>,</trans> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 12, 247</bibl></cit>; <cit><quote lang="la">called also: minister fulminis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:4:4:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 4, 4, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">flammiger,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1020,001:8:675" default="NO"><author>Stat.</author> Th. 8, 675</bibl></cit>. —Also <hi rend="ital">fem.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">aetheriā lapsa plagā Jovis ales,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:1:394" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 1, 394</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">regia ales,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:4:362" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 4, 362</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ales digna Jove,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Manil.</author> 1, 443</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n1794.5" n="C" level="2"> For <hi rend="ital">a deity as winged</hi>, <hi rend="ital">masc.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Cyllenius ales,</quote> <trans>i.e. <tr>Mercury</tr>,</trans> <bibl default="NO"><author>Claud.</author> 33, 77</bibl></cit>; <cit><quote lang="la">or even for men: aureus ales,</quote> <trans><tr>Perseus</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1020,001:1:544" default="NO"><author>Stat.</author> Th. 1, 544</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n1794.6" n="D" level="2"> Ales canorus, <hi rend="ital">a swan</hi>, for <hi rend="ital">a poet</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:2:20:15" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 2, 20, 15</bibl>. —Also <hi rend="ital">absol.</hi> ales: Maeonii carminis ales, of the singer of a Mæonian (Homeric) song, <pb n="83" /> <cb n="ALEX" /> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:1:6:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 1, 6, 2</bibl> Jahn. (In <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:5:298" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 5, 298</bibl>, if ales erant is read, ales is collect.; cf. Schne<bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Gr. 2, 240</bibl>; but the <number>sing.</number> seems to be more in accordance with the preceding hominem putat locutum, she supposing that she heard a man, but it was a bird, and Merkel here reads <hi rend="ital">Ales erat.</hi>）—</sense><sense id="n1794.7" n="E" level="2"> In the lang. of augury, alites are <hi rend="ital">birds that gave omens by their flight</hi>, as the buteo, sanqualis, aquila, etc. (but oscines, by their voice, as the corvus, cornix, and noctua), <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=193" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 193</bibl> (cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=3" default="NO"><author>id.</author> p. 3</bibl>); <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:2:64:160" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> N. D. 2, 64, 160</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">tum huc, tum illuc volent alites: tum a dextrā, tum a sinistrā parte canant oscines,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,053:1:53:120" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Div. 1, 53, 120</bibl></cit>; cf. Manut. ad <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:6:6, p. 394" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 6, 6, p. 394</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:10:43" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 10, 19, 22, § 43</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Arn.</author> adv. G. 7, 59</bibl>.—Hence, <usg type="style">poet.</usg>: ales, <hi rend="ital">augury</hi>, <hi rend="ital">omen</hi>, <hi rend="ital">sign</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">cum bonā nubit alite,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0472,001:61:20" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cat.</author> 61, 20</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">malā soluta navis exit alite,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,003:10:1" default="NO"><author>Hor.</author> Epod. 10, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">secundā alite,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 16, 23</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
alesa: <entryFree id="n1795" type="main" key="A^le_sa"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ălēsa</orth>, v. Halesa.</entryFree>
alesco: <entryFree id="n1796" type="main" key="a^lesco"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ălesco</orth>, <itype>ĕre</itype>, <sense id="n1796.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">v. inch. n.</hi> [alo], <hi rend="ital">to grow up</hi>, <hi rend="ital">increase</hi> (only ante-class.), <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:R. R. 1:44:4" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> R. R. 1, 44, 4</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:2:4:19" default="NO">2, 4, 19</bibl>: alescendi cacumen, * <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:2:1130" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 2, 1130</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
alesia: <entryFree id="n1797" type="main" key="A^le^si^a"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ălĕsĭa</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*)alesi/a</foreign>, Diod. Sic., <sense id="n1797.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a city of the Mandubii in Celtic Gaul</hi>, now <hi rend="ital">Alise</hi> in the <hi rend="ital">Dép. de la Cōte d' Or</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:7:68" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 7, 68</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,002:3:47" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> B. C. 3, 47</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1044,001:2:47" default="NO"><author>Vell.</author> 2, 47</bibl>.—Also, <orth extent="full" lang="la">Ălexĭa</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*)aleci/a</foreign> Strabo, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1242,001:2:2" default="NO"><author>Flor.</author> 2, 2</bibl>; cf. Mannert Gall. 175.</sense></entryFree>
alesus: <entryFree id="n1798" type="main" key="A^le_sus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ălēsus</orth>, v. Halesus.</entryFree>
alethia: <entryFree id="n1799" type="main" key="A^le_thi_a"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ălēthīa</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)lh/qeia</foreign> (truth), <sense id="n1799.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">one of the Æons of Valentinus</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Tert.</author> Valent. 12</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
aletinus: <entryFree id="n1800" type="main" key="A^le_ti_nus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ălētīnus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <sense id="n1800.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">an inhabitant of the town</hi> Aletium, <hi rend="ital">in the land of the Hirpini</hi>, now <hi rend="ital">Calitri</hi> (* acc. to others, <hi rend="ital">Lecce</hi>), <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:3:105" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 3, 11, 16, § 105</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
aletrium: <entryFree id="n1801" type="main" key="A^le_tri^um"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ălētrĭum</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>n.</gen>, <sense id="n1801.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a town in Latium</hi>, now <hi rend="ital">Alatri;</hi> whence, </sense><sense id="n1801.1" n="a" level="4"> <orth extent="full" lang="la">Ălētrīnas</orth>, <itype>ātis</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos>, <hi rend="ital">pertaining to Aletrium</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,010:chapter=16" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Clu. 16</bibl>. —<orth extent="full" lang="la">Ălētrīnātes</orth>, <hi rend="ital">the inhabitants of Aletrium</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,010:chapter=20" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Clu. 20</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:3:63" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 3, 5, 9, § 63</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n1801.2" n="b" level="4"> Also, <orth extent="full" lang="la">Ălētrīnensis</orth>, <itype>e</itype>, the same: <cit><quote lang="la">foederatus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,026:chapter=22" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Balb. 22</bibl></cit> dub.</sense></entryFree>
aletudo: <entryFree id="n1802" type="gloss" key="a^le^tu_do"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ălĕtūdo</orth>, <itype>ĭnis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>alo</etym>, <sense id="n1802.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">fatness</hi>, = corporis pinguedo, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=23" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 23</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
aleuas: <entryFree id="n1803" type="main" key="A^leuas"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ăleuas</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*)aleu/as</foreign>. <sense id="n1803.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">A tyrant of Larissa</hi>, <hi rend="ital">slain by his own servants</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,010:321" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> Ib. 321</bibl> and 509 Merk.—</sense><sense id="n1803.1" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">A worker in bronze</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:34:86" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 34, 8, 19, § 86</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
aleus: <entryFree id="n1804" type="main" key="A_le^us1" n="1"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ālĕus</orth>, <itype>another reading for Alius</itype>, = Elius, Plaut. Capt.; v. 1. Alius.</entryFree>

<entryFree id="n1805" type="hapax" key="A^le^us2" n="2"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ălĕus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos>: Alea Minerva, <sense id="n1805.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the Alean</hi> or <hi rend="ital">Alic Minerva</hi>, so called either from Aleus, king of Arcadia, or from Alea, a town in that country, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1020,001:4:288" default="NO"><author>Stat.</author> Th. 4, 288</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
alex: <entryFree id="n1806" type="main" key="a_lex"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ālex</orth>, v. alec.</entryFree>
alexamenus: <entryFree id="n1807" type="main" key="A^lexa^me^nus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ălexămĕnus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*)alecameno/s</foreign>, <sense id="n1807.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a leader of the Ætolians</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:35:24" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 35, 24</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
alexander: <entryFree id="n1808" type="main" key="A^lexander"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ălexander</orth>, <itype>dri</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <etym><foreign lang="greek">*)ale/candros</foreign>, hence, <bibl default="NO"><author>Charis.</author> 64</bibl> P. asserts that there is also a <case>nom.</case> Alexandrus, but gives no example</etym>, <sense id="n1808.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the name of many persons of antiquity;</hi> among whom, </sense><sense id="n1808.1" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">The most renowned is Alexander</hi>, <hi rend="ital">son of Philip and Olympia</hi>, <hi rend="ital">surnamed</hi> Magnus, <hi rend="ital">the founder of the great Macedonian monarchy extending from Macedonia to the Indus</hi> (v. his life in Plut. and Curt.).—</sense><sense id="n1808.2" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Alexander</hi>, <hi rend="ital">son of Perseus</hi>, <hi rend="ital">king of Macedonia</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:42:52" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 42, 52</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:45:39" default="NO" valid="yes">45, 39</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n1808.3" n="III" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">A tyrant of Pherœ</hi>, <hi rend="ital">in Thessaly;</hi> hence also sometimes called Pheræus, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,053:1:25" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Div. 1, 25</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,036:2:49" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Inv. 2, 49</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:2:7" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Off. 2, 7</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,001:Pelop. 5:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Pelop. 5, 1</bibl>.— </sense><sense id="n1808.4" n="IV" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">A king of Epirus</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:8:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 8, 3</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n1808.5" n="V" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Another name of Paris</hi>, <hi rend="ital">son of Priam</hi>, Enn. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:L. L. 7:5:96" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> L. L. 7, 5, 96</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,054:chapter=15" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Fat. 15</bibl>; Auct. ad <bibl default="NO"><author>Her.</author> 4, 30</bibl>; <cit><quote lang="la">hence sometimes, Alexander Paris,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:34:76 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 34, 8, 19, § 76 al.</bibl></cit></sense></entryFree>
alexandrea: <entryFree id="n1809" type="main" key="A^lexandre_a"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ălexandrēa</orth> (the form of Cicero's time, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,035:2:19" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Phil. 2, 19</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,048:5:19" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Fin. 5, 19</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1224,001:4:10:33" default="NO"><author>Prop.</author> 4, 10, 33</bibl> (<sense id="n1809.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">Alexandria</hi>, Müll.); <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:4:14:35" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 4, 14, 35</bibl> K. and H.; also <orth extent="full" lang="la">Ălexandrīa</orth> under the Empire; so, Antiochēa and Antiochīa; cf. <bibl default="NO"><author>Prisc.</author> p. 588</bibl> P., Ochsn. Eclog. 143, and Osann ad <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,043:page=467" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Rep. p. 467</bibl>), <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*)aleca/ndreia</foreign>, <hi rend="ital">a name of several towns of antiquity;</hi> among which, </sense><sense id="n1809.1" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">The most distinguished is the city built by Alexander the Great</hi>, <hi rend="ital">after the destruction of Tyre</hi>, <hi rend="ital">upon the north coast of Egypt</hi>, <hi rend="ital">the residence of the Ptolemies</hi>, <hi rend="ital">and the emporium of Eastern trade during the Middle Ages</hi>, <hi rend="ital">sometimes with the appellation</hi> Magna, now <hi rend="ital">Iskenderieh</hi> or <hi rend="ital">Alexandria</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:5:62" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 5, 10, 11, § 62</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n1809.2" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">A town in Troas</hi>, now <hi rend="ital">Eski Stamboul</hi>, <hi rend="ital">sometimes called</hi> Alexandria, <bibl default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Ac. 2, 4</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:5:124" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 5, 30, 33, § 124</bibl>; <cit><quote lang="la">and sometimes Alexandria Troas,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:35:42" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 35, 42</bibl></cit>; <cb n="ALGO" /> 37, 35; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:36:128" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 36, 16, 25, § 128</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n1809.3" n="III" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">A town in Aria</hi>, <hi rend="ital">also called</hi> Alexandria Ariōn (i. e. Arionum), now <hi rend="ital">Herat</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:6:61" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 6, 17, 21, § 61</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:6:93" default="NO" valid="yes">6, 23, 25, § 93</bibl>.—Hence, <orth extent="full" lang="la">Ălexandrīnus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos>, <hi rend="ital">pertaining to Alexandria</hi>, </sense><sense id="n1809.4" n="A" level="2"> In Egypt: <cit><quote lang="la">vita atque licentia,</quote> <trans><tr>a luxurious and licentious life</tr>, <tr>like that of Alexandria</tr>, <tr>at that time a centre of luxury</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,002:3:110" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. C. 3, 110</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Petr.</author> 31</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:1:2:7" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 1, 2, 7</bibl> Spald.: <cit><quote lang="la">Alexandrina navis,</quote> <trans><tr>an Alexandrian merchantship</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=aug.:98" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Aug. 98</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=nero:45" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Ner. 45</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=gal.:10" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Galb. 10</bibl>: Bellum Alexandrinum, <hi rend="ital">the history of the expedition of Cœsar into Egypt</hi>, <hi rend="ital">after the battle at Pharsalus</hi>, Auct. B. Alex. 1.—</sense><sense id="n1809.5" n="B" level="2"> In Troas, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:15:131" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 15, 30, 39, § 131</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:23:158" default="NO" valid="yes">23, 8, 80, § 158</bibl>. —<hi rend="ital">Subst.</hi>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">Ălexandrīni</orth>, <itype>ōrum</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <hi rend="ital">inhabitants of Alexandria</hi> (in Egypt): <cit><quote lang="la">ad Alexandrinos istos revertamur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,030:12:34" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Rab. Post. 12, 34</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,027:21:49" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Pis. 21, 49</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
alexipharmacon: <entryFree id="n1810" type="greek" key="a^lexi^pharma^con"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ălexĭpharmăcon</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>n.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)lecifa/rmakon</foreign>, <sense id="n1810.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">an antidote for poison</hi>, only in <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:21:146" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 21, 20, 84, § 146</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
alga: <entryFree id="n1811" type="main" key="alga"><orth extent="full" lang="la">alga</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>from ligo, qs. alliga, as binding, entwining, Van.</etym>, <sense id="n1811.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">sea-weed</hi>, comprising several kinds, of which one (Fucus vesiculosus, Linn.) was used for coloring red, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:26:10:66" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 26, 10, 66</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:32:66" default="NO" valid="yes">32, 6, 22, § 66</bibl>. Freq. in the poets, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:3:17:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 3, 17, 10</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:7:590" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 7, 590</bibl>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1294,001:10:16:5" default="NO"><author>Mart.</author> 10, 16, 5</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1035,001:1:252" default="NO"><author>Val. Fl.</author> 1, 252</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Claud.</author> Ruf. 1, 387</bibl>. In prose, Auct. B. Afr. 24 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi> —Hence also for <hi rend="ital">a thing of little worth</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">vilior algā,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,004:2:5:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> S. 2, 5, 8</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">projectā vilior algā,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,001:7:42" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> E. 7, 42</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
algensis: <entryFree id="n1812" type="hapax" key="algensis"><orth extent="full" lang="la">algensis</orth>, <itype>e</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>alga</etym>, <sense id="n1812.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">that supports itself on sea-weed</hi>, <hi rend="ital">lives upon it</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:9:131" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 9, 37, 91, § 131</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
algeo: <entryFree id="n1813" type="main" key="algeo"><orth extent="full" lang="la">algeo</orth>, <itype>alsi, 2</itype>, <pos>v. n.</pos> <etym>acc. to Fest. from <foreign lang="greek">a)lge/w</foreign> = to feel pain; cf. <foreign lang="greek">a)/lgos</foreign>, algor, and algus</etym>, <sense id="n1813.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to be cold</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to feel cold;</hi> cf. <bibl default="NO"><author>Consent.</author> 2051</bibl> P. (opp. aestuare; accordingly a subjective coldness; while <hi rend="ital">frigere</hi>, opp. calere, is objective, Doed. Syn. 3, 89): si algebis, tremes, Naev. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:2:71:286" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> de Or. 2, 71, 286</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">erudiunt juventutem, algendo, aestuando,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:2:14:34" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 2, 14, 34</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">sudavit et alsit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,006:413" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> A. P. 413</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">algentis manus est calfacienda sinu,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,004:2:214" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> A. A. 2, 214</bibl></cit>.—<usg type="style">Poet.</usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">algentes togae, i. e. so torn to pieces, that those who wear them must suffer from cold,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1294,001:12:36" default="NO"><author>Mart.</author> 12, 36</bibl></cit>.— <usg type="style">Trop.</usg>: probitas laudatur et alget, <hi rend="ital">virtue is praised</hi>, <hi rend="ital">and yet freezes</hi>, i. e. <hi rend="ital">is not cherished</hi>, <hi rend="ital">is neglected</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1276,001:1:74" default="NO"><author>Juv.</author> 1, 74</bibl>.—Hence, <orth extent="full" lang="la">algens</orth>, <pos>P. a.</pos>, in the post-Aug. per., = algidus and frigidus, <hi rend="ital">cold</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">pruinae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1020,001:3:469" default="NO"><author>Stat.</author> Th. 3, 469</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">loca,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:14:27" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 14, 2, 4, § 27</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:16:46" default="NO" valid="yes">16, 10, 19, § 46</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
algesco: <entryFree id="n1814" type="main" key="algesco"><orth extent="full" lang="la">algesco</orth>, <itype>alsi, 3</itype>, <sense id="n1814.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">v. inch. n.</hi> [algeo]. </sense><sense id="n1814.1" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">To catch cold</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">ne ille alserit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,006:1:1:11" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Ad. 1, 1, 11</bibl></cit> (cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">frigus colligere,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Hor.</author> Ep. 1, 11, 13</bibl></cit>, and perfrigescere, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1276,001:7:194" default="NO"><author>Juv.</author> 7, 194</bibl>).—</sense><sense id="n1814.2" n="2" level="3"> Post-Aug. (cf. algens) of things, <hi rend="ital">to become cold</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">(vites) aegrotant et, cum alsere, laesis uredine attonsarum oculis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:17:226" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 17, 24, 37, § 226</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">rabies flammarum,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Prud.</author> Apoth. 142</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
algidensis: <entryFree id="n1815" type="hapax" key="Algi^densis"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Algĭdensis</orth>, <itype>e</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>2. Algidus</etym>, <sense id="n1815.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">growing upon Mount Algidus</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:19:81" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 19, 5, 26, § 81</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
algidum: <entryFree id="n1816" type="main" key="Algi^dum"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Algĭdum</orth>, v. Algidus.</entryFree>
algidus: <entryFree id="n1817" type="main" key="algi^dus1" n="1"><orth extent="full" lang="la">algĭdus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>algeo</etym>, <sense id="n1817.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">cold</hi>: algida, sc. regio, Naev. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,040:45:152" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Or. 45, 152</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">loca,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0472,001:63:70" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cat.</author> 63, 70</bibl></cit>.—Whence,</sense></entryFree>

<entryFree id="n1818" type="main" key="Algi^dus2" n="2"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Algĭdus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <sense id="n1818.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a high snow-capped mountain</hi>, <hi rend="ital">and the forest upon it</hi>, <hi rend="ital">south-east of Rome</hi>, <hi rend="ital">between Tusculum and Velitrœ</hi>, now <hi rend="ital">Monte Compatri</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:26:9:12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 26, 9, 12</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:18:130" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 18, 13, 34, § 130</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">gelidus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:1:21:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 1, 21, 6</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">nivalis,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 3, 23, 9</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,002:69" default="NO"><author>id.</author> C. S. 69</bibl>.—Hence, </sense><sense id="n1818.1" n="I" level="1"> <orth extent="full" lang="la">Algĭdum</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>n.</gen>, <hi rend="ital">a town upon it</hi>, now <hi rend="ital">Pava</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1242,001:1:11" default="NO"><author>Flor.</author> 1, 11</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n1818.2" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Adj.</hi>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">Algĭdus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <hi rend="ital">pertaining to Algidum</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">terra,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,007:6:722" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> F. 6, 722</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">secessus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1294,001:10:30" default="NO"><author>Mart.</author> 10, 30</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
algificus: <entryFree id="n1819" type="hapax" key="algi^fi^cus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">algĭfĭcus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>algus-facio</etym>, <sense id="n1819.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">that makes cold</hi>, <hi rend="ital">chilling</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">quod timor omnis sit algificus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:19:4" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 19, 4</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
algor: <entryFree id="n1820" type="main" key="algor"><orth extent="full" lang="la">algor</orth>, <itype>ōris</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <etym>cf. algeo</etym>, <sense id="n1820.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">cold</hi> (that is felt), <hi rend="ital">coldness</hi> (class., for the ante-class. algus or algu; acc. to <bibl default="NO"><author>Charis.</author> 23</bibl> P., even in Cic.), <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,017:1:3:33" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Rud. 1, 3, 33</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">Prodit hiemps, sequitur crepitans hanc dentibus algor,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:5:746" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 5, 746</bibl></cit> Lachm.: <cit><quote lang="la">obest praegnantibus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:R. R. 2:7:10" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> R. R. 2, 7, 10</bibl></cit>: corpus patiens inediae, vigiliae, algoris, * <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:C. 5:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> C. 5, 3</bibl> (cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,013:1:10:20" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Cat. 1, 10, 20</bibl>: illam praeclaram tuam patientiam famis, frigoris, inopiae rerum omnium): confectus algore, * <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,004:3:22" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> H. 3, 22</bibl>. In Pliny for <hi rend="ital">cold</hi> in gen. (even in the <number>plur.</number>): <cit><quote lang="la">vites algore intereunt,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:17:217" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 17, 24, 37, § 217</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:8:139" default="NO" valid="yes">8, 39, 59, § 139</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">corpus contra algores munire,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:15:19" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 15, 4, 5, § 19</bibl></cit>. <cb n="ALIB" /></sense></entryFree>
algosus: <entryFree id="n1821" type="main" key="algo_sus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">algōsus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>alga</etym>, <sense id="n1821.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">abounding in sea-weed</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">vivunt in algosis, sc. locis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:32:95" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 32, 9, 31, § 95</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">litus,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Aus.</author> Ep. 7, 42</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
algus: <entryFree id="n1822" type="main" key="algus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">algus</orth>, <itype>ūs</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, acc. to <bibl default="NO"><author>Prisc.</author> p. 699</bibl> P.; Rudd. I. p. 122, or <orth extent="full" lang="la">algu</orth>, <gen>n.</gen>, acc. to <bibl default="NO"><author>Charis.</author> 23</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">98</bibl> P.; cf. Schne<bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Gr. 2, 342 sq.</bibl> [algeo], <sense id="n1822.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the feeling of cold</hi> (subjective), <hi rend="ital">coldness</hi> (usu. only in the <case>abl.</case>; hence the form of the <case>nom.</case> is uncertain; ante-class. for the class. algor). </sense><sense id="n1822.1" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Masc.</hi>: algum, famem, Plaut. Fragm. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Prisc.</author> p. 699</bibl> P.—</sense><sense id="n1822.2" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Unc. gen.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">interficere aliquem fame atque algu,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,013:1:3:36" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Most. 1, 3, 36</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">perire algu,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,017:2:7:24" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Rud. 2, 7, 24</bibl></cit>; Att. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> 72, 9</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0043,001:ib. 72:9" default="NO"><author>Lucil.</author> ib. 72, 9</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:3:732" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 3, 732</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
alia: <entryFree id="n1823" type="main" key="a^li^a_"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ălĭā</orth>, <pos>adv.</pos>, v. <itype>alius</itype>, <pos>adv.</pos> B.</entryFree>
aliacmon: <entryFree id="n1824" type="main" key="A^li^acmon"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ălĭacmon</orth>, v. Haliacmon.</entryFree>
alias: <entryFree id="n1825" type="main" key="a^li^as"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ălĭas</orth>, <pos>adv.</pos>, v. <itype>alius</itype>, <pos>adv.</pos> C.</entryFree>
alibi: <entryFree id="n1826" type="main" key="a^li^bi_"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ălĭbī</orth>, <pos>adv.</pos> <etym>contr. from aliubi; aliusibi</etym>, <sense id="n1826.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">elsewhere.</hi> </sense><sense id="n1826.1" n="I.A." level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Elsewhere</hi>, <hi rend="ital">otherwhere</hi>, <hi rend="ital">somewhere else</hi>, <hi rend="ital">in</hi> or <hi rend="ital">at another place</hi>, = alio loco, <foreign lang="greek">a)/lloqi</foreign> (very freq. in the post-Aug. per., esp. in Pliny; in Cic. only twice, and then in connection with nusquam and nec usquam. Never in Hor. or Juv.; in the other poets rare): <hi rend="ital">St.</hi> Hiccine nos habitare censes? <hi rend="ital">Ch.</hi> Ubinam ego alibi censeam? <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,019:4:3:72" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Trin. 4, 3, 72</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">scio equidem alibi jam animum tuum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,020:4:4:13" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Truc. 4, 4, 13</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">alibi gentium et civitatum,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>App.</author> Flor. p. 356, 6</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 360, 4</bibl>.—Hence, </sense><sense id="n1826.2" n="B" level="2"> Esp. </sense><sense id="n1826.3" n="1" level="3"> Alibi ... alibi (even several times), <hi rend="ital">in one place ... in another; here ... there</hi> = hic ... illic; <cit><quote lang="la">hence also sometimes hic or illic ... alibi: alibi pavorem, alibi gaudium ingens facit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:3:18" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 3, 18</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:8:32" default="NO" valid="yes">8, 32</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Ep. 98 al" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Ep. 98 al.</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">exercitus, trifariam dissipatus, alibi primum, alibi postremum agmen, alibi impedimenta, inter vepres delituit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:38:46" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 38, 46</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:2:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 2, 3, 3, § 8</bibl>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:5:99 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 5, 27, 27, § 99 al.</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">hic segetes, illic veniunt felicius uvae, Arborei fetus alibi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,002:1:54" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> G. 1, 54</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:10:146" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 10, 50, 71, § 146</bibl>. Once alibi ... deinde, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0860,001:7:4:26" default="NO"><author>Curt.</author> 7, 4, 26</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n1826.4" n="2" level="3"> Joined with words of the same origin (alius; v. alius, aliter, etc.): alibi alius or aliter, <hi rend="ital">one here</hi>, <hi rend="ital">another there; one in this</hi>, <hi rend="ital">the other in that manner</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">esse alios alibi congressus materiaï, Qualis hic est,</quote> <trans><tr>that matter has elsewhere other combinations</tr>, <tr>similar to that of the world</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:3:1065" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 3, 1065</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">exprobrantes suam quisque alius alibi militiam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:2:23" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 2, 23</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">pecora diversos alium alibi pascere jubet,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:9:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 9, 2</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:44:33" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 44, 33</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">alius alibi projectus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,033:18:18" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Sap. 18, 18</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">medium spatium torrentis, alibi aliter cavati,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:44:35" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 44, 35</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n1826.5" n="3" level="3"> Alibi atque alibi, <hi rend="ital">at one time here</hi>, <hi rend="ital">at another there; now here</hi>, <hi rend="ital">now there</hi> (cf. aliubi, B.): <cit><quote lang="la">haec (aqua) alibi atque alibi utilior nobilitavit loca gloriā ferri,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:34:144" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 34, 14, 41, § 144</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n1826.6" n="4" level="3"> With negatives, <hi rend="ital">nec</hi>, <hi rend="ital">non</hi>, <hi rend="ital">nusquam</hi>, <hi rend="ital">nec usquam</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">nec tam praesentes alibi cognoscere divos,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,001:1:42" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> E. 1, 42</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">asperrima in hac parte dimicatio est, nec alibi dixeris magis mucrone pugnari,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:6:4:4" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 6, 4, 4</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">nusquam alibi,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Ac. 2, 32, 103</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">omnis armatorum copia dextrā sinistrā ad equum, nec usquam alibi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:13:52" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Att. 13, 52</bibl></cit>. And instead of a negative, an interrogation implying it: <cit><quote lang="la">num alibi quam in Capitolio?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:5:52" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 5, 52</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n1826.7" n="5" level="3"> Alibi quam, indicating comparison, <hi rend="ital">elsewhere than</hi>, commonly with a neg., <hi rend="ital">non</hi>, <hi rend="ital">nusquam</hi>, etc., <hi rend="ital">nowhere else than</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">qui et alibi quam in Nilo nascitur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:32:125" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 32, 10, 43, § 125</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">posse principem alibi quam Romae fieri,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,004:1:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> H. 1, 4</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:15:20" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> A. 15, 20</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">faciliusque laudes vestras alibi gentium quam apud vos praedicārim,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>App.</author> Flor. p. 360, 4</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">nusquam alibi quam in Macedoniā,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:43:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 43, 9</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ne alibi quam in armis animum haberent,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:10:20" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 10, 20</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:1:77" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 1, 77</bibl>: nec alibi quam in Germaniā, * <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=aug.:23" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Aug. 23</bibl>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:R. R. 8:11:8" default="NO"><author>Col.</author> R. R. 8, 11, 8</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n1826.8" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Transf.</usg> from place to other objects. </sense><sense id="n1826.9" n="A" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">Otherwise</hi>, <hi rend="ital">in something else</hi>, <hi rend="ital">in other things</hi>, <hi rend="ital">in other respects</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">si alibi plus perdiderim, minus aegre habeam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,004:5:1:16" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Bacch. 5, 1, 16</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">neque istic neque alibi tibi erit usquam in me mora,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,001:2:5:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> And. 2, 5, 9</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,002:2:3:38" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Heaut. 2, 3, 38</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">nec spem salutis alibi quam in pace,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:30:35:11" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 30, 35, 11</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">alibi quam in innocentiā spem habere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:7:41" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 7, 41</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">alibi quam mos permiserit,</quote> <trans><tr>otherwise</tr>, <tr>in other things</tr>, <tr>than custom allows</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:11:1:47" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 11, 1, 47</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:4:1:53" default="NO">4, 1, 53</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n1826.10" n="B" level="2"> Of persons, <hi rend="ital">elsewhere</hi>, <hi rend="ital">with some other one</hi> (very rare): <cit><quote lang="la">priusquam hanc uxorem duxi, habebam alibi (sc. apud meretricem) animum amori deditum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,005:3:1:14" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Hec. 3, 1, 14</bibl></cit>: Quantum militum transportatum sit, apud auctores discrepat: alibi decem milia peditum, duo milia ducentos<pb n="84" /> <cb n="ALID" />  equites, alibi parte plus dimidiā rem auctam invenio, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:29:25" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 29, 25</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">interdum alibi est hereditas, alibi tutela,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:26:4:1" default="NO"><author>Dig.</author> 26, 4, 1</bibl></cit>; so, in designating <hi rend="ital">another place in an author</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:4:2:110" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 4, 2, 110</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:8:3:21 al" default="NO">8, 3, 21 al.</bibl>—</sense><sense id="n1826.11" n="C" level="2"> In post-Aug. prose sometimes, like alias (v. that word), for alioqui, <hi rend="ital">otherwise</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">rhinocerotes quoque, rarum alibi animal, in iisdem montibus erant,</quote> <trans><tr>an animal otherwise rare</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0860,001:9:1:5" default="NO"><author>Curt.</author> 9, 1, 5</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">nemus opacum arboribus alibi inusitatis,</quote> <trans><tr>with trees else rare</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0860,001:9:1:13" default="NO"><author>id.</author> 9, 1, 13</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
alibilis: <entryFree id="n1827" type="main" key="a^li^bi^lis"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ălĭbĭlis</orth>, <itype>e</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>alo</etym>, <sense id="n1827.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">affording nourishment</hi>, <hi rend="ital">nutrilious</hi>, <hi rend="ital">nourishing</hi> (perh. only in Varr.): <cit><quote lang="la">lac,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:R. R. 2:11:2" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> R. R. 2, 11, 2</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">casei,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:ib. 2:11:2" default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 2, 11, 2</bibl></cit>, § 3.—<hi rend="ital">Pass.</hi> of that which readily grows or fattens: <cit><quote lang="la">ita pulli alibiliores fiunt,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:R. R. 3:9" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> R. R. 3, 9</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
alica: <entryFree id="n1828" type="main" key="a^li^ca"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ălĭca</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>from alo, acc. to Paul. ex <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=7" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 7</bibl> Müll.; akin to <foreign lang="greek">a)le/w, o)lai/</foreign> acc. to Doed.</etym>, orig. <pos>adj.</pos>, <sense id="n1828.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">nourishing</hi>, sc. farina. </sense><sense id="n1828.1" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">A kind of grain</hi>, <hi rend="ital">spelt</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Cato</author>, R. R. 76 <hi rend="ital">init.</hi></bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:18:50" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 18, 7, 10, § 50</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n1828.2" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Grits prepared from it</hi>, <hi rend="ital">spelt-grits</hi>, Gr. <foreign lang="greek">xo/ndros</foreign>, later <foreign lang="greek">a)/lic</foreign>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0836,001:6:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cels.</author> 6, 6</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:22:128" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 22, 25, 61, § 128</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n1828.3" n="III" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">A drink prepared from these grits</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1294,001:13:6" default="NO"><author>Mart.</author> 13, 6</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
alicarius: <entryFree id="n1829" type="main" key="a^li^ca_ri^us"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ălĭcārĭus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>alica</etym>, <sense id="n1829.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">of</hi> or <hi rend="ital">pertaining to spelt;</hi> hence, <orth extent="full" lang="la">ălĭcārĭus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <hi rend="ital">one who grinds spelt</hi>: nemo est alicarius posterior te, Lucil. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Charis.</author> p. 75</bibl> P.; and <orth extent="full" lang="la">ălĭcārĭa</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, <hi rend="ital">a prostitute</hi> (as frequenting the place of the spelt-mills): <cit><quote lang="la">alicariae meretrices appellabantur in Campaniā (where the best spelt-grits were prepared,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:18:109" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 18, 11, 29, § 109</bibl></cit>), Paul. ex <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=7" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 7</bibl> Müll.: pistorum amicas, reliquas alicarias, * <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,015:1:2:54" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Poen. 1, 2, 54</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
alicastrum: <entryFree id="n1830" type="hapax" key="a^li^castrum"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ălĭcastrum</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>n.</gen>, sc. frumentum [id.], <sense id="n1830.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a kind of spelt</hi>, <hi rend="ital">summer-spelt</hi> (i. e. sown in the spring), <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:2:6" default="NO"><author>Col.</author> 2, 6</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:2:9" default="NO">2, 9</bibl>; cf. <bibl default="NO"><author>Isid.</author> Aug. 17, 3</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
alicubi: <entryFree id="n1831" type="main" key="a^li^cu^bi"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ălĭcŭbi</orth> (earlier written <orth extent="full" lang="la">ălĭquobi</orth>, like <sense id="n1831.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">neutrobi</hi>, acc. to <bibl default="NO"><author>Cassiod.</author> Orth. 2314</bibl> P.; cf. Schne<bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Gr. 1, 29</bibl>), <pos>adv.</pos> <etym>aliquis-ubi</etym>, <hi rend="ital">somewhere</hi>, <hi rend="ital">anywhere</hi>, <hi rend="ital">at any place</hi>, or <hi rend="ital">in any thing</hi> (Inter alicubi et usquam hoc interest, quod alicubi absolute profertur, ut alicubi fuimus, i. e. in aliquo loco; <cit><quote lang="la">usquam autem ad omnia loca refertur,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Prisc.</author> p. 1058</bibl></cit> P.; very rare): si salvus sit Pompeius et constiterit alicubi, hanc <foreign lang="greek">vekui/an</foreign> relinquas, Att. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:9:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 9, 10</bibl>. </sense><sense id="n1831.1" n="I" level="1"> In gen.: tu si alicubi fueris, dices hic porcos coctos ambulare, <hi rend="ital">if you shall be anywhere</hi>, i. e. <hi rend="ital">wherever you may be</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Petr.</author> 45</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n1831.2" n="II" level="1"> Esp. </sense><sense id="n1831.3" n="A" level="2"> Alicubi ... alicubi, repeated, <hi rend="ital">in one place ... in another</hi>, <hi rend="ital">here ... there</hi>, like alius, alias, alibi, etc.: <cit><quote lang="la">ut alicubi obstes tibi, alicubi irascaris, alicubi instes gravius,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Tranq. 2:2" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Tranq. 2, 2</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">tecta alicubi imposita montibus, alicubi ex plano in altitudinem montium educta,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Ep. 89:21" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Ep. 89, 21</bibl></cit> (in both passages some read <hi rend="ital">aliubi;</hi> v. Fickert).—</sense><sense id="n1831.4" n="B" level="2"> Strengthened by other definite words: <cit><quote lang="la">utinam hic prope adesset alicubi,</quote> <trans><tr>somewhere here</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,006:3:4:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Ad. 3, 4, 7</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">hic alicubi in Crustumenio,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Fl. 29, 71</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">in quibus (scriptis) et suum alicubi reperiri nomen,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,004:7" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Gram. 7</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
alicula: <entryFree id="n1832" type="main" key="a_li^cu^la"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ālĭcŭla</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>ala</etym>, <sense id="n1832.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a light upper garment</hi> (quod alas nobis injecta contineat, Vel. Long. 2230 P., but better acc. to Ferrar. de Re Vest. 2, 3, c. 1, from the collar or cape upon it), * <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1294,001:12:82" default="NO"><author>Mart.</author> 12, 82</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">aliculā subornatus polymitā,</quote> <trans><tr>a light hunting-dress</tr>,</trans> <bibl default="NO"><author>Petr.</author> 40, 5</bibl></cit>; <hi rend="ital">a child's coat</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:34:2:24" default="NO"><author>Dig.</author> 34, 2, 24</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
alicunde: <entryFree id="n1833" type="main" key="a^li^cunde"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ălĭcunde</orth>, <pos>adv.</pos>, of place [aliquis-unde], <sense id="n1833.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">from somewhere</hi> = ab aliquo loco, Gr. <foreign lang="greek">a)mo/qen</foreign>. </sense><sense id="n1833.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">tu mihi aliquid aliquo modo alicunde ab aliquibus blatis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,009:3:1:13" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Ep. 3, 1, 13</bibl></cit>; cf. verse 10: venit meditatus alicunde ex solo loco, Ter And. 2, 4, 3: aliunde fluens alicunde extrinsecus aër, <hi rend="ital">streaming from some part from another source</hi>, * <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:5:522" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 5, 522</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">praecipitare alicunde,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,048:5:11:31" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Fin. 5, 11, 31</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,008:16:46" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Caecin. 16, 46</bibl>. —</sense><sense id="n1833.2" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Transf.</usg> </sense><sense id="n1833.3" n="A" level="2"> Of persons: <cit><quote lang="la">alicunde exora mutuum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,014:1:1:44" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Pers. 1, 1, 44</bibl></cit>: non quaesivit procul alicunde. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:20:48" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Verr. 2, 20, 48</bibl>.—Hence, alicunde corradere, <hi rend="ital">to scrape together from some source</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,006:2:2:34" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Ad. 2, 2, 34</bibl>, and alicunde sumere, <hi rend="ital">to get from somebody</hi>, i. e. <hi rend="ital">to borrow from some one</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,004:2:1:70" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Phorm. 2, 1, 70</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n1833.4" n="B" level="2"> Of things: <cit><quote lang="la">nos omnes, quibus est alicunde aliquis objectuslabor,</quote> <trans><tr>from any thing</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,005:3:1:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Hec. 3, 1, 6</bibl></cit>. (In <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:10:1:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 10, 1, 3</bibl>, B. and K. read <hi rend="ital">aliunde</hi> for <hi rend="ital">alicunde.</hi>）</sense></entryFree>
alid: <entryFree id="n1834" type="main" key="a^lid"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ălid</orth> for <orth extent="full" lang="la">aliud</orth>, v. 2. alius <sense id="n1834.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">init.</hi> <cb n="ALIE" /></sense></entryFree>
alidensis: <entryFree id="n1835" type="hapax" key="A^li^densis"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ălĭdensis</orth>, <itype>e</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos>, <sense id="n1835.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">of</hi> or <hi rend="ital">pertaining to Alida</hi> or <hi rend="ital">Alinda</hi>, <hi rend="ital">a town in Caria</hi>, <hi rend="ital">where splendid garments were manufactured;</hi> hence, <orth extent="full" lang="la">ălĭdense</orth> (sc. vestimentum), <hi rend="ital">a full dress</hi>, <hi rend="ital">court-dress</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:4:1130" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 4, 1130</bibl>; where Lachmann read <hi rend="ital">alidensia</hi>, a word not elsewhere found in Latin or Greek, and Munro now reads <hi rend="ital">indusia;</hi> v. indusium.</sense></entryFree>
alienatio: <entryFree id="n1836" type="main" key="a^li^e_na_ti^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ălĭēnātĭo</orth>, <itype>ōnis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>alieno</etym>. <sense id="n1836.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Act.</hi>, <hi rend="ital">the transferring of the possession of a thing to another</hi>, <hi rend="ital">so as to make it his property</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Alienatio tum fit, cum dominium ad alium transferimus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:18:1:67" default="NO"><author>Dig.</author> 18, 1, 67</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Ben. 5:10" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Ben. 5, 10</bibl>. So, alienatio sacrorum, <hi rend="ital">a transfer of the sacred rites</hi> (sacra) <hi rend="ital">of one family</hi> (gens) <hi rend="ital">to another</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,040:42:144" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Or. 42, 144</bibl>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,044:3:20:48" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Leg. 3, 20, 48</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n1836.1" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Neutr.</hi>, <hi rend="ital">the transferring of one's self</hi>, i. e. <hi rend="ital">the going over to another;</hi> hence, </sense><sense id="n1836.2" n="A" level="2"> <usg type="style">Trop.</usg>, <hi rend="ital">a separation</hi>, <hi rend="ital">desertion</hi>, <hi rend="ital">aversion</hi>, <hi rend="ital">dislike</hi>, <hi rend="ital">alienation</hi> (the internal separating or withdrawing of the feeling of good-will, friendship, and the like; while <hi rend="ital">disjunctio</hi> designates merely an external separation): <cit><quote lang="la">tuam a me alienationem commendationem tibi ad impios cives fore,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,035:chapter=2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Phil. 2</bibl></cit>. 1: <cit><quote lang="la">alienatio consulum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,058:1:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Q. Fr. 1, 4</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">alienatio disjunctioque amicitiae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,052:21:76" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Lael. 21, 76</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">alienatio exercitūs (opp. benevolentia),</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,002:2:31" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. C. 2, 31</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">in Vitellium alienatio,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,004:2:60" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> H. 2, 60</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">alienatio patrui,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:2:43" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> A. 2, 43</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Numquid non perditio est iniquo, et alienatio operantibus injustitiam,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Vulg.</author> Job, 31, 3</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n1836.3" n="B" level="2"> In medic. lang.: <cit><quote lang="la">alienatio mentis,</quote> <trans><tr>aberration of mind</tr>, <tr>loss of reason</tr>, <tr>delirium</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0836,001:4:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cels.</author> 4, 2</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:21:155" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 21, 21, 89, § 155</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">continua,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:1:18:14" default="NO"><author>Dig.</author> 1, 18, 14</bibl></cit>; also without <hi rend="ital">mentis</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">alienatio saporque,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Ep. 78" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Ep. 78</bibl></cit>: alienationis in commoda, Firm. 4, 1.</sense></entryFree>
alienigena: <entryFree id="n1837" type="main" key="a^li^e_ni^ge^na"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ălĭēnĭgĕna</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> (also, <orth extent="full" lang="la">ălĭēnĭgĕ-nus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos>; cf. <bibl default="NO"><author>Prisc.</author> p. 677</bibl> P., and advena) [alienus-gigno], <sense id="n1837.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">born in a foreign land;</hi> hence, </sense><sense id="n1837.1" n="I" level="1"> In gen., <hi rend="ital">foreign</hi>, <hi rend="ital">alien;</hi> and <hi rend="ital">subst.</hi>, <hi rend="ital">a stranger</hi>, <hi rend="ital">a foreigner</hi>, <hi rend="ital">an alien.</hi> </sense><sense id="n1837.2" n="A" level="2"> Of persons (very freq. in Cic., esp. in his orations): <cit><quote lang="la">homo longinquus et alienigena,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,034:chapter=3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Deiot. 3</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">alienigenae hostes,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,013:4:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Cat. 4, 10</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:26:13" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 26, 13</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">testes,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,007:chapter=10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Font. 10</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">dii,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,044:2:10" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Leg. 2, 10</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">mulieres,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,013:11:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> 3 Reg. 11, 1</bibl></cit>.—<hi rend="ital">Subst.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">quid alienigenae de vobis loqui soleant,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Fl. 27</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">si ipse alienigena summi imperii potiretur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,018:7:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Eum. 7, 1</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0860,001:5:11" default="NO"><author>Curt.</author> 5, 11</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0860,001:6:3" default="NO">6, 3</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,003:22:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Lev. 22, 10</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,003:17:18" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> Luc. 17, 18</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n1837.3" n="B" level="2"> Of things: <cit><quote lang="la">vino alienigenā utere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:2:24" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 2, 24</bibl></cit>; and with the <pos>adj.</pos> form: <orth extent="full" lang="la">ălĭēnĭgĕnus</orth>, <itype>a</itype>, um: <cit><quote lang="la">pisces alienigeni,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:8:16:9" default="NO"><author>Col.</author> 8, 16, 9</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">fetus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:8:5:10" default="NO"><author>id.</author> 8, 5, 10</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">semina,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:3:4:1" default="NO"><author>id.</author> 3, 4, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ALIENIGENVM CORPVS,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Inscr. Orell.</author> 5048</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ne alienigenae justitiae obliti videamur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1038,001:6:5:1" default="NO"><author>Val. Max.</author> 6, 5, 1</bibl></cit> <hi rend="ital">ext.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">exempla,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1038,001:1:5:1" default="NO"><author>id.</author> 1, 5, 1</bibl></cit> <hi rend="ital">ext.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">studia,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1038,001:2:1" default="NO"><author>id.</author> 2, 1 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">sanguis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1038,001:6:2:1" default="NO"><author>id.</author> 6, 2, 1</bibl></cit> <hi rend="ital">ext.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">conversationis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,024:4:13" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> 2 Macc. 4, 13</bibl></cit>.— </sense><sense id="n1837.4" n="II" level="1"> In Lucr., <hi rend="ital">produced from different materials</hi>, <hi rend="ital">heterogeneous</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">scire licet nobis venas et sanguen et ossa [et nervos alienigenis ex partibus esse],</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:1:860" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 1, 860</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:1:865" default="NO" valid="yes">1, 865</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:1:869" default="NO" valid="yes">1, 869</bibl>; 1, 874; 5, 880.</sense></entryFree>
alienigenus: <entryFree id="n1838" type="main" key="a^li^e_ni^ge^nus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ălĭēnĭgĕnus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <sense id="n1838.0" n="I" level="1"><xr><lbl>v.</lbl> <ref type="sym" targOrder="U">the preced.</ref></xr></sense></entryFree>
alieniloquium: <entryFree id="n1839" type="main" key="a^li^e_ni^lo^qui^um"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ălĭēnĭlŏquĭum</orth>, <itype>ii</itype>, <gen>n.</gen> <etym>alienus-loqui</etym>, <sense id="n1839.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the talk of crazy persons</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:Sent. Mor. p. 28" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> Sent. Mor. p. 28</bibl> Devit.; cf.: aliena loqui s. v. alienus, B.</sense></entryFree>
alienitas: <entryFree id="n1840" type="main" key="a^li^e_ni^tas"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ălĭēnĭtas</orth>, <itype>ātis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>alienus</etym>. In medic. lang., <sense id="n1840.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">The causes</hi> or <hi rend="ital">materials of disease in the human system</hi>, <hi rend="ital">which are extraneous to it</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">auferre alienitatem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2305,001:Tard. 5:4" default="NO"><author>Cael. Aur.</author> Tard. 5, 4</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">alienitatis obtrusio,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2305,001:ib. 5:64" default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 5, 64</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">manens alienitas,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2305,001:Acut. 3:20" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Acut. 3, 20</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n1840.1" n="II" level="1"> For alienatio (q. v. B.): <cit><quote lang="la">mentis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2305,001:Acut. 2:39" default="NO"><author>Cael. Aur.</author> Acut. 2, 39</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
alieno: <entryFree id="n1841" type="main" key="a^li^e_no"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ălĭēno</orth>, <itype>āvi, ātum, 1</itype>, <pos>v. a.</pos> <etym>id.</etym> (purely prosaic, but class.). <sense id="n1841.0" n="I" level="1"> Orig., <hi rend="ital">to make one person</hi> or <hi rend="ital">thing another</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">facere, ut aliquis alius sit. Thus, in Plaut., Sosia says to Mercury, who represented himself as Sosia: certe edepol tu me alienabis numquam, quin noster siem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,001:1:1:243" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Am. 1, 1, 243</bibl></cit>. So also Pliny: <cit><quote lang="la">sacopenium, quod apud nos gignitur, in totum transmarino alienatur,</quote> <trans><tr>is entirely other than</tr>, <tr>different from</tr>, <tr>the transmarine one</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:20:197" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 20, 18, 75, § 197</bibl></cit>.—Hence, of things, a t. t. in the Roman lang. of business, <hi rend="ital">to make something the property of another</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to alienate</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to transfer by sale</hi> (in the jurid. sense, diff. from <hi rend="ital">vendere: Alienatum</hi> non proprie dicitur, quod adhuc in dominio venditoris manet? <hi rend="ital">venditum</hi> tamen recte dicetur, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:50:16:67" default="NO"><author>Dig.</author> 50, 16, 67</bibl>; the former, therefore, includes the idea of a complete <cb n="ALIE" /> transfer of the thing sold): <cit><quote lang="la">pretio parvo ea, quae accepissent a majoribus, vendidisse atque alienāsse,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:4:60" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Verr. 2, 4, 60</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">venire vestras res proprias atque in perpetuum a vobis alienari,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,011:2:21:54" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Agr. 2, 21, 54</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">vectigalia (opp. frui),</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 2, 13, 33</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:R. R. 2:1" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> R. R. 2, 1</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:4:7:4" default="NO"><author>Dig.</author> 4, 7, 4</bibl>.—Esp., <hi rend="ital">to remove</hi>, <hi rend="ital">separate</hi>, <hi rend="ital">make foreign</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">urbs maxuma alienata,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:J. 48:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> J. 48, 1</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n1841.1" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Transf.</usg> to mental objects, and with esp. reference to that from which any person or thing is separated or removed, <hi rend="ital">to cast off</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to alienate</hi>, <hi rend="ital">estrange</hi>, <hi rend="ital">set at variance</hi>, <hi rend="ital">render averse</hi>, <hi rend="ital">make enemies</hi> (<hi rend="ital">Abalienatus</hi> dicitur, quem quis a se removerit; <hi rend="ital">alienatus</hi>, qui alienus est factus, Paul. ex <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=25" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 25</bibl> Müll.; class., esp. freq. in the <hi rend="ital">part.</hi> alienatus). </sense><sense id="n1841.2" n="A" level="2"> In gen.: <cit><quote lang="la">eum omnibus eadem res publica reconciliavit, quae alienārat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,025:chapter=9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Prov. Cons. 9</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">legati alienati,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,027:chapter=96" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Pis. 96</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">alienati sunt peccatores,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,027:51:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Psa. 51, 4</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO"><author>ib.</author> Col. 1, 21</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">alienari a Senatu,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:1:14" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 1, 14</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">studium ab aliquo,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,027:chapter=76" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Pis. 76</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">si alienatus fuerit a me,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,053:14:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Ezech. 14, 7</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">alienati a viā Dei,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,010:4:18" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> Eph. 4, 18</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">voluntatem ab aliquo,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,035:2:38" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Phil. 2, 38</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:3:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Fam. 3, 6</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">tantā contumeliā acceptā omnium suorum voluntates alienare (sc. a se),</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:7:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 7, 10</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">voluntate alienati,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:J. 66:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> J. 66, 2</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,001:Alcib. 5:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Alcib. 5, 1</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">falsā suspitione alienatum esse,</quote> <trans><tr>neglected</tr>, <tr>discarded</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:C. 35:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> C. 35, 3</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">animos eorum alienare a causā,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,025:chapter=21" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Prov. Cons. 21</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">a dictatore animos,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:8:35" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 8, 35</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">sibi animum alicujus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1044,001:2:112" default="NO"><author>Vell.</author> 2, 112</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,004:1:59" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> H. 1, 59</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:1:7:18" default="NO"><author>Just.</author> 1, 7, 18</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n1841.3" n="B" level="2"> Esp. </sense><sense id="n1841.4" n="1" level="3"> Mentem alienare alicui, <hi rend="ital">to take away</hi> or <hi rend="ital">deprive of reason</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to make crazy</hi>, <hi rend="ital">insane</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to drive mad</hi> (not before the Aug. per., perh. first by Livy): <cit><quote lang="la">erat opinio Flaccum minus compotem fuisse sui: vulgo Junonis iram alienāsse mentem ferebant,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:42:28" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 42, 28</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">signum alienatae mentis,</quote> <trans><tr>of insanity</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=aug.:99" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Aug. 99</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">alienata mens,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:Rep. Ord. 2:12:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> Rep.
