Ord. 2, 12, 6</bibl></cit> (cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:25:39" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 25, 39</bibl>: alienatus sensibus).—And <hi rend="ital">absol.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">odor sulfuris saepius haustus alienat,</quote> <trans><tr>deprives of reason</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Q. N. 2:53" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Q. N. 2, 53</bibl></cit>.—Hence, <hi rend="ital">pass.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">alienari mente,</quote> <trans><tr>to be insane</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:28:93" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 28, 8, 27, § 93</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ita alienatus mente Antiochus (erat),</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,024:5:17" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> 2 Macc. 5, 17</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n1841.5" n="2" level="3"> In medic. lang.: alienari, of parts of the body, <hi rend="ital">to die</hi>, <hi rend="ital">perish</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">intestina momento alienantur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0836,001:7:16" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cels.</author> 7, 16</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0836,001:8:10" default="NO" valid="yes">8, 10</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0836,001:5:26" default="NO" valid="yes">5, 26</bibl>, n. 23: <cit><quote lang="la">in corpore alienato,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Ep. 89" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Ep. 89</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">(spodium) alienata explet,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:23:76" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 23, 4, 38, § 76</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n1841.6" n="3" level="3"> Alienari ab aliquā re, <hi rend="ital">to keep at a distance from something</hi>, i. e. <hi rend="ital">to be disinclined to</hi>, <hi rend="ital">have an aversion for</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to avoid</hi> = abhorrere (only in Cic.): <cit><quote lang="la">a falsā assensione magis nos alienatos esse quam a ceteris rebus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,048:3:5:18" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Fin. 3, 5, 18</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">alienari ab interitu iisque rebus, quae interitum videantur afferre,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 3, 5, 16</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
alienus: <entryFree id="n1842" type="main" key="a^li^e_nus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ălĭēnus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype> <etym>2. alius</etym>. <sense id="n1842.0" n="I" level="1"> <pos>Adj.</pos> </sense><sense id="n1842.1" n="A" level="2"> In gen., <hi rend="ital">that belongs to another person</hi>, <hi rend="ital">place</hi>, <hi rend="ital">object</hi>, etc., <hi rend="ital">not one's own</hi>, <hi rend="ital">another's</hi>, <hi rend="ital">of another</hi>, <hi rend="ital">foreign</hi>, <hi rend="ital">alien</hi> (opp. suus): NEVE. ALIENAM. SEGETEM. PELLEXERIS., Fragm. XII. Tab. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:28:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 28, 2</bibl>, and <bibl default="NO"><author>Serv.</author> ad Verg. E. 8, 99</bibl>: plus ex alieno jecore sapiunt quam ex suo, Pac. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,053:1:57" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Div. 1, 57</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,012:2:2:111" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Mil. 2, 2, 111</bibl>; cf. <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 2, 2, 88</bibl>, and Lind. <bibl default="NO"><author>ib.</author> 2, 3, 3</bibl>: quom sciet alienum puerum (<hi rend="ital">the child of another</hi>) tolli pro suo, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,005:4:1:61" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Hec. 4, 1, 61</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">in aedīs inruit Alienas,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,006:1:2:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Ad. 1, 2, 9</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,001:1:1:125" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> And. 1, 1, 125</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">alienae partes anni,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:1:182" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 1, 182</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,002:2:149" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> G. 2, 149</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">pecuniis alienis locupletari,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,002:47:137" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Rosc. Am. 47, 137</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">cura rerum alienarum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:1:9:30" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Off. 1, 9, 30</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">2, 23, 83</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">alienos mores ad suos referre,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,001:Epam. 1:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Epam. 1, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">in altissimo gradu alienis opibus poni,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,022:chapter=20" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Sest. 20</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">semper regibus aliena virtus formidolosa est,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:C. 7:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> C. 7, 2</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">amissis bonis alienas opes exspectare,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:ib. 58" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> ib. 58</bibl></cit>. 10 Herz.: <cit><quote lang="la">aliena mulier,</quote> <trans><tr>another man's wife</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,024:chapter=37" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Cael. 37</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">mulier alieni viri sermonibus assuefacta,</quote> <trans><tr>of another woman's husband</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:1:46" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 1, 46</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">virtutem et bonum alienum oderunt,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:35:43" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 35, 43</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">alienis pedibus ambulamus, alienis oculis agnoscimus, alienā memoriā salutamus, alienā operā vivimus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:29:19" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 29, 1, 8, § 19</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">oportet enim omnia aut ad alienum arbitrium aut ad suum facere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1318,001:6:14" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> Ep. 6, 14</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=cl.:2" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Claud. 2</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">alienum cursum alienumque rectorem, velut captā nave, sequi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1318,002:82:3" default="NO"><author>Plin.</author> Pan. 82, 3</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:15:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 15, 1 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">pudicitiae neque suae neque alienae pepercit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=cal.:36" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Calig. 36</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">epistolas orationesque et edicta alieno formabat ingenio,</quote> <trans>i. e. <tr>caused to be written by another</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=dom.:20" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Dom. 20</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">te conjux aliena capit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,004:2:7:46" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> S. 2, 7, 46</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">1, 1, 110</bibl>; so <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 1, 3, 116</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">vulnus,</quote> <trans><tr>intended for another</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:10:781" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 10, 781</bibl></cit>: aliena <pb n="85" /> <cb n="ALIE" /> cornua, of Actæon transformed into a stag, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:3:139" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 3, 139</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">alieno Marte pugnabant, sc. equites,</quote> <trans>i. e. <tr>without horses</tr>, <tr>as footmen</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:3:62" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 3, 62</bibl></cit>: aes alienum, lit. <hi rend="ital">another's money;</hi> hence, in reference to him who has it, <hi rend="ital">a debt;</hi> cf. aes. So also: <cit><quote lang="la">aliena nomina,</quote> <trans><tr>debts in others' names</tr>, <tr>debts contracted by others</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:C. 35:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> C. 35, 3</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n1842.2" n="B" level="2"> Esp. </sense><sense id="n1842.3" n="1" level="3"> In reference to relationship or friendship, <hi rend="ital">not belonging to one</hi>, <hi rend="ital">alien from</hi>, <hi rend="ital">not related</hi> or <hi rend="ital">allied</hi>, <hi rend="ital">not friendly</hi>, <hi rend="ital">inimical</hi>, <hi rend="ital">strange</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,005:1:2:43" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Capt. 1, 2, 43</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">alienus est ab nostrā familiā,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,006:3:2:28" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Ad. 3, 2, 28</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,002:5:4:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Heaut. 5, 4, 6</bibl> Ruhnk.: <cit><quote lang="la">multi ex finibus suis egressi se suaque omnia alienissimis crediderunt,</quote> <trans><tr>to utter strangers</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:6:31" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 6, 31</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">non alienus sanguine regibus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:29:29" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 29, 29</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1044,001:2:76" default="NO"><author>Vell.</author> 2, 76</bibl>.— <cit><quote lang="la">Hence alienus and propinquus are antith.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,052:5:19" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Lael. 5, 19</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ut neque amicis neque etiam alienioribus desim,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:1:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Fam. 1, 9</bibl></cit> Manut.: <cit><quote lang="la">ut tuum factum alieni hominis, meum vero conjunctissimi et amicissimi esse videatur,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 3, 6</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n1842.4" n="2" level="3"> <usg type="style">Trop.</usg>: alienum esse in or ab aliquā re, <hi rend="ital">to be a stranger to a thing</hi>, i. e. <hi rend="ital">not to be versed in</hi> or <hi rend="ital">familiar with</hi>, <hi rend="ital">not to understand</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">in physicis Epicurus totus est alienus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,048:1:6:17" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Fin. 1, 6, 17</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">homo non alienus a litteris,</quote> <trans><tr>not a stranger to</tr>, <tr>not unversed in</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:2:26" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Verr. 2, 2, 26</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n1842.5" n="3" level="3"> <hi rend="ital">Foreign to a thing</hi>, i. e. <hi rend="ital">not suited to it</hi>, <hi rend="ital">unsuitable</hi>, <hi rend="ital">incongruous</hi>, <hi rend="ital">inadequate</hi>, <hi rend="ital">inconsistent</hi>, <hi rend="ital">unseasonable</hi>, <hi rend="ital">inapposite</hi>, <hi rend="ital">different from</hi> (opp. aptus); constr. with <hi rend="ital">gen.</hi>, <case>dat.</case>, <case>abl.</case>, and <hi rend="ital">ab;</hi> cf. Burm. ad <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,007:1:4" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> F. 1, 4</bibl>; Manut. ad <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:9:14:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 9, 14, 5</bibl>; Spald. ad <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:6:3:33" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 6, 3, 33</bibl>; Zumpt, Gr. § 384. </sense><sense id="n1842.6" n="(a)" level="5"> With <hi rend="ital">gen.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">pacis (deorum),</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:6:69" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 6, 69</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">salutis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:3:832" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 3, 832</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">aliarum rerum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:6:1064" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 6, 1064</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">dignitatis alicujus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,048:1:4:11" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Fin. 1, 4, 11</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">neque aliena consili (sc. domus D. Bruti),</quote> <trans><tr>convenient for consultation</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:C. 40:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> C. 40, 5</bibl></cit> Kritz al.—</sense><sense id="n1842.7" n="(b)" level="5"> With <hi rend="ital">dat.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">quod illi causae maxime est alienum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,008:9:24" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Caecin. 9, 24</bibl></cit>: arti oratoriae, Quint. prooem. 5; 4, 2, 62; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Q. N. 4 praef" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Q. N. 4 praef.</bibl>—</sense><sense id="n1842.8" n="(g)" level="5"> With <case>abl.</case>: <cit><quote lang="la">neque hoc dii alienum ducunt majestate suā,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,053:1:38:83" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Div. 1, 38, 83</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">homine alienissimum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:1:13:41" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Off. 1, 13, 41</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">dignitate imperii,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,025:8:18" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Prov. Cons. 8, 18</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">amicitiā,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:11:27" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Fam. 11, 27</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">existimatione meā,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:6:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Att. 6, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">domus magis his aliena malis,</quote> <trans><tr>farther from</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,004:1:9:50" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> S. 1, 9, 50</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">loco, tempore,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:6:3:33" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 6, 3, 33</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n1842.9" n="(d)" level="5"> With <hi rend="ital">ab</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">alienum a vitā meā,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,006:5:8:21" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Ad. 5, 8, 21</bibl></cit>: a dignitate rei publicae, Tib. Gracch. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:7:19:7" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 7, 19, 7</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">a sapiente,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Ac. 2, 43, 132</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">a dignitate,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:4:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Fam. 4, 7</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">navigationis labor alienus non ab aetate solum nostrā, verum etiam a dignitate,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:16:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Att. 16, 3</bibl></cit>.—（<foreign lang="greek">e</foreign>) With <hi rend="ital">inf.</hi> or <hi rend="ital">clause</hi> as subject: <cit><quote lang="la">nec aptius est quidquam ad opes tuendas quam diligi, nec alienius quam timeri,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:2:7:23" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Off. 2, 7, 23</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">non alienum videtur, quale praemium Miltiadi sit tributum, docere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,001:6:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Milt. 6, 1</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n1842.10" n="4" level="3"> <hi rend="ital">Averse</hi>, <hi rend="ital">hostile</hi>, <hi rend="ital">unfriendly</hi>, <hi rend="ital">unfavorable to</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">illum alieno animo a nobis esse res ipsa indicat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,006:3:2:40" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Ad. 3, 2, 40</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,034:9:24" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Deiot. 9, 24</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">a Pyrrho non nimis alienos animos habemus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,052:chapter=8" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Lael. 8 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">sin a me est alienior,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:2:17" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Fam. 2, 17</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ex alienissimis amicissimos reddere,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 15, 4</bibl></cit> al.: <cit><quote lang="la">Muciani animus nec Vespasiano alienus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,004:2:74" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> H. 2, 74</bibl></cit>.—Rar. transf. to things; as in the histt., alienus locus, <hi rend="ital">a place</hi> or <hi rend="ital">ground unfavorable for an engagement</hi>, <hi rend="ital">disadvantageous</hi> (opp. suus or opportunus; cf. <cit><quote lang="la">Gron. Obs. 4, 17, 275): alieno loco proelium committunt,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:1:15" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 1, 15</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">alienissimo sibi loco contra opportunissimo hostibus conflixit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,002:4:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Them. 4, 5</bibl></cit> Brem.—So of time <hi rend="ital">unfitting</hi>, <hi rend="ital">inconvenient</hi>, <hi rend="ital">unfavorable</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:R. R. 3:16" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> R. R. 3, 16</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">ad judicium corrumpendum tempus alienum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:chapter=5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Verr. 1, 5</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,008:chapter=67" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Caecin. 67</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">vir egregius alienissimo rei publicae tempore exstinctus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,039:chapter=1" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Brut. 1</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:15:14" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Fam. 15, 14</bibl>.—Of other things: alienum (<hi rend="ital">dangerous</hi>, <hi rend="ital">perilous</hi>, <hi rend="ital">hurtful</hi>) suis rationibus, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:C. 56:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> C. 56, 5</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0836,001:4:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cels.</author> 4, 5</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n1842.11" n="5" level="3"> In medic. lang. </sense><sense id="n1842.12" n="a" level="4"> Of the body, <hi rend="ital">dead</hi>, <hi rend="ital">corrupted</hi>, <hi rend="ital">paralyzed</hi> (cf. alieno, II. B. 2.), <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1011,001:Comp. 201" default="NO"><author>Scrib.</author> Comp. 201</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n1842.13" n="b" level="4"> Of the mind, <hi rend="ital">insane</hi>, <hi rend="ital">mad</hi> (cf. alieno and alienatio): <cit><quote lang="la">Neque solum illis aliena mens erat, qui conscii conjurationis fuerant,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:C. 37:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> C. 37, 1</bibl></cit> Herz.—</sense><sense id="n1842.14" n="II" level="1"> <pos>Subst.</pos> </sense><sense id="n1842.15" n="1" level="3"> <orth extent="full" lang="la">ălĭēnus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <hi rend="ital">a stranger.</hi> </sense><sense id="n1842.16" n="a" level="4"> <hi rend="ital">One not belonging to one's house</hi>, <hi rend="ital">family</hi>, or <hi rend="ital">country</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">apud me cenant alieni novem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,018:3:2:21" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Stich. 3, 2, 21</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ut non ejectus ad alienos, sed invitatus ad tuos īsse videaris,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,013:1:9:23" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Cat. 1, 9, 23</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quas copias proximis suppeditari aequius est, eas transferunt ad alienos,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:1:14" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Off. 1, 14</bibl></cit>: cives potiores quam peregrini, <cb n="ALIM" /> propinqui quam alieni, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,052:5:19" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Am. 5, 19</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">quasi ad alienos durius loquebatur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,001:42:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Gen. 42, 7</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">a filiis suis an ab alienis?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,001:17:24" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> Matt. 17, 24</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">cives potiores quam peregrini, propinqui quam alieni,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,052:chapter=5" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Lael. 5</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quod alieno testimonium redderem, in eo non fraudabo avum meum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1044,001:2:76" default="NO"><author>Vell.</author> 2, 76</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n1842.17" n="b" level="4"> <hi rend="ital">One not related to a person</hi> or <hi rend="ital">thing</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">in longinquos, in propinquos, in alienos, in suos irruebat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,031:28:76" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Mil. 28, 76</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">vel alienissimus rusticae vitae, naturae benignitatem miretur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:3:21:3" default="NO"><author>Col.</author> 3, 21, 3</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n1842.18" n="2" level="3"> <orth extent="full" lang="la">ălĭēnum</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>n.</gen>, <hi rend="ital">the property of a stranger</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Haec erunt vilici officia: alieno manum abstineant, etc.,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Cato</author>, R. R. 5, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">alieno abstinuit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=tit.:7" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Tit. 7</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ex alieno largiri,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:3:8:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 3, 8, 8</bibl></cit>; so, <cit><quote lang="la">de alieno largiri,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:36:3:9" default="NO"><author>Just.</author> 36, 3, 9</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">alieni appetens, sui profugus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:C. 5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> C. 5</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:5:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 5, 5</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">in aliena aedificium exstruere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,031:27:74" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Mil. 27, 74</bibl></cit> (cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">in alieno solo aedificare,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:41:1:7" default="NO"><author>Dig.</author> 41, 1, 7</bibl></cit>).—<hi rend="ital">Plur.</hi>, </sense><sense id="n1842.19" n="a" level="4"> <hi rend="ital">The property of a stranger</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">quid est aliud aliis sua eripere, aliis dare aliena?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:2:23" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Off. 2, 23</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:30:30" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 30, 30</bibl>: aliena pervadere, <hi rend="ital">a foreign</hi> (in opp. to the Roman) <hi rend="ital">province</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Amm.</author> 23, 1</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n1842.20" n="b" level="4"> <hi rend="ital">The affairs</hi> or <hi rend="ital">interests of strangers: Men.</hi> Chreme, tantumue ab re tuast oti tibi, aliena ut cures, ea, quae nihil ad te attinent. <hi rend="ital">Chrem.</hi> Homo sum; <cit><quote lang="la">humani nihil a me alienum puto,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,002:1:1:23" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Heaut. 1, 1, 23</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">aliena ut melius videant quam sua,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 3, 1, 95</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n1842.21" n="c" level="4"> <hi rend="ital">Things strange</hi>, <hi rend="ital">foreign</hi>, <hi rend="ital">not belonging to</hi> the matter in hand: <cit><quote lang="la">Quod si hominibus bonarum rerum tanta cura esset, quanto studio aliena ac nihil profutura multumque etiam periculosa petunt, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:J. 1:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> J. 1, 5</bibl></cit>; hence, aliena loqui, <hi rend="ital">to talk strangely</hi>, <hi rend="ital">wildly</hi>, like a crazy person: <cit><quote lang="la">Quin etiam, sic me dicunt aliena locutum, Ut foret amenti nomen in ore tuum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,008:3:19" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> Tr. 3, 19</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">interdum in accessione aegros desipere et aliena loqui,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0836,001:3:18" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cels.</author> 3, 18</bibl></cit> (v. alieniloquium).!*? <hi rend="ital">Comp.</hi> rare, but <hi rend="ital">sup.</hi> very freq.; no <pos>adv.</pos> in use.</sense></entryFree>
aliger: <entryFree id="n1843" type="main" key="a_li^ger"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ālĭger</orth>, <itype>gĕra, gĕrum</itype> (<sense id="n1843.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">gen. plur.</hi> aligerūm, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1035,001:7:171" default="NO"><author>Val. Fl.</author> 7, 171</bibl>), <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>ala-gero</etym>, <hi rend="ital">bearing wings</hi>, <hi rend="ital">winged</hi> (a <usg type="style">poet.</usg> word of the Aug. per.). </sense><sense id="n1843.1" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Adj.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">amor,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:1:663" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 1, 663</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">agmen,</quote> <trans>i. e. <tr>of birds</tr>,</trans> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 12, 249</bibl></cit>: aligero tollitur axe Ceres, <hi rend="ital">upon the winged chariot</hi> (i. e. drawn by dragons), <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,007:4:562" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> F. 4, 562</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">Jovis Nuntius,</quote> <trans>i. e. <tr>Mercury</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1020,002:3:3:80" default="NO"><author>Stat.</author> S. 3, 3, 80</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">genus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Hippol. 338 al" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Hippol. 338 al.</bibl></cit>—In the prose of Pliny, like many other <usg type="style">poet.</usg> words: <cit><quote lang="la">aligeri serpentes,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:12:85" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 12, 19, 42, § 85</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Cupidines,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:36:41" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 36, 5, 4, § 41</bibl></cit>.—*</sense><sense id="n1843.2" n="II" level="1"> <orth extent="full" lang="la">Ālĭgĕri</orth>, <hi rend="ital">subst.</hi>, <hi rend="ital">the winged gods of love</hi>, <hi rend="ital">Cupids</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1345,001:7:458" default="NO"><author>Sil.</author> 7, 458</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
alii: <entryFree id="n1844" type="main" key="Alii"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Alii</orth>, <itype>ōrum</itype>, v. Alis and 1. Alius.</entryFree>
alimentarius: <entryFree id="n1845" type="main" key="a^li^menta_ri^us"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ălĭmentārĭus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>alimentum</etym>, <sense id="n1845.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">pertaining to</hi> or <hi rend="ital">suitable for nourishing</hi> (a legal term; in the class. per. only once; later in the lang. of law and in epitaphs). </sense><sense id="n1845.1" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Adj.</hi>: lex, <hi rend="ital">relating to the apportionment of provisions among the poor</hi>, Cael. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:8:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 8, 6</bibl> Manut.: <cit><quote lang="la">causa,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:2:15:8" default="NO"><author>Dig.</author> 2, 15, 8</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ratio,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:48:13:4" default="NO"><author>ib.</author> 48, 13, 4</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">res,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Amm.</author> 20, 8</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> 21, 12</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n1845.2" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Subst.</hi>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">ălĭmentārĭus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <hi rend="ital">one to whom means of subsistence has been left by will</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:2:15:8 al" default="NO"><author>Dig.</author> 2, 15, 8 al.</bibl></sense></entryFree>
alimentum: <entryFree id="n1846" type="main" key="a^li^mentum"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ălĭmentum</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>n.</gen> <etym>alo</etym>, <sense id="n1846.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">nourishment</hi>, <hi rend="ital">nutriment;</hi> and concr., <hi rend="ital">food</hi>, <hi rend="ital">provisions</hi>, <hi rend="ital">aliment</hi> (in the poets only in the <number>plur.</number>). </sense><sense id="n1846.1" n="I" level="1"> In gen.: <cit><quote lang="la">alimenta corporis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,072:chapter=6" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Univ. 6</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">plus alimenti est in pane quam in ullo alio,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0836,001:2:18" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cels.</author> 2, 18</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0836,001:8:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 8, 1</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:17:13:20" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 17, 13, 20</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">alimenta reponere in hiemem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:2:16:16" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 2, 16, 16</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=tib.:54" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Tib. 54</bibl>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:6:23" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 6, 23</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">alimenta petens,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,001:41:55" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Gen. 41, 55</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">alimenta negare,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> Tr 5, 8, 13</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">habentes alimenta et quibus tegamur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,015:6:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> 1 Tim. 6, 8</bibl></cit>.—In the jurists: <cit><quote lang="la">alimenta,</quote> <trans><tr>all things which pertain to the support of life</tr>, <tr>aliment</tr>, <tr>maintenance</tr>, <tr>support</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:34" default="NO"><author>Dig.</author> 34</bibl></cit>, tit. 1, De alimentis, and 1. 6.— <usg type="style">Poet.</usg> (very freq. in Ovid): <cit><quote lang="la">picem et ceras, alimentaque cetera flammae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:14:532" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 14, 532</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">concipit Iris aquas, alimentaque nubibus affert,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,010:1:271" default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 1, 271</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">lacrimaeque alimenta fuere,</quote> <trans><tr>tears were his food</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,010:10:75" default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 10, 75</bibl></cit> (cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">fuerunt mihi lacrimae meae panes die ac nocte,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,027:41:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Psa. 41, 4</bibl></cit>): <cit><quote lang="la">ignis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:8:837" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 8, 837</bibl></cit>. —<usg type="style">Trop.</usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">vitiorum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:2:769" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 2, 769</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">furoris,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,010:3:479" default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 3, 479</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">addidit alimenta rumoribus,</quote> <trans><tr>gave new support to the rumors</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:35:23" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 35, 23 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">alimentum famae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,004:2:96" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> H. 2, 96</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">alimentum virtutis honos,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1038,001:2:6:5" default="NO"><author>Val. Max.</author> 2, 6, 5</bibl></cit>.— </sense><sense id="n1846.2" n="II" level="1"> Esp., for the Gr. <foreign lang="greek">trofei=a</foreign> or <foreign lang="greek">qre/ptra</foreign>, <hi rend="ital">the reward</hi> or <hi rend="ital">recompense due to parents from children for their rearing</hi>: quasi alimenta exspectarct a nobis (patria), Cic. <cb n="ALIO" /> Rep. 1, 4 Mos. (in <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1035,001:6:570" default="NO"><author>Val. Fl.</author> 6, 570</bibl>, this is expressed by <hi rend="ital">nutrimenta;</hi> in <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:50:13:1:section=14" default="NO"><author>Dig.</author> 50, 13, 1, § 14</bibl>, by <hi rend="ital">nutricia</hi>).</sense></entryFree>
alimodi: <entryFree id="n1847" type="gloss" key="alimo^di"><orth extent="full" lang="la">alimŏdi</orth>: pro alius modi, Paul. ex <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=28" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 28</bibl> Müll.</entryFree>
alimon: <entryFree id="n1848" type="greek" key="a^li^mo^n"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ălĭmŏn</orth>, v. halimon.</entryFree>
alimonia: <entryFree id="n1849" type="main" key="a^li^mo_ni^a"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ălĭmōnĭa</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>alo</etym> (ante- and postclass. for alimentum), <sense id="n1849.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">nourishment</hi>, <hi rend="ital">food</hi>, <hi rend="ital">sustenance</hi>, <hi rend="ital">support</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">quaestus alimoniae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,014:1:2:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Pers. 1, 2, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">naturalis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:17:15:5" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 17, 15, 5</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">flammae,</quote> <trans><tr>fuel</tr>,</trans> <bibl default="NO"><author>Prud.</author> Cath. 5, 19</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO"><author>App.</author> M. 2, p. 115</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">in alimoniam ignis,</quote> <trans><tr>for the food of the burnt-offering</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,003:3:16" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Lev. 3, 16</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,023:14:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> 1 Macc. 14, 10</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
alimonium: <entryFree id="n1850" type="main" key="a^li^mo_ni^um"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ălĭmōnĭum</orth>, <itype>ii</itype>, <gen>n.</gen> <etym>id.; the termination as in testi-monium, parsi-monium, vadimonium</etym> (ante-class. and post-Aug. for the class. alimentum), <sense id="n1850.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">nourishment</hi>, <hi rend="ital">sustenance</hi>, <hi rend="ital">support</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">mellis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:R. R. 3:16:15" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> R. R. 3, 16, 15</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:3:1:8" default="NO">3, 1, 8</bibl> <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi>; 2, 1, 14; <cit><quote lang="la">5, 16: infectus alimonio,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:11:16" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 11, 16</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">collationes in alimonium atque dotem puellae recepit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=cal.:42" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Calig. 42</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quaerere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1276,001:14:76" default="NO"><author>Juv.</author> 14, 76</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">denegare,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:25:3:4" default="NO"><author>Dig.</author> 25, 3, 4</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Arn.</author> 5, p. 167</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
alio: <entryFree id="n1851" type="main" key="a^li^o_"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ălĭō</orth>, <pos>adv.</pos>, v. 2. alius, II. A.</entryFree>
alioqui: <entryFree id="n1852" type="main" key="a^li^o_qui_"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ălĭōquī</orth> (Corssen, Ausspr. II. p. 839, questions the MS. authority for the forms <orth extent="full" lang="la">ălĭ-ōquin</orth> and <orth extent="full" lang="la">cĕtĕrōquin</orth>, <itype>but if they are genuine</itype>, he believes they have the <pos>prep.</pos> in affixed, as in deoin), <pos>adv.</pos> (prop. <case>abl.</case> alioqui, i. e. alio quo modo, <sense id="n1852.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">in some other way;</hi> used in the ante-Aug. per. only once in Lucr.; but freq. after that per., esp. by the histt., and by Pliny the younger). </sense><sense id="n1852.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>, to indicate that something has its existence or right in all but the exception given, <hi rend="ital">in other respects</hi>, <hi rend="ital">for the rest</hi>, <hi rend="ital">otherwise;</hi> Gr. <foreign lang="greek">a)/llws</foreign>, often with <pos>adj.</pos> standing either before or after it: <cit><quote lang="la">milites tantum, qui sequerentur currum, defuerunt: alioqui magnificus triumphus fuit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:37:46" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 37, 46</bibl></cit> Madv.; <cit><quote lang="la">8, 9: Hannibal tumulum tutum commodumque alioqui, nisi quod longinquae aquationis erat, cepit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:30:29:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 30, 29, 10</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">atqui si vitiis mediocribus ac mea paucis Mendosa est natura, alioquin recta,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,004:1:6:66" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> S. 1, 6, 66</bibl></cit> K. and H.: <cit><quote lang="la">solitus alioquin id temporis luxus principis intendere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:13:20" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 13, 20</bibl></cit> Halm; so <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 4, 37</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0860,001:7:4:8" default="NO"><author>Curt.</author> 7, 4, 8</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0860,001:8:2:2" default="NO">8, 2, 2</bibl>.—Sometimes concessive, hence also with <hi rend="ital">quamquam</hi>, <hi rend="ital">quamvis</hi>, <hi rend="ital">cum</hi>, <hi rend="ital">as for the rest</hi>, <hi rend="ital">besides</hi>: triumphatum de Tiburtibus: alioqui mitis victoria fuit, i. e. <hi rend="ital">although in other respects the victory was</hi>, etc., <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:7:19" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 7, 19</bibl>: at si tantula pars oculi media illa peresa est, Incolumis quamvis alioqui splendidus orbis (<hi rend="ital">al though in other respects uninjured and clear</hi>) occidit extemplo lumen, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:3:414" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 3, 414</bibl> (Lachmann rejected this line; Munro receives it and reads <hi rend="ital">alioquoi</hi>): <cit><quote lang="la">ideo nondum eum legi, cum alioqui validissime cupiam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1318,001:9:35" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> Ep. 9, 35</bibl></cit> Keil; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:10:198" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 10, 69, 93, § 198</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n1852.2" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Transf.</usg> </sense><sense id="n1852.3" n="A" level="2"> To indicate that something exists, avails, or has influence in other cases beside those mentioned, <hi rend="ital">yet</hi>, <hi rend="ital">besides</hi>, <hi rend="ital">moreover</hi> (syn.: <cit><quote lang="la">porro, praeterea): sed haec quidem alioquin memoria magni professoris, uti interponeremus, effecit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0836,001:8:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cels.</author> 8, 4</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ne pugnemus igitur, cum praesertim plurimis alioqui Graecis sit utendum,</quote> <trans><tr>very many other Greek words besides</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:2:14:4" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 2, 14, 4</bibl></cit> Halm: <cit><quote lang="la">non tenuit iram Alexander, cujus alioqui potens non erat,</quote> <trans><tr>of which he had not the control at other times</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0860,001:4:2:6" default="NO"><author>Curt.</author> 4, 2, 6</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,004:3:32" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> H. 3, 32</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">quā occasione Caesar, validus alioquin spernendis honoribus hujuscemodi orationem coepit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:4:37" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> A. 4, 37</bibl></cit>.—So in questions, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:4:5:3" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 4, 5, 3</bibl>.—Also et alioqui in Pliny: afficior curā; et alioqui meus pudor, mea dignitas in discrimen adducitur, Plin Ep. 2, 9, 1; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:ib. 10:42:2" default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 10, 42, 2</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:Pan. 45:4" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Pan. 45, 4</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:68:7" default="NO">68, 7</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:7:9" default="NO">7, 9</bibl>.—And in copulative clauses with <hi rend="ital">et ... et</hi>, <hi rend="ital">cum ... tum</hi>, etc., <hi rend="ital">both in general</hi> (or <hi rend="ital">in other respects</hi>) ... <hi rend="ital">and</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">et alioqui opportune situm, et transitus eā est in Labeates,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:43:19" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 43, 19</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">mors Marcelli cum alioqui miserabilis fuit, tum quod, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:27:27:11" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 27, 27, 11</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:5:6:4" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 5, 6, 4</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:12:10:63" default="NO">12, 10, 63</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n1852.4" n="B" level="2"> To indicate that something is in itself situated so and so, or avails in a certain manner, <hi rend="ital">in itself</hi>, <hi rend="ital">even in itself</hi>, <hi rend="ital">himself</hi>, etc.: corpus, quod illa (Phryne) speciosissima alioqui (<hi rend="ital">in herself even most beautiful</hi>) diductā nudaverat tunicā, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:2:15:9" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 2, 15, 9</bibl> Spald.; 10, 3, 13; 2, 1, 4.—</sense><sense id="n1852.5" n="C" level="2"> Ellipt. like the Gr. <foreign lang="greek">a)/llws</foreign>, and commonly placed at the beginning of a clause, to indicate that something must happen, if the previous assertion or assumption shall not be (which fact is not <pb n="86" /> <cb n="ALIQ" /> expressed), <hi rend="ital">otherwise</hi>, <hi rend="ital">else</hi> (cf. aliter, b. <foreign lang="greek">g</foreign>): <cit><quote lang="la">vidistine aliquando Clitumnum fontem? si nondum (et puto nondum: alioqui narrāsses mihi),</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1318,001:8:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> Ep. 8, 8</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:1:20" default="NO" valid="yes">1, 20</bibl>: Nec, si pugnent inter se, qui idem didicerunt, idcirco ars, quae utrique tradita est, non erit; <cit><quote lang="la">alioqui nec armorum, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:2:17:33" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 2, 17, 33</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:4:2:23" default="NO"><author>id.</author> 4, 2, 23</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">non inornata debet esse brevitas, alioqui sit indocta,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:4:2:46" default="NO"><author>id.</author> 4, 2, 46</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Da mihi liberos, alioquin moriar,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,001:30:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Gen. 30, 1</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,001:6:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> Matt. 6, 1</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,019:9:17" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> Heb. 9, 17</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">languescet alioqui industria, si nullus ex se metus aut spes,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:2:38" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 2, 38</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n1852.6" n="D" level="2"> (Eccl. Lat.) As an <hi rend="ital">advers. conj.</hi>, <hi rend="ital">but</hi> (cf. ceterum and the Gr. <foreign lang="greek">a)lla/</foreign>): <cit><quote lang="la">alioquin mitte manum tuam et tange os ejus et carnem,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Vulg.</author> Job, 2, 5</bibl></cit>. Cf. Hand, Turs. I. pp. 234-241.</sense></entryFree>
aliorsum: <entryFree id="n1853" type="main" key="a^li^orsum"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ălĭorsum</orth> or <orth extent="full" lang="la">aliorsus</orth>, also twice not contr. <orth extent="full" lang="la">ălĭo-vorsum</orth> and <orth extent="full" lang="la">ălĭō-versus</orth>, <pos>adv.</pos> <sense id="n1853.0" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>, <hi rend="ital">directed to another place</hi> (<hi rend="ital">other men</hi>, <hi rend="ital">objects;</hi> cf.: alias, alibi, alio, etc.), <hi rend="ital">in another direction</hi>, <hi rend="ital">elsewhither</hi>, <hi rend="ital">elsewhere</hi> (Aliorsum et illorsum sicut introrsum dixit Cato, Paul. ex. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=27" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 27</bibl> Müll.; only ante- and post-class.). </sense><sense id="n1853.1" n="A" level="2"> Of place: <cit><quote lang="la">mater ancillas jubet ... aliam aliorsum ire,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,020:2:4:47" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Truc. 2, 4, 47</bibl></cit> (where aliam aliorsum is like alius alio, etc.): <cit><quote lang="la">jumentum aliorsum ducere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:7:15" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 7, 15</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">lupi aliorsum grassantes,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>App.</author> M. 8, p. 209</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n1853.2" n="B" level="2"> Of persons: <cit><quote lang="la">infantis aliorsum dati facta amolitio,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:12:1" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 12, 1</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n1853.3" n="C" level="2"> Of things: <cit><quote lang="la">sed id aliorsum pertinet,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:17:1" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 17, 1</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n1853.4" n="II" level="1"> Fig., = in aliam partem or rationem, <hi rend="ital">in another manner</hi>, <hi rend="ital">in a different sense;</hi> so in Terence: aliorsum aliquid accipere, <hi rend="ital">to receive something in another manner</hi> or <hi rend="ital">otherwise</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to take it differently</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">vereor, ne aliorsum atque ego feci acceperit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,003:1:2:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Eun. 1, 2, 1</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,003:2:4:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Aul. 2, 4, 8</bibl>, atqui ego istuc, Antrax, aliovorsum dixeram, <hi rend="ital">with another design</hi>, <hi rend="ital">in a different sense</hi>: alioversus, uncontr. in <bibl default="NO"><author>Lact.</author> 1, 17, 1</bibl>. Cf. Hand, Turs. I. pp. 241 and 242.</sense></entryFree>
alioversus: <entryFree id="n1854" type="main" key="a^li^o_versus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ălĭōversus</orth>, <sense id="n1854.0" n="I" level="1"><xr><lbl>v.</lbl> <ref type="sym" targOrder="U">the preced.</ref></xr></sense></entryFree>
alipes: <entryFree id="n1855" type="main" key="a_li^pe_s"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ālĭpēs</orth>, <itype>ĕdis</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> (<case>abl.</case> alipedi, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1035,001:5:612" default="NO"><author>Val. Fl.</author> 5, 612</bibl>, like aliti from ales) [ala-pes] (<usg type="style">poet.</usg> and rare; never in Hor.). <sense id="n1855.0" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>, <hi rend="ital">with wings on the feet</hi>, <hi rend="ital">wing-footed.</hi>—As an epithet of Mercury: <cit><quote lang="la">sacra alipedis dei,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,007:5:100" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> F. 5, 100</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:11:312" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> M. 11, 312</bibl>; <cit><quote lang="la">also simply Alipes for Mercurius: mactatur vacca Minervae, Alipedi vitulus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,010:4:754" default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 4, 754</bibl></cit>.—So of <hi rend="ital">the horses in the chariot of the Sun</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:2:48" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 2, 48</bibl>.— Hence, </sense><sense id="n1855.1" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Transf.</usg>, <hi rend="ital">swift</hi>, <hi rend="ital">fleet</hi>, <hi rend="ital">quick</hi> (cf. ales, I.): cervi, * Lucr 6, 766; <cit><quote lang="la">equi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:12:484" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 12, 484</bibl></cit>; also alipes, <hi rend="ital">absol.</hi> for equus, <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 7, 277</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">alipedi curru,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1035,001:5:612" default="NO"><author>Val. Fl.</author> 5, 612</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1345,001:7:700" default="NO"><author>Sil.</author> 7, 700</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
aliphae: <entryFree id="n1856" type="main" key="A^li_phae"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ălīphae</orth> and <orth extent="full" lang="la">Ălīphānus</orth>, v. Allifae.</entryFree>
aliphera: <entryFree id="n1857" type="main" key="A^li_phe_ra"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ălīphēra</orth> or <orth extent="full" lang="la">Ălīphīra</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*)ali/fhra</foreign>, Paus., <foreign lang="greek">*)ali/feira</foreign>, Polyb., <sense id="n1857.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a town in Arcadia</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:6:2:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 6, 2, 3</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:28:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 28, 8</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:32:5" default="NO" valid="yes">32, 5</bibl>; <hi rend="ital">its inhabitants</hi>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">Ălīphīraei</orth>, <itype>orum</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:4:22" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 4, 6, 10, § 22</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
alipilus: <entryFree id="n1858" type="main" key="a_li^pi^lus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ālĭpĭlus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <etym>ala- 1. pilus</etym>, <sense id="n1858.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a slave who plucked the hair from the armpits of the bathers</hi> (cf. ala, II.): <cit><quote lang="la">alipilum cogita tenuem et stridulam vocem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Ep. 56:2" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Ep. 56, 2</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">M. OCTAVIVS PRIMIGENIVS ALIPILVS A TRITONE,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Inscr. Grut.</author> 812, 6</bibl></cit> (cf. <bibl default="NO"><author>Inscr. Orell.</author> 4302</bibl>).</sense></entryFree>
aliptes: <entryFree id="n1859" type="greek" key="a^lipte_s"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăliptēs</orth> or <orth extent="full" lang="la">ălipta</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)lei/pths</foreign>, <sense id="n1859.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the manager in the school for wrestlers</hi>, who took care that the wrestlers anointed their bodies with unguents, in order to give them the necessary suppleness, and exercised them in the ring, <hi rend="ital">master of wrestling</hi>, or <hi rend="ital">of the ring</hi>: ut aliptae, virium et coloris rationem habere, * <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:1:9:15" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 1, 9, 15</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">Geometres, pictor, aliptes,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1276,001:3:76" default="NO"><author>Juv.</author> 3, 76</bibl></cit>; <cit><quote lang="la">aliptā egere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0836,001:1:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cels.</author> 1, 1</bibl></cit> Daremb.</sense></entryFree>
aliqua: <entryFree id="n1860" type="main" key="a^li^qua_"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ălĭquā</orth>, <pos>adv.</pos>, v. <itype>aliquis</itype>, <pos>adv.</pos> D.</entryFree>
aliquam: <entryFree id="n1861" type="main" key="a^li^quam"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ălĭquam</orth>, <pos>adv.</pos>, v. <itype>aliquis</itype>, <pos>adv.</pos> C.</entryFree>
aliquamdiu: <entryFree id="n1862" type="main" key="a^li^quamdi^u"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ălĭquamdĭu</orth>, v. <itype>aliquis</itype>, <pos>adv.</pos> C. 1.</entryFree>
aliquando: <entryFree id="n1863" type="main" key="a^li^quando^"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ălĭquandŏ</orth>, <sense id="n1863.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">temp. adv.</hi> [aliquis; Corssen, Ausspr. II. p. 856, regards the affix in this word and in quando as from an earlier -da = dies]. </sense><sense id="n1863.1" n="I. A." level="1"> In opp. to a definite, fixed point of time, <hi rend="ital">at some time</hi> or <hi rend="ital">other</hi>, <hi rend="ital">once; at any time</hi>, <hi rend="ital">ever</hi> (i. e. at an indefinite, undetermined time, of the past, present, and future; mostly in affirmative clauses, while umquam is only used of past and future time, and in negative clauses or those implying doubt; cf. Beier ad <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:2:14:51" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Off. 2, 14, 51</bibl>).—Of the past: neque ego umquam fuisse tale monstrum in terris ullum puto: quis clarioribus viris quodam tempore jucundior? quis turpioribus conjunctior:<cb n="ALIQ" />  quis civis meliorum partium aliquando? <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,024:5:12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Cael. 5, 12</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">Ad quem angelorum dixit aliquando, Sede etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,019:1:13" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Heb. 1, 13</bibl></cit>.—Of the future: <cit><quote lang="la">erit illud profecto tempus et illucescet aliquando ille dies, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,031:26:69" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Mil. 26, 69</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">cave, ne aliquando peccato consentias,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Vulg.</author> Tob. 4, 6</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">huic utinam aliquando gratiam referre possimus! Habebimus quidem semper,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:14:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 14, 4</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ne posset aliquando ad bellum faciendum locus ipse adhortari,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:1:11:35" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Off. 1, 11, 35</bibl></cit>.—Of the present: de rationibus et de controversiis societatis vult dijudicari. Sero: verum aliquando tamen, <hi rend="ital">but yet once</hi>, in opp. to <hi rend="ital">not at all</hi>, <hi rend="ital">never</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Quint. 13, 43</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n1863.2" n="B" level="2"> With <hi rend="ital">non</hi>, <hi rend="ital">nec</hi> (eccl. Lat.): <cit><quote lang="la">non peccabitis aliquando,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Vulg.</author> 2</bibl></cit> Pet. 1, 10: <cit><quote lang="la">nec aliquando defuit quidquam iis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,011:25:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> 1 Reg. 25, 7</bibl></cit>; 25, 15; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,056:14:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> Dan. 14, 6</bibl>; ib 1 Thess. 2, 5.—</sense><sense id="n1863.3" n="C" level="2"> In connection with <hi rend="ital">ullus</hi>, and oftener, esp. in Cic., with <hi rend="ital">aliquis</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">quaerere ea num vel e Philone vel ex ullo Academico audivisset aliquando,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Ac. 2, 4, 11</bibl></cit>: Forsitan aliquis aliquando ejusmodi quidpiam fecerit. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:32:78" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Verr. 2, 32, 78</bibl>; <cit><quote lang="la">ego quia dico aliquid aliquando, et quia, ut fit, in multis exit aliquando aliquid, etc.,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Planc 14, 35</bibl></cit>; <cit><quote lang="la">non despero fore aliquem aliquando,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:1:21:95" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> de Or. 1, 21, 95</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">docendo etiam aliquid aliquando,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,040:42:144" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Or. 42, 144</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Nam aut erit hic aliquid aliquando, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:7:11:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Fam. 7, 11, 2</bibl></cit>.—So with <hi rend="ital">quisquis</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">nec quidquam aliquando periit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,011:25:15" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> 1 Reg. 25, 15</bibl></cit>; 25, 7.—</sense><sense id="n1863.4" n="D" level="2"> Si forte aliquando or si aliquando, <hi rend="ital">if at any time</hi>, <hi rend="ital">if ever;</hi> or of a distant, but undefined, point of time, <hi rend="ital">if once</hi>, <hi rend="ital">at one time</hi>, or <hi rend="ital">one day</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">si quid hujus simile forte aliquando evenerit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,002:3:2:40" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Heaut. 3, 2, 40</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quod si aliquando manus ista plus valuerit quam vestra ac rei publicae dignitas, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,013:4:10:20" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Cat. 4, 10, 20</bibl></cit>: ampla domus dedecori saepe domino fit, et maxime si aliquando alio domino solita est frequentari, <hi rend="ital">once</hi>, i. e. <hi rend="ital">at a former time</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:1:39:139" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Off. 1, 39, 139</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n1863.5" n="E" level="2"> It is often used (opp.: in praesentiā, nunc, adhuc) of an indefinite, past, or future time = olim, quondam, <hi rend="ital">once</hi>, <hi rend="ital">formerly; in future time</hi>, <hi rend="ital">hereafter</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">quod sit in praesentiā de honestate delibatum, virtute aliquando et industriā recuperetur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,036:2:58:174" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Inv. 2, 58, 174</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">aliquando nobis libertatis tempus fuisse, quod pacis vobiscum non fuerit: nunc certe, etc., Liv 25, 29: Iol ad mare, aliquando ignobilis, nunc illustris,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0929,001:1:6" default="NO"><author>Mel.</author> 1, 6</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Qui aliquando non populus, nunc autem populus Dei,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Vulg.</author> 1</bibl></cit> Pet. 2, 10; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,018:11" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> Philem. 11</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">quam concedis adhuc artem omnino non esse, sed aliquando, etc.,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> de Or 1, 58, 246</bibl></cit>.—Sometimes the point of time in contrast can be determined only from the context: <cit><quote lang="la">quaerere num e Philone audivisset aliquando,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Ac. Pr. 2, 4, 11</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">veritus sum deesse Pompeii saluti, cum ille aliquando non defuisset meae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:6:6:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Fam. 6, 6, 10</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">aut quisquam nostri misereri potest, qui aliquando vobis hostis fuit?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:J. 14:17" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> J. 14, 17</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Zacynthus aliquando appellata Hyrie,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:4:54" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 4, 12, 19, § 54</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1318,001:6:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> Ep. 6, 10</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">quae aliquando viderat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,001:42:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Gen. 42, 9</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO"><author>ib.</author> 1</bibl> Pet. 3, 20.—</sense><sense id="n1863.6" n="II" level="1"> Of that which at times happens, in contrast with that which never or seldom occurs, <hi rend="ital">sometimes</hi>, <hi rend="ital">now and then</hi> = non numquam, interdum (opp.: numquam, raro; semper, saepe). </sense><sense id="n1863.7" n="A" level="2"> Te non numquam a me alienārunt, et me aliquando immutārunt tibi, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:5:8:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 5, 8, 2</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">liceret ei dicere utilitatem aliquando cum honestate pugnare,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:3:3:12" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Off. 3, 3, 12</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">sitne aliquando mentiri boni viri?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:3:29:113" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> de Or. 3, 29, 113</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:5:13:31" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 5, 13, 31</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">multa proelia et aliquando non cruenta,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,001:17" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> Agr. 17</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=aug.:43" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Aug. 43</bibl>.— </sense><sense id="n1863.8" n="B" level="2"> With <hi rend="ital">numquam</hi>, <hi rend="ital">raro; semper</hi>, <hi rend="ital">saepe</hi>, <hi rend="ital">saepius</hi>, <hi rend="ital">modo</hi> in another clause: <cit><quote lang="la">convertit se aliquando ad timorem, numquam ad sanitatem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,015:5:17" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Sull. 5, 17</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">senatumque et populum numquam obscura nomina, etiam si aliquando obumbrentur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,004:2:32" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> H. 2, 32</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quod non saepe, atque haud scio an umquam, in aliquā parte eluceat aliquando,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,040:2:7" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Or. 2, 7</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">raro, sed aliquando tamen, ex metu delirium nascitur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0836,001:3:18" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cels.</author> 3, 18</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0836,001:8:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 8, 4</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0836,001:1" default="NO" valid="yes">1</bibl> praef.: <cit><quote lang="la">aliquando ... semper,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:45:23:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 45, 23, 8</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">aliquando fortuna, semper animo maximus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1044,001:2:18" default="NO"><author>Vell.</author> 2, 18</bibl></cit>: Haud semper errat fama; <cit><quote lang="la">aliquando et elegit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,001:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> Agr. 9</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">aliquando ... saepe,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0836,001:1 praef" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cels.</author> 1 praef.</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">nec tamen ubique cerni, aliquando propter nubila, saepius globo terrae obstante,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:2:56" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 2, 13, 10, § 56</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:3:27" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 3, 27</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,001:38" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Agr. 38</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n1863.9" n="C" level="2"> In partitive clauses, twice, or even several times, like modo—modo, sometimes also alternating <cb n="ALIQ" /> with <hi rend="ital">non numquam</hi> or <hi rend="ital">modo</hi> (so only in the post-Aug. per.), <hi rend="ital">at one time ... at another</hi>, <hi rend="ital">now.. now</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">confirmatio aliquando totius causae est, aliquando partium,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:5:13:58" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 5, 13, 58</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:17:262" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 17, 28, 47, § 262</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Q. N. 2:36:2" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Q. N. 2, 36, 2</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">aliquando emicat stella, aliquando ardores sunt, aliquando fixi et haerentes, non numquam volubiles,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:ib. 1:14" default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 1, 14</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=cal.:52" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Calig. 52</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">Vespasianus modo in spem erectus, aliquando adversa reputabat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,004:2:74" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> H. 2, 74</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:16:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> A. 16, 10</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n1863.10" n="D" level="2"> In colloquial lang., to indicate that there is occasion for a certain thing, <hi rend="ital">once</hi>, <hi rend="ital">for once</hi>, <hi rend="ital">on this occasion</hi>, <hi rend="ital">now</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">aliquando osculando melius est, uxor, pausam fieri,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,017:4:6:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Rud. 4, 6, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">sed si placet, sermonem alio transferamus, et nostro more aliquando, non rhetorico loquamur,</quote> <trans><tr>now in our own way</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:1:29:133" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> de Or. 1, 29, 133</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">sed ne plura: dicendum enim aliquando est, Pomponium Atticum sic amo, ut alterum fratrem,</quote> <trans><tr>I must for once say it</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:13:1:14" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Fam. 13, 1, 14</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n1863.11" n="E" level="2"> In commands, exhortations, or wishes, = tandem, <hi rend="ital">at length</hi>, <hi rend="ital">now at last</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">audite quaeso, judices, et aliquando miseremini sociorum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:28:72" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Verr. 1, 28, 72</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">mode scribe aliquando ad nos, quid agas,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:7:12:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Fam. 7, 12, 2</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">stulti, aliquando sapite,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,027:93:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Psa. 93, 8</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ipse agat, ut orbatura patres aliquando fulmina ponat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:2:391" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 2, 391</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Aliquando isti principes sibi populi Romani auctoritati parendum esse fateantur,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Imp. Pomp. 22, 64</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Verr. 4, 37, 81</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:J. 14:21" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> J. 14, 21</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:2:390" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 2, 390</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">et velim aliquando, cum erit tuum commodum, Lentulum puerum visas,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:12:28" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 12, 28</bibl></cit>.—Hence, </sense><sense id="n1863.12" n="F" level="1"> Of that which happens after long expectation or delay, freq. in connection with <hi rend="ital">tandem</hi>, <hi rend="ital">finally</hi>, <hi rend="ital">at length</hi>, <hi rend="ital">now at last</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">quibus (quaestionibus) finem aliquando amicorum auctoritas fecit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,010:67:191" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Clu. 67, 191</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">(dii) placati jam vel satiati aliquando,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,032:6:18" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Marcell. 6, 18</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">collegi me aliquando,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,010:18:51" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Clu. 18, 51</bibl></cit>: aliquando idque sero usum loquendi populo concessi, <hi rend="ital">finally.</hi> i. e. after I have for a long time spoken in another manner, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,040:48:160" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Or. 48, 160</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">te aliquando collaudare possum, quod jam, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:7:17" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Fam. 7, 17</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=aug.:70" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Aug. 70</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">diu exspectaverant, dum retia extraherentur: aliquando extractis piscis nullus infuit,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Clar. Rhet. 1</bibl></cit>.—With <hi rend="ital">tandem</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">aliquando tandem huc animum ut adducas tuum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,005:4:4:61" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Hec. 4, 4, 61</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">spes est et hunc aliquan do tandem posse consistere,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Quint. 30, 94</bibl></cit> tandem aliquando L. Catilinam ex urbe ejecimus, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,013:2:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Cat. 2, 1</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">ut tandem aliquando timere desinam,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 1, 7, 18</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Quint. 30, 94</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">servus tandem aliquando mihi a te exspectatissimas litteras reddidit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:16:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Fam. 16, 9</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">tandem aliquando refloruistis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,011:4:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Phil. 4, 10</bibl></cit>.—With <hi rend="ital">jam</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">utile esse te aliquando jam rem transigere,</quote> <trans><tr>now at length</tr></trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:1:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 1, 4</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
aliquantillum: <entryFree id="n1864" type="hapax" key="a^li^quantillum"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ălĭquantillum</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>n.</gen> <sense id="n1864.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">adj. doub. dim</hi> [aliquantulus], <hi rend="ital">a very little indeed</hi>, <hi rend="ital">a little bit</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">foris aliquantillum gusto,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,005:1:2:28" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Capt. 1, 2, 28</bibl></cit></sense></entryFree>
aliquantisper: <entryFree id="n1865" type="main" key="a^li^quantisper"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ălĭquantisper</orth>, <sense id="n1865.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">adv. temp.</hi> [aliquantus-per; analog. to paulisper], <hi rend="ital">for a moderate period of time</hi> (neither too long nor too short), <hi rend="ital">for a while</hi>, <hi rend="ital">for a time</hi>, <hi rend="ital">for some time</hi> (ante-class. and post-Aug.): concedere aliquantisper hinc mihi intro libet, * <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,016:1:5:158" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Ps. 1, 5, 158</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">Quor non ludo hunc aliquantisper?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,006:4:5:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Ad. 4, 5, 5</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">concedas aliquo ab ore eorum aliquantisper,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,002:3:3:11" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Heaut. 3, 3, 11</bibl></cit>: si illi egestate aliquantisper jacti forent, Caecil. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> 511, 27</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1242,001:2:18:14" default="NO"><author>Flor.</author> 2, 18, 14</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">sed ille simulato timore diu continuit se, et insultare Parthos aliquantisper passus est,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:42:4:8" default="NO"><author>Just.</author> 42, 4, 8</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:1:8:3" default="NO"><author>id.</author> 1, 8, 3</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
aliquanto: <entryFree id="n1866" type="main" key="a^li^quanto_"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ălĭquantō</orth> and <orth extent="full" lang="la">ălĭquantum</orth>, <pos>adv.</pos>, v. aliquantus.</entryFree>
aliquantorsum: <entryFree id="n1867" type="main" key="a^li^quantorsum"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ălĭquantorsum</orth>, <pos>adv.</pos> of place [aliquanto-versum], <sense id="n1867.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">somewhat toward</hi> (a place). Perlati aliquantorsum longius, quam sperabamus, pergamus ad reliqua, <hi rend="ital">on some what</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Amm.</author> 22, 8, 48</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
aliquantulum: <entryFree id="n1868" type="main" key="a^li^quantu^lum"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ălĭquantŭlum</orth>, <pos>adv.</pos>, v. aliquantulus.</entryFree>
aliquantulus: <entryFree id="n1869" type="main" key="a^li^quantu^lus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ălĭquantŭlus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <sense id="n1869.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">adj. dim.</hi> [aliquantus], <hi rend="ital">little</hi>, <hi rend="ital">small</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">aliquantulus frumenti numerus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0530,001:B. Afr. 21" default="NO"><author>Hirt.</author> B. Afr. 21</bibl></cit>.—In the <hi rend="ital">neutr.</hi> as <hi rend="ital">subst.</hi> with <hi rend="ital">partit. gen.</hi>, <hi rend="ital">a little</hi> aeris alieni, <bibl default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Quint. 4, 15</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">suspitionis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,036:2:9" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Inv. 2, 9</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">muri,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:21:12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 21, 12</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">agri,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:21:31" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 21, 31</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">aquae tepidae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=nero:48" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Ner. 48</bibl></cit>.— Hence, <orth extent="full" lang="la">ălĭquantŭlum</orth>, <itype>and once</itype>, <orth extent="full" lang="la">ălĭ-quantŭlō</orth>, <pos>adv.</pos>, <hi rend="ital">somewhat</hi>, <hi rend="ital">a little</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">pansam aliquantulum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,011:3:4:55" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Merc. 3, 4, 55</bibl></cit>: quaeso tandem aliquantulum tibi parce. <pb n="87" /> <cb n="ALIQ" /> rer. Heaut. 1, 1, 111: <cit><quote lang="la">subtristis visust esse aliquantulum mihi,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> And. 2, 6, 16</bibl></cit>: auri navem evertat gubernator an paleae, in re aliquantulum, in gubernatoris inscitiā nihil interest, <hi rend="ital">something</hi> (ironic. for aliquid, multum), <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,047:3:1" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Par. 3, 1</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">deflexit jam aliquantulum de spatio curriculoque consuetudo majorum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,052:12:40" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Lael. 12, 40</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">aliquantulum progredi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,053:1:33:73" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Div. 1, 33, 73</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">a proposito declinare,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,040:40:138" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Or. 40, 138</bibl></cit>.—With <hi rend="ital">comp.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">stadia aliquantulum breviora,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:1:1" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 1, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">aliquantulo tristior,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Vop.</author> Aur. 38</bibl></cit> Gruter.</sense></entryFree>
aliquantus: <entryFree id="n1870" type="main" key="a^li^quantus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ălĭquantus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>alius-quantus; v. aliquis</etym>, <sense id="n1870.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">somewhat</hi>, <hi rend="ital">some</hi>, <hi rend="ital">moderate</hi>, <hi rend="ital">tolerable; considerable</hi>, <hi rend="ital">not a little</hi> (designating the medium between much and little; cf. Ernest. ad <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=jul.:87" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Caes. 87</bibl>; Wolf ad <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=jul.:10" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Caes. 10</bibl>; Hotting. ad <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,053:2:1" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Div. 2, 1</bibl>; Herz. ad <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:3:13" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 3, 13</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">5, 10</bibl>; Brut. ad <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,001:Dion, 3:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Dion, 3, 3</bibl>; Kritz ad <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:C. 8:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> C. 8, 2</bibl>). </sense><sense id="n1870.1" n="I" level="1"> In gen.: <hi rend="ital">M.</hi> sed quaero, utrum aliquid actum superioribus diebus, an nihil arbitremur: <hi rend="ital">A.</hi> Actum vero et aliquantum quidem, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:5:6:15" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 5, 6, 15</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">Romani signorum et armorum aliquanto numero, hostium paucorum potiti,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:J. 74:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> J. 74, 3</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">timor aliquantus, sed spes amplior,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:ib. 105:4" default="NO"
